number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 2, 2016
												Sonic Generations is the 20th anniversary game and features both the 2D and 3D gameplay from past Sonic the Hedgehog games. So, to know if this game is worth to be played, let’s get down the road and review this game.Story:The game starts as Sonic from the past (who is known as Classic Sonic is this game) running at Green Hill Zone when a weird monster-like creature appeared. In the next part, Sonic from the present (who is known as Modern Sonic) gets a surprise birthday party from his friends. But before they could start celebrating, the monsters-thingy appeared out of nowhere and kidnaps Sonic’s friends and Sonic chases the monster to save his friends. Modern Sonic travels throughout different levels that seem to be very familiar to him, and realizes that he had visited the zones before- he traveled back to the past. There, he met someone who look like him, albeit younger. Modern Sonic teams up with his past self, Classic Sonic, to save their friends and restore color to the world.Gameplay:This game has two gameplay style based on your character. Classic Sonic represents the games from the Sega Genesis/Mega Drive and features 2D gameplay, while Modern Sonic represents the games from the 3D games such as Sonic Adventures and features its 3D platforming gameplay. You can choose freely who to use when you’re at the hub are of the game or when selecting a level. Act 1 is Classic Sonic while Act 2 is Modern Sonic.Classic Sonic features skills that he used before from classic titles. Classic Sonic uses skills like Spin Dash and Spin Charge to boost his speed and attack enemies. You could also use the down on the analog stick while running to attack enemies. Since he is in a 2D environment, Sonic could only move left and right to proceed throughout the level.Modern Sonic features skills that are used in 3D Sonic the Hedgehog titles such as Sonic Adventures. Modern Sonic can move freely on the field and can Auto Lock-On enemies to use Homing Attack. Modern Sonic can use the X Button to Dash at enemies at full speed and it has a meter that can be replenished using Rings that are scattered throughout the level.The goal of each level is simple: Run through the 3 stages, play the challenges to get the keys to the boss then defeat the boss to unlock the next 3 stages. Challenges offers different goals to complete it such as using a certain power up, defeating a doppelganger, teaming up with another character, and many more.Graphics:The graphics of this game looks great even though it was released back in 2011. The art style is nice, as the stages greatly resembles its appearance from the game where it came from and the characters were created neatly. The water movement from water levels also has its graphics rendered very well. The animation for wind effects, fiery explosion, facial expressions were great and well animated. The aesthetics for the buildings and smoke in Crisis City Zone, the seafloor at the Seaside Hill Zone, the skyscrapers at Speed Highway Zone are very excellent, as if you’re looking at a piece of art.My only problem is the Hub Zone. It was very bland compared to the hub zones in Sonic Adventure. Also, you can only explore the hub in a side scrolling fashion, but not in 3D open world exploration. Although maybe it’s because of the game’s story? Oh.Music:Most Sonic games’ soundtracks were a piece of art and give us thrills and excitement throughout a level. Well, guess what? Those soundtracks are back and some of them are remixed to suit the level. Playable stages had their themes remixed and both 2D and 3D version of each stage has its own remixed theme. For example, the theme for Green Hill Zone Act 1 (Classic Stage) has the music closely resemble the Genesis version while Act 2 (Modern Stage) gives an upbeat music compare to the Act 1 version.Other tracks from other Sonic games such as Open your Heart and Live and Learn can be collected and use that soundtrack to change the stage’s music. Who wouldn’t want to run on Speed Highway with Live and Learn as the background music?Presentation:The game is divided into three segments: Classic or Genesis era, Dreamcast era, and Modern era. They each have 3 stages from the games of their respective era, along with a boss stage and a rival stage. You will see stages such as Green Hill Zone, Chemical Plant, City Escape, and so on. These stages are created to mimic their appearances from past Sonic games and has a major overhaul for 2D and 3D gameplay. For example, the Green Hill Zone’s Act stage is based on the stage of the same name from the very first stage of Sonic the Hedgehog game on Genesis. It has its 3 act combined into 1 stage for Sonic Generations in the 2D segment and created an entirely new version of the stage for the 3D gameplay of Modern Sonic.The game also features extra stages were you can do challenges like gathering certain amount of rings or catching certain number of Chaos. It’s a great and fun alternative when you wanted to replay a stage but with more challenge. Finishing them gives you unlockables such as artwork, concept art, and music from other Sonic titles.Characters from the Sonic franchise appears and although not playable, they served as Sonic’s friend/rival on different extra stages. Characters like Knuckles and Tails help Sonic in some stage like destroying an obstacle. They also appear as rivals, like Knuckles having a race against Sonic.Despite that, the extra stages were kind of repetitive due to the challenges mostly racing, collecting certain number of rings or reach the goal before time runs out.Overall:After suffering from broken games these past few years (*cough* Sonic 06 *cough*) Sega managed to create a great game that gives both nostalgic and new feel to gamers. Not only that they presented and combined some amazing stages, but they also managed to recreate it without losing its touch. The stages are still awesome like their past counterpart. The story feels a little weak compare to the story of Sonic Adventure and Sonic Colors, but still is great since it was simple, unlike the Sonic 06 complicated story. The game was great and I recommend this game to you all gamers out there.

content:
Posted: December 13, 2013
												The best game of all time. I am a huge Sonic fan, but this is a really good game even if you aren't a sonic fan. Buy it now! The only thing I have to complain about is that it's pretty short, but you have some side missions as well to go through as well.Multiplayer would also be nice. You can compare times, but that's about it. It would be nice to have like a race or to play it through with co-op. One play as Sonic and the other one plays as Tails, kinda like Sonic 4 ep 2. That would be awesome.Keep in mind that if you have too many friends, you can't access the multiplayer part. It's a bug in the game that probably never will be fixed. For this, I've changed the rating of it from a 9 to a 8.This game gets an 8/10.

content:
Posted: August 2, 2016
												Sonic Generations is the 20th anniversary game and features both the 2D and 3D gameplay from past Sonic the Hedgehog games. So, to know if this game is worth to be played, let’s get down the road and review this game.Story:The game starts as Sonic from the past (who is known as Classic Sonic is this game) running at Green Hill Zone when a weird monster-like creature appeared. In the next part, Sonic from the present (who is known as Modern Sonic) gets a surprise birthday party from his friends. But before they could start celebrating, the monsters-thingy appeared out of nowhere and kidnaps Sonic’s friends and Sonic chases the monster to save his friends. Modern Sonic travels throughout different levels that seem to be very familiar to him, and realizes that he had visited the zones before- he traveled back to the past. There, he met someone who look like him, albeit younger. Modern Sonic teams up with his past self, Classic Sonic, to save their friends and restore color to the world.Gameplay:This game has two gameplay style based on your character. Classic Sonic represents the games from the Sega Genesis/Mega Drive and features 2D gameplay, while Modern Sonic represents the games from the 3D games such as Sonic Adventures and features its 3D platforming gameplay. You can choose freely who to use when you’re at the hub are of the game or when selecting a level. Act 1 is Classic Sonic while Act 2 is Modern Sonic.Classic Sonic features skills that he used before from classic titles. Classic Sonic uses skills like Spin Dash and Spin Charge to boost his speed and attack enemies. You could also use the down on the analog stick while running to attack enemies. Since he is in a 2D environment, Sonic could only move left and right to proceed throughout the level.Modern Sonic features skills that are used in 3D Sonic the Hedgehog titles such as Sonic Adventures. Modern Sonic can move freely on the field and can Auto Lock-On enemies to use Homing Attack. Modern Sonic can use the X Button to Dash at enemies at full speed and it has a meter that can be replenished using Rings that are scattered throughout the level.The goal of each level is simple: Run through the 3 stages, play the challenges to get the keys to the boss then defeat the boss to unlock the next 3 stages. Challenges offers different goals to complete it such as using a certain power up, defeating a doppelganger, teaming up with another character, and many more.Graphics:The graphics of this game looks great even though it was released back in 2011. The art style is nice, as the stages greatly resembles its appearance from the game where it came from and the characters were created neatly. The water movement from water levels also has its graphics rendered very well. The animation for wind effects, fiery explosion, facial expressions were great and well animated. The aesthetics for the buildings and smoke in Crisis City Zone, the seafloor at the Seaside Hill Zone, the skyscrapers at Speed Highway Zone are very excellent, as if you’re looking at a piece of art.My only problem is the Hub Zone. It was very bland compared to the hub zones in Sonic Adventure. Also, you can only explore the hub in a side scrolling fashion, but not in 3D open world exploration. Although maybe it’s because of the game’s story? Oh.Music:Most Sonic games’ soundtracks were a piece of art and give us thrills and excitement throughout a level. Well, guess what? Those soundtracks are back and some of them are remixed to suit the level. Playable stages had their themes remixed and both 2D and 3D version of each stage has its own remixed theme. For example, the theme for Green Hill Zone Act 1 (Classic Stage) has the music closely resemble the Genesis version while Act 2 (Modern Stage) gives an upbeat music compare to the Act 1 version.Other tracks from other Sonic games such as Open your Heart and Live and Learn can be collected and use that soundtrack to change the stage’s music. Who wouldn’t want to run on Speed Highway with Live and Learn as the background music?Presentation:The game is divided into three segments: Classic or Genesis era, Dreamcast era, and Modern era. They each have 3 stages from the games of their respective era, along with a boss stage and a rival stage. You will see stages such as Green Hill Zone, Chemical Plant, City Escape, and so on. These stages are created to mimic their appearances from past Sonic games and has a major overhaul for 2D and 3D gameplay. For example, the Green Hill Zone’s Act stage is based on the stage of the same name from the very first stage of Sonic the Hedgehog game on Genesis. It has its 3 act combined into 1 stage for Sonic Generations in the 2D segment and created an entirely new version of the stage for the 3D gameplay of Modern Sonic.The game also features extra stages were you can do challenges like gathering certain amount of rings or catching certain number of Chaos. It’s a great and fun alternative when you wanted to replay a stage but with more challenge. Finishing them gives you unlockables such as artwork, concept art, and music from other Sonic titles.Characters from the Sonic franchise appears and although not playable, they served as Sonic’s friend/rival on different extra stages. Characters like Knuckles and Tails help Sonic in some stage like destroying an obstacle. They also appear as rivals, like Knuckles having a race against Sonic.Despite that, the extra stages were kind of repetitive due to the challenges mostly racing, collecting certain number of rings or reach the goal before time runs out.Overall:After suffering from broken games these past few years (*cough* Sonic 06 *cough*) Sega managed to create a great game that gives both nostalgic and new feel to gamers. Not only that they presented and combined some amazing stages, but they also managed to recreate it without losing its touch. The stages are still awesome like their past counterpart. The story feels a little weak compare to the story of Sonic Adventure and Sonic Colors, but still is great since it was simple, unlike the Sonic 06 complicated story. The game was great and I recommend this game to you all gamers out there.

												The Sonic games have had a spotty record after the transition to 3D.I'm happy to say this is one of the good ones. And no, I don't feel like a 12 year old saying that.

content:
Posted: June 30, 2016
												I am a man in his 30s and I'm reviewing a Sonic game: Yes my existence is an embarrassing insult. That said someone my age is at the perfect point in their life where Sonic is prime nostalgia bait so indulge me. I admit I missed the "dark days" having not touched any of the games since Sonic 3 so my nostalgia may be very limited in its scope.Sonic Generations appears to be a Greatest hits compilation, taking the best bits from a number of prior Sonic games (at least from what I've seen on Youtube) and meshing them together with the most famous levels. I knew Chemical Plant and Green Hill Zone and they seemed to evoke the joys of the older games, and from what I saw of it City Escape looks like the footage of whatever game that was from, so I guess this is a nice and faithful remake. If anything it seems to be Sonic with all the fat stripped off giving a leaner and meaner game than some of the recently badly received titles.With each level there are two variations of how they play out, first a classic 2d sonic map with the old move set from Sonic 2 which is then followed by a modern Sonic map which feels more akin to a racing game in places. Regardless of which is played things usually pan out quite well with a good bead running through both setting the pace and mood for the game.Speaking of pace, Sonic Generations belts along at the rapid pace you would expect of the blue hedgehog. With the speed, momentum and physics system meshing with some very well planned levels the game's camera work and level design mesh to make a very satisfying experience. Sonic games have a somewhat unique design to levels, encouraging you to go higher in a mostly sprawling variety of paths rewarding the use of momentum by giving greater goodies, more interesting challenges and a brisker pace to clear the stage as opposed to the more mundane and slower lower paths. While this may sound like it would encourage exploration, the design is mainly egging the player to utilise the speed they build up. Missed the ledge with a jump? Screw it, make the best of what you have as you GOTTA GO FAST! I normally love exploring everything, but here doing so would break the endorphin rush of belting along. There are some slower sections where you do have to be mindful of enemies, but they rarely cause issues.So this game is all round lovely? Well, no. The above applies to the majority of the game, especially the first half. Maps like Green Hill Zone, Chemical Plant and City Escape are blooming fantastic, but later levels like Wisp Zone and Catastrophe City have some quirks to them with badly placed enemies plonked right in the way of speed zones where predicting their presence is a dice roll, also I found the momentum to throw Sonic off platforms at times where it did not make sense causing a lot of instant death pitfalls to occur. Annoyingly enough these moments tend to be in the modern Sonic levels giving more credence to the nostalgic older style being superior and left me not wanting to do the modern versions of the later levels, act 3 being more bad then good culminating in a confusing boss fight before leading to the final boss in the game being a pain in the rear end.Despite it's ropey later levels this is as highly rated a Sonic game can be post 1995. I did try a few of the other newer games while typing this up and they were quite depressing. There is more dreck then quality in this franchise, Sonic being some high profile rock star of the early 90s but aging badly due to what appears to be mismanagement and a strange self indulgence in his obsession with being cool. Like these aging rock stars there are brief moments where they may actually be able to pull it off and gets the old gang back together, though this is usually followed up with a relapse and an age of embarrassment. This is the greatest hits tour after the rehab. If you have ANY nostalgia for this series give Generations a shot, but after that is done it may be wise to stop and never come back.

content:
Posted: April 3, 2013
												Sonic Generations is a hidden "gem" among the other pretty terrible Sonic games out there. After beating the game I found it to be fun, but lackluster, nothing that stood out as a reason to recommend it; however, once I figured out that there was a huge modding community out there for the game my outlook on the game changed and I felt I had to mention it, if only briefly.Team Sonic has been doing some bad and some good in their games. The epitome of this mindset has to be Sonic Unleashed - there's a really cool part of the game where you go flying around through well designed levels at breakneck speeds collecting coints and almost getting dizzy from the camera movement while you race against time to reach the finish line. Those levels were amazing and fun. Then there were the "God of War"-esque levels coupled on there as well, which were slow, boring, and, sadly, mandatory. I bought that game on PS3 and hated it - not so much because the Were-Sonic sections were terrible (which they were) but because of the lost potential the game had. Well, Sonic Generations takes it in the right direction, utilizing those same awesome level types where you fly around at lightspeed but instead of a Were-Sonic you are granted an Oldschool-Sonic for Type B levels. This would be fine if that Sonic didn't handle like a 12-Ton dump truck. The physics seemed to work fine but the stopping and starting of the character were just awful, and I found myself using my trademark "spin" while accidentally moving so I'd be going at about 2 miles/hour while the time keeps ticking away and I keep getting more aggravated. Those levels weren't nearly as much fun as the other levels, and normally I wouldn't recommend half a game, but Sonic Generations on PC is unique in that the modding community allows you to turn the game into what you want to play. Want more of the good levels? Download the Sonic Generations Unleashed Project. Want to change the physics up to more of a "classic" Sonic feel? Go ahead, there's a mod for that too. The ability to swap in and out parts of the game that you don't like or want to experience more of really turns Sonic Generations into a hidden gem that can provide hours of fun for any level of Sonic fan.Pros:Mods (see above)Full Controller SupportGreat Level Design (for the most part - Modern Sonic levels shine)Good MusicCons:Handling/Controls (especially Classic Sonic)Fixed Camera (makes some platforming awkward)Unnecessary RPG-esque Upgrade System Leaderboards are a fun idea, but it's rampant with cheaters - first hundred or so entries on all boards are 0 second runsAs I said, I wouldn't recommend the game without the modding community backing me up. That said, even if you're only going to play vanilla, the game isn't terrible, and the Modern Sonic sections shine and show the level design genius Team Sonic has. With mods Sonic Generations squaks by with a B+

Posted: January 8, 2015
												This is a bloody good game! Sonic The Hedgehog at it's finest in this amazing blend of old and new. This is what modern Sonic The Hedgehog is supposed to be, Sonic Generations does everything it has set out to do beautifully and more than makes up for the disappointment that Sonic The Hedgehog (2006) turned out to be. In this mixture of old and new, Sonic Generations brings back an iconic level from each of the most popular Sonic The Hedgehog titles (such as Green Hill, Chemical Plant, City Escape etc.) with an act for both the retro Sonic 2D scroller style that we all grew up with and the more modern 3D Sonic Adventure style, both of which have their own unique features making them similar and familiar, but different enough to keep them interesting and fresh. The game also includes a museum of sorts and a nifty skills/perks feature for both the old and new Sonic. Plenty of mini-games, unlockables, achievements and side-stages that accompany the main game structure bring lots of replay value to the Sonic Generations too, there is quite a lot to do.With that being said, the only real problem with this game is that the story feels very short, it definitely could have benefited from some additional stages, but that doesn't make this any less of a great title. Sonic Generations is the modern version of Sonic The Hedgehog that we've been waiting for, this is what we wanted and SEGA delivered. If they remade all of the retro Sonic The Hedgehog games in the style of the Act 1 Sonic Generations levels, it would be perfect.  This is a must have for Sonic The Hedgehog fans, and even one to grab if you're new to the franchise, this game brings the best features from all the eras of sonic games together to make one fantastic game. Couldn't reccomend this more!

content:
Posted: December 2, 2013
												If you're a fan of Sonic Colors, and/or a fan of Sonic Unleashed's daytime stages, then I suggest you pick this game up. This game offers a set of nine individual levels from three eras of the Sonic franchise, ranging from the Sega Genesis to Nintendo Wii.The gameplay is a combination of Sonic Colors and Sonic The Hedgehog (Genesis Titles). Throughout Classic Sonic's stages, you'll be doing a lot of platforming in a 2D realm, whereas Modern Sonic you'll be doing a lot of boosting. The game offers two acts with every level- one for each Sonic.The graphics are simply superb. Playing this on the consoles doesn't do it justice. The console version runs at 30 FPS where the PC port runs at 60 FPS. The attention to detail in the levels are stunning as well. Green Hill Zone looks fantastic, and City Escape is absolutely beautiful. You can really see where San Francisco was the inspiration for that level. However, before purchasing this title, do realize that this game can get be very heavy on your PC at times. While I never experienced problems, my friends reported having some slowdown during some areas such as Chemical Plant and Planet Whisp. Also, it's recommended that you use an Xbox 360 and/or PC controller for this game. The game is worth the price, and it's a must have for any Sonic The Hedgehog fan. I suggest giving it a purchase and playing it now! If you're not sure, how about you click that "Download Demo" button up there at the top and give it a try. I gurantee you that it'll change your mind. ;)

content:
Posted: February 14, 2015
												I don’t consider myself a Sonic fan and I really don’t have any nostalgia for the series as a whole.  Most of my good memories come from Sonic and Knuckles, so it has been a long time since I played a Sonic game for any real length of time.   I discovered a nostalgia and love for Sonic through this game that I didn’t know existed. Its gameplay is simple but effective and its graphics and art charming.  No matter your level of respect or disdain for that little blue rodent this is a game worth exploring.The story starts off as Sonic celebrates his twentieth birthday, with a monster known as the Time Eater crashing the party and dispersing Sonic's friends to various stages in history. Sonic is knocked out after futily taking on the monster. He wakes up in the White Space dimension and encounters Tails, as well as his plumper, black-pupiled younger self. The two Sonics have to free their friends in two different versions of levels that have emerged over the years, and eventually defeat the monster summoned by Dr. Eggman. Modern Sonic utilises the game mechanics used in 3D games like Heroes and Colours. His homing attack allows him to lock-on to an enemy when he jumps at them and can boost through levels for additional speed. Classic Sonic handles the traditional side-scrolling levels, sporting the ability to spin-dash. Levels run at a slower pace as they require some more caution, and he also can’t auto aim at enemies or jump as far.Generations is something of a healthy montage of what comprised the first twenty years of Sonic games. The nine stages are all throwbacks from three console eras. Three zones from the heights of the ‘Classic Era’ have been lovingly reimagined, including the signature Green Hill. The ‘Dreamcast Era’ touches up Adventure’s Speed Highway and City Escape plus Sunside Beach from the later Heroes. The ‘Modern Era’ even revitalises Crisis City from the disastrous 2006 reboot, as well as Rooftop Run and Planet Wisp from Unleashed and Colours. Boss fights are dispersed between each era, but can only be unlocked upon completion of three side missions. These are usually comprised of another objective within a level, such as a ghost race or collecting items. Some are fun and others are less so, but aren’t a necessity to reach the end. Similarly to secret special stages in the originals, hidden stars encourage exploration of the multiple paths in each level. There are also the Red Rings hidden in the main stages to encourage players to explore every nook and cranny as both Sonics to find them. Ample rewards await players who take up all of these challenges in the form of new powers, which can be added to either Sonic's play mechanics to make old stages new again. These powers are hardly throwaway, but they're also hand-picked from Sonic's rich game history. Prepare to relive the fun of using the special elemental shields from Sonic 3, give Classic Sonic the Homing Attack, give Modern Sonic unlimited boost meter in exchange for one-hit death (one of my favorites), allow either Sonic to stop on a dime, or even endow the time-slowing skill from Secret Rings. There are dozens of these, and they're great for playing around in stages, exploration, or for finding the best combination for the fastest times.Bottom line: If you are or have ever been a fan of Sonic the Hedgehog during the series' two-decade history, then this is your game. Sega made this for us. If you've been away from Sonic for a while or have been wondering what he's all about, then this is actually a great game to start with, as it features the two best-playing versions of Sonic in the series, along with his greatest stages, all in one place. Play it however you can, even if you rent it, but whatever you do, don't call it "short" or "over quickly." There's enough game here to last potentially ages.


Sonic Generations Gameplay Demo 
A Video of Sonic Generations

content:
Posted: November 15, 2014
												This is practically a sonic game that allows you to relive some of the best moments of the sonic franchise.The game is split into two different game styles: old school and new school.Old school is where you play as classic sonic and remember the good old days of a simple(...ish) 2D platformer with the occassional jumping and dashing into robots, and going up against the evil nefarious Dr. Robotn--ahem, Eggman.And new school is practically taking the mechanics of current gen Sonic and playing through a 3D environment, using your boost, rails and homing attacks to get past the zones.Maybe I'm a little too old school, but I much prefer the classic Sonic if anything. It feels well paced.But in any case, this game made me appreciate Sonic all over again, and wished that it didn't end so soon.For a price tag of $30, I feel that's a little overpricey for a game that basically lets you play areas that you've visited before, and would like it more if this game either had more levels or had a price cut for it. But when it's on sale, this game really is a must to buy.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: January 21, 2015
Intro: DREAM SONIC GAME.well, close to it lol.The Sonic series has had a lot of ups and downs. 06's buggy mess, the storybook series, the Werehog stages, Sonic 4's broken physics. It really hasn't been that great for the blue blur, but Generations has truly restored the famous hedgehog to his former glory. Colors was pretty decent (Worth playing on Dolphin if you haven't) but this game is so much better.Gameplay: There's a great blend of sidescrolling and full 3d platforming. The stages are very well designed and its just what you'd want out of a modern Sonic game. Like the old classic games, there are so many alternate routes and paths. While Unleashed day stages were enjoyable, they were quite linear. That's completely gone and improved so much. This FINALLY feels like a modern take on the classic Sonic series and really what else should an anniversary remake be? The speed here is fast like Unleashed and the platforming isn't blocky like it was in Colours. There's a great blend of everything. No forced gimmicks, with the exception of optional side missions and those are actually quite fun as well. Speaking of which, this game has a nice amount of content for a Sonic game. Apart from the mentioned side missions (and there's a ton), there's a bunch of unlockables such as powerups you can equip for playing levels and music tracks.Music: Speaking of music, this game sounds wonderful. It includes a bunch of remixes of tracks in the series as well as complete remakes of them with the original artists returning! On top of that, you can use the unlocked music to change what plays in each level. Such a simple, but great feature.Visuals: Since we're talking about art, the visuals in this game are fantastic. The textures might not be the highest and a tad more anti-aliasing in the options wouldn't hurt, but I'm just nitpicking. This game looks absolutely gorgeous and I think they absolutely nailed the artstyle for a modern Sonic game.Story: The story.. umm. yeah, the story isn't good. Its just there. Don't expect a good story in this one. Considering this is an anniversary title, I don't think it even matters. The game is fun enough that I can look past this without considering it a flaw.PC Version: As for the PC side of things? This game is one of Sega's better ports and I'm glad to see them improving on that aspect. It runs quite well and I had no issues with it. Works flawlessly with the few gamepads I've used and performs without problem. Even when I had a weak PC, I could stay at 60 FPS pretty easily. Also has some leaderboards.And of course there's mods. From your typical character swaps to music changes to new levels and even full blown expansions. The most popular one is the Unleashed project. It ports all of the day stages from Sonic Unleashed into this game. Tons of fun to play through and you don't have to suffer through those tedious werehog levels :)Conclusion: Overall this game is definitely a top favorite for the series and I'm a rather big Sonic fan. In fact, finding out the modern Sonic games were on PC now was a huge motivation to even get a proper gaming PC. This was my first game on Steam! and it still holds up 5 years later.I really loved playing through Sonic Generations and can't recommend it enough. Its not something that'll get you hundreds of hours unless you're a completionist, speedrunner, or enjoy playing or even creating mods, but there's still plenty of content and replay-ability regardless. I really think its the best Sonic game out there! Give it a go.Buy it.

content:
Posted: August 23, 2015
												Sonic Generations is the game that Sonic fans have wanted for years. SEGA's Sonic team has struggled to make Sonic work in the 3D space. But Generations handles it very well. Having both classic and modern Sonic help to facilitate two very different forms of gameplay. Classic Sonic's levels have a greater emphasis on platforming in 2-d esque stages. Modern Sonic has the bigger 3-D levels. A lot of these levels have sections that are on rails but these help lend a sense of speed. Modern Sonic also has some of his more recent tricks like his homing attack. This contrast between the two gives the game variety. As you complete levels you progress through a simple but entertaining story. Like Mario; Sonic stories generally never get too deep or overly complex. The game avoids many of the errors Sonic games have had in the past; like shoehorning in new characters. In my time with the game I haven't met any new characters. Old familiar faces like Tails, Knuckles and Amy are present. Visually the game looks very nice indeed which is further helped by a mostly consistent framerate. I did have a few drops here and there however. Having played Lost World I felt the level design was fantastic and the parkour system was an interesting new mechanic. If they could find a way to take the foundation of Lost World and marry that with the speed found in Generations I think it would make for quite a Sonic game. If you are a Sonic fan and have not played this game. This is definitely one you want to check out.

												This game is living proof that SEGA is serious about getting the Sonic franchise back on track. After a few piles of♥♥♥♥♥♥they decided to label games (most notabley Sonic the Hedgehog for the Xbox 360) the franchise looked like it was on its last legs. But out of nowhere games like this came out and honestly it blows my mind how much a company does care about the quality of their products, particularly their flagship franchise (unlike Activision and COD). The music is really good, the controls (playing with a gamepad) are pretty solid, the story didn't make me want to kill myself (again I'm looking at you Sonic the Hedgehog for the Xbox 360), and for the most part the game runs flawless.I have encountered a memory leak issue which I easily fixed by launching the game directly from the steamapps folder, and also a noticable fps drop on certain parts of Chemical Plant but in all honesty those things are so small and forgivable because of how good this game is.SEGA, please keep up the quality. I don't care if the game has to be delayed a couple more years because of it, I am willing to wait if the end product is anywhere near as good as this.

content:
Posted: June 16, 2014
												When I was little I had a Genesis and only a handful of games for it. Of the games I had were Sonics 2, 3, and & Knuckles. I played them all so much. When I grew up and moved out, I bought a Genesis from a games emporium just so I could play those Sonics on my TV once more. Later I played Sonic Adventure at the nagging of my friends and quite enjoyed it, too.It is a constant shame that there have been such flops since the good old days of Sonic as to ruin the name of the franchise. But then theres this game. This game is competant and neat. It evokes the feeling of the old Sonics and it doesn't screw around. I feel like I'm 5 again.I reccomend playing it even if you've never been a fan or never played a Sonic game.

												It's a good and fun game. If you're into Sonic, definitely worth checking out.Modern Sonic plays like normal Sonic from the Unleashed game, which focuses on high speed platforming.Classic Sonic plays like the old sega genesis Sonic, which focuses on more slow platform gameplay while still retaining some of his characteristic speed, though the physics aren't 100% recreated, it's still fun to play as the cute little blue hedgehog of the old days.After you beat the main storyline there's a ton of post game content and challenges to complete, so there's much to keep you entertained after your done with the main content.Even after that, you can check out community mods which are full of other fan created content.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 20, 2014
												Up front I will say that I have never been a fan of Sonic. I never disliked the games, but none of them ever grabbed me. I recently tried to play Sonic Adventure 2, and while the Sonic/Shadow stages were reasonably okay (but not fantastic), the other types of stages were boring, tedious, and annoying. Not to mention the laughable plot or horrendous voice acting and volume mixing issues that game has. Far from "best game ever" as many Sonic fans would try to make you believe. After having played through the entirety of Sonic Generations, I will say that hands down THIS is the best Sonic game. Taking levels from all of Sonic's history and offering two seperate versions of the levels (classic mode, which plays like the genesis games, and modern mode which plays like the daytime stages of Sonic Unleashed or Sonic Colors), as well as providing many challenges for each of the levels. The gameplay for both modern and classic modes feel great, and aside from a few very minor issues, this is an incredibly enjoyable game, if a little bit easy to get S rank on the times. Definitely would recommend, but perhaps not at full price. The game took me about 8-9 hours to complete including all challenges, so it's not incredibly long. If you don't do all the challenges and only do the ones that are required, you could probably blaze through the game in half the time it took me.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 20, 2014
												If you have been growing tiresome of the continuous flops that Sonic Team has been shooting out over the past decade, Sonic Generations will serve as a blunt reminder that the Blue-Blur still has some life left in him. Sonic Generations is a monumental tribute to fans; boasting large and beautiful recreations of iconic stages from past games. (FYI, said games are Sonic the Hedgehog, Sonic the Hedgehog 2, Sonic & Knuckles, Sonic Adventure, Sonic Adventure 2, Sonic Heroes, Sonic 2006, Sonic Unleashed, and Sonic Colors). The nostalgia will be strong with this one; but make no mistake, the actual game here is genuinely good. You alternate between both modern and classic versions of Sonic throughout the course of the game; each level featuring both a classic and modern section.  Classic Sonic plays as you might expect.  Entirely 2-D platforming and the lack of a boost successfully replicate the formula that made classic Sonic the Hedgehog installments so great.Modern Sonic plunges you into EXTREMELY fast-paced mayhem that made it's debut in the form of daytime stages in Sonic: Unleashed.  Quick reaction time is needed to take full advantage of numerous shortcuts that riddle the maps. Also, the mod community has actually managed to find ways of adding new content to Sonic Generations on PC. As a matter of fact, there is a mod out now that allows you to play nearly all of the levels from Sonic Unleashed, despite the fact that it is a console exclusive. Overall, I recommend this game with complete confidence that most will enjoy it.  If you have been discouraged at all by recent attempts to reignite the gaming icon that is Sonic, you NEED to restore your faith right now by playing this game.  In all honesty, the story IS slapped on and completely laughable, but it's refined gameplay and undoubtedly nostalgic nature makes Sonic Generations a crowning achievement for Sonic Team.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 8, 2015
												Sonic Generations is the best way to acknowledge good Sonic games that doesn't involve playing the older good Sonic games. The PC version of Sonic Generations is a very solid port, with high framerate support, modding support and decent fast visuals. However, running mods such as the Unleashed Project require a decent modern CPU due to the relatively poor CPU porting. This also means that people with slower or less powerful processors may have some problems running busier levels, due to the games poor handling of multiple CPU threads. I did not encounter any framerate problems, but there is always going to be users who do encounter these issues, and my warning is simply ensure that you have a decent CPU. The gameplay itself blends the best of older Sonic, with modern stages built around the best ideas of Unleashed and Colours.I've only played it with a controller, so I can't judge the PC controls. I can point out that there is sometimes some delay between the pressing of the button, and Sonic actually doing it sometimes. Besides these occasional problems, the game controls very solidly and I have no actual complaints involving the controls beside this small problem. Sonic also has some problems with precise movements in some levels due to speed and sometimes eratic camera movements. The game also sadly lacks in the number of main courses, which is a shame because everything that they've put in, both modern and classic are brilliant. Game length is instead lengthened by short challenges that are required for progression, or unlock bonus tracks on the soundtrack for use in the game levels. Sadly, these challenges aren't really that interesting to play compared to the actual main games levels, and even with this, the game comes out on the short side.Visuals and port wise, graphical options are limited, but with mod support and game support for high resolution textures and shadows, the port works well most of the time. For the speed that Sonic moves at, the visuals are acceptable (and improvable with mods), and run at 60 FPS, something not available on the console versions.Sound-wise, the game for the most part shines. It features many tracks from older Sonic games, most of them are remixed and sound really good. Voice acting is a bit strange, minor characters such as those from Sonic Heroes, or ones like Shadow sound really stupid, but the main characters are voiced fine enough I suppose, although Eggman/Robotnik is the only one who I think sounds close enough to what I asscoiate the character with (that's what happens when you change voice actors when I'm not paying attention). There are some issues with audio sychronisation that I've encountered and have been unable to ever replicate, such as out of sync audio or no sound in the cutscenes at all, then again, the only thing you miss in this case is cheesy writing. No gameplay affecting issues though in terms of sound. The soundtrack, although consisting mostly of remixes, is still a great soundtrack, probably being one of my favourites for the series.Overall, its a good Sonic game in an age of disappointing Sonic games, probably my favourite in the series. It ends up being a bit too short, which is sad because awful Sonic games like Sonic 06 are many times longer than this for the average player, even with all the bloating from the little side missions. Despite that, I'd say it is worth getting, unless you really hate Sonic. This game does almost everything right, fast colourful visuals, a story that doesn't get in the way of the game and a good varied soundtrack.And then there's mods, which help almost every game they exist for.

content:
Posted: January 7, 2014
												Sonic Generations is a great game although 30 Bucks may be pushing it (get it on sale) Needless to Say there is still alot of fun to be had, I really enjoyed racing through remakes of my Favourite stages (though I wish there was a little more) and even after beating the four to six hour Storyline (during which you also get to face other hedgehogs) you can dive into doing Side missions which are pretty good (stay away from vector). This game even has a modding community, a pretty awesome one at that so if you like getting laughs at modding your game sonic will not disappoint (I dont know if I spelled it Right). The Downsides are that completing the storyline in one sitting can get pretty repetitive and voice actors have changed (takes a bit out of my childhood) But other than that the game is still really good so yeah, Sonic Generations is good, Just not 30 Dollars good. 8/10 (on sale)

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: September 17, 2016
												Sonic 2 was the first game that belonged to me, getting it along with my sega genesis for my birthday somewhere around the years of 92-93. from that peak it has been absolutely tragic how far Sonic has fallen, and everyone has their experiences with how horrible it has been to see the blue blur be reduced to a running joke.If i'm to keep this review short then all i have to say is that Sonic Generations made me feel like a kid again. The opening stage captured the familiarity of long past memories with the joy of uncovering something new. It's not a perfect game to be sure, i had my fair share of frustrations but i think this is a true return to form. If you're an old school sonic fan you'll love it, if you're new to the series; count yourself lucky that you haven't experienced the heartbreak us older guys have and enjoy.i ahve no shame admitting this is a fair representation of me while playing the opening level:https://giphy.com/gifs/wViS9n0RqN2

												Sonic Generations marks a pretty serious turning point that the Sonic franchise has been building up to for almost three years: a good Sonic game. It's missing a little bit of the white-knuckle excitement I got from Sonic Unleashed, and could've really benefited from DLC expansion content, but this is the first Sonic game in a very long time that I feel comfortable recommending to others. content:
Posted: March 13, 2015
												Sonic Generations is a celebration of Sonic 20th year of video gaming history, this title has no big complex plot just a normal Sonic game this time around, unlike Sonic's 15th celebration with broken game play and awful story, this game is good and I can say they did one hell of a good job with this one. The story, I can't say that it will be the most understandable but at least it's simple and only has one story this time unlike 2006's Sonic the Hedgehog. The Music:When it's good damn it's good; only a few tracks are off in this title, notably Sonic 2's chemical plant act2 and Sonic Adventures City Escape act2.Sonic Generations is a buggy mess of a game, but at least it can be fun, even if there are a lot of flaws that I think could have been worked out with a little more testing and feedback from longterm fans of the Sonic the Hedgehog franchise.I could only think they Sonic Rushed it out the doors of there offices before even testing it for last minute bug fixes, the 3d engine camera is very broken and can even be broken from normal game play, this seems to be the case for all version of the game so if you think it’s just the PC version.PC port specific errors:Online mode crashes:Even with a normal everyday Internet connection, this makes very little sense, the only thing it should be doing it downloading the scores and uploading the fastest time you have set in online time attack. If your Internet is slow even by a little bit or even if it is fast, it crashes and have you to restart the game to try again and hope to Jesus the ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ will not crash again.Game Controller Support is broken:If you have a xbox360 controller it works fine, if you don’t well you will have to download and install a modded pad input emulator to get the damn thing to work.No window mode:This is a ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ move that game programmers have made before, nothing to bad but if you wanted to do this well damn.Video config glitch:If you update your video card drivers and you then you try and play the game, it will give you an error and say for you to run the config, then after doing so nothing changes, it will keep giving you an error until you go into the game folder and delete a config file before you can play the game again.

content:
Posted: December 20, 2013
												Sonic Generations is an amazing game, it gives you the experience of levels both old and new, and it has an amazing mod community. With all the side missions, it goes for hours of gameplay. You can choose to enjoy the scenery and go slowly, or zip through the level, or as most would say: "GOTTA GO FAST". You have the choice between Classic Sonic, or Modern Sonic, Classic Sonic making the levels 2D, and as you can probably guess, like the classic games (STH1,STH2,SCD), and Modern Sonic making it a mixture of 2D and a fresh, open 3D style. Ok, not so open in some levels, but still truly amazing. I would reccomend this game to anyone.

content:
Posted: May 12, 2014
												Absolutely. Buy this.The classic Sonic mechanics aren't perfect but still very much enjoyable. The elemental shields return, which is always nice even though it's not mandatory to win.The modern Sonic is where this game really shines : this game understands how a 3D Sonic should be played and offers the ultimate experience.The PC version offers a 60 FPS experience which will make the levels even more enjoyable, and with the mods available plus the one coming later, you would miss a lot of fun with the Blue Blur if you didn't buy this.If I had one tiny problem with this game it would be the last bossfight which is absolutely terrible & annoying. But you can still beat the boss once you get used to the awkward controls of this last battle. Plus, one bad bossfight versus tons of fun levels & other bossfights ? This game is an absolute winner.

												Best Sonic game in the last decade, and even though nostalgia helps make this a great play for gaming veterans, it's still a great platformer by its own right. Excellent music with remixes of many of your favorite Sonic level themes, and tweaked level designs that seems to have been tuned to solve some of the frustrating "didn't see that coming" problems that so often plague Sonic games.Some may say that it suffers from a shortage of content and excessive padding (12 stages with 2 levels each, and mandatory "challenges" to reach the boss levels), but it seemed just right to me, for a game of its nature and for the price I paid.Gets a point shaved off because of the terrible final boss battle.

content:
Posted: December 30, 2013
												This is probably my favorite Sonic game of the last 15 years. It's not something I plan to go back to and doesn't get visited near annually like 3&Knuckles, but I still enjoyed it a lot. It improved on the few things I liked about Unleashed and Colors and the added PC benefits of a rock solid framerate and higher resolution makes it more of a spectacle to play. I don't have the metrics or straight comparisons to validate this, but Generations felt a bit slower to me compared to Unleashed in the 3D sections. Either that or the zones were designed with Sonic's movement in mind more. While Unleashed felt like a game that rewards rote memorization and simply has too much "speed" for the sake of speed, Generations felt like a game that rewarded good reaction time and doesn't punish as harshly. It seems like windows for finding the alternate paths, ducking the obstacle, etc, are more lax. This sounds like the game was simplified a bit, and that's maybe true; however it just felt more balanced, and more fun to fail and more rewarding to succeed (and more likely without commiting the map to memory.) 2D gameplay is great. And while I feel it is also slowed down a bit, it manages to hold my interest compared to other platformers which haven't. Wisp powers change things up without being too abundant.The story and dialogue and everything outside of gameplay is garbage. Or, extremely silly and simple. Which I suppose is a direction I don't mind compared to melodrama or whatever you want to call what was vomited out of the mid-2000s games. If you've played Colors it's mostly more of the same here.The various challenges are hit or miss. Many require playing the game in an extremely unituitive manner with questionable gameplay, Espio challenges are especially bad. However, the time-trial esqe challenges were extremely fun to undertake. The act 2 Planet Wisp challenge offered a great deal of enjoyable frustration as it required me to really learn the stage in order to succeed.Basically, I feel Generations is a platformer worth playing, even if it still has the stink of modern-day Sonic on and in it. Hearing both original and remixed tracks of various sonic themes is quite the trip down memory lane, even if the songs get a little less familiar once you get past the Genesis era games.

content:
Posted: January 14, 2014
												This is SEGA's love letter to fans that were waiting for the time when Sonic The Hedgehog returned to his roots and had a great sense of speed, Sonic Generations is probably the best 3D Sonic game to be released since Sonic Adventure 2. In this wonderful game you play as both Classic Sonic and Modern Sonic, racing through stages from the blue hedgehog's past thanks to time travel, yeah the plot isn't really that great or isn't suspensful in anyway possible it's just an excuse to have 2 Sonic's on screen and give SEGA, the chance to revisted old worlds such as Green Hill Zone, Chemical Plant including some of the modern stages that have been completely remade, some for the better i'm looking at you Crisis City.There is a lot of music in the game and it's fantastic the stage music is great both different for Modern and Classic Sonic, they also included various theme songs from different games and give you the choice to choose which song you want playing on a stage, once you've unlocked the tracks via getting red rings which I highly recommend you collect there is a lot of extra unlockables, though it's a shame you can't play as other characters but that can be done with mods on the PC version this game has a very active modding community so it's worth purchasing on PC and if your a really big fan of Sonic the Hedgehog, if you are then you'll get a kick out of this!.

number of helpful: 4 of 6 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 5, 2014
												To be quite honest, this is the best Sonic game I've played in a very long time. While it isn't too great on its story aspects, it delivers amazingly on what Sonic fans care the most about - Gameplay. The Classic Sonic gameplay found in the game appeals to even those who weren't very fond of the classic games, since it's easier to get the gist of and is required for less than half of the game. Modern Sonic's gameplay in this game is basically what it was in Unleashed, except with 90% of the issues fixed. And, with no night time stages to hold you back, the only disappointing thing about Modern Sonic is the lack of levels, since you only get nine levels with four boss fights, and some(lame) modified layouts of those levels. This is where the modding community comes in, though. Thanks to modding, this game's faults can all be fixed with additional content, and even content from the previous games. As someone who enjoys Sonic, you really would owe it to yourself to buy this game, especially during a sale.

content:
Posted: May 15, 2015
Story Well,there barely is any and what's left of it can be ignored but if you play a Sonic Game for the story then I have some bad news for you.Basically,Sonic friends are kidnapped and you have to free them by beating the level.You will go back to levels and settings of previous Sonic games like GreenHill Zone (Sonic the Hedgehog; what a surprise), Rooftop Run (Sonic Unleashed), or Speed Highway (Sonic Adventure). Dr.Eggman is obviously also involved in the story.GameplayThe game is devided into two part: The Modern Sonic Gameplay and the Classic Sonic Gameplay.The levels with Modern Sonic are 3D and 2D similar to Sonic Unleashed or Sonic Colors and also play similar to these games. Classic Sonics levels on the other hand are all in 2.5D and are much more similar to the classic Sonic games (Sonic the Hedgehog 1, 2 and 3&K) and not like Sonic 4.After you have beaten Act 1 & 2 of an era (each era consists or 3 Zones, there are 3 eras) you have to beat three challenge levels. There are alot of challenge levels to choose from and they are mostly rather easy so that shouldn't be a problem. Beating challenge levels can also unlock news skills that you can then use in Act 1 & 2 and you also unlock music from older Sonic games that you can then listen to or select as the music to play in a level.Then there also are the Rival Battles and the Boss Battles, there is one Rival and one Boss Battle in each era and each of the are similar how you originally fought the boss but they are different enough to feel completely new.There are also 5 Red Rings to collect (only in Act 1 & 2) that also unlock new music and skills. SoundtrackThe Soundtrack is as good as always and since this is an anniversary game it consists of a lot of (great) remixes.And like I already said, you can unlock new,old music that can be used in levels and challenges.Summarized, the soundtrack is great.PC PortThe PC port is functional. It does everything it has to. I haven't had that much problems with it. Sad thing is that the Online Mode doesn't really work in the PC Version and you can't play Sonic the Hedgehog 1 like you could on consoles (but we can buy the pre-order DLC, which they can't :P )Also,each time you change your PC set-up (like for example the monitor) you have to go the the files,delete all .cfg files, then re-start the Conig Tool and then you can play the game.This is rather annoying but when you don't change your set-up this shouldn't affect you.The game only shows you the Xbox 360 controller icons but you can change the key-bindings so that shouldn't be a big problem, controller is still recommented.So yes, I recommend this game but not for 30€Also,this game has some great mods which you can have fun with like for example play the Act 1 level of Sonic Unleashed or change the character model to Shadow.I made a list for that here:


Mods for Sonic Generations(Better Version) 
A Guide for Sonic Generations
By: Leonard

			A short explanation about how to install mods and a list of the best ones.

number of helpful: 5 of 8 people (63%) found this review helpful3 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: November 25, 2015
												Sonic and pals are throwing a super cool nostalgia party, and you're invited! How fun! Chilli dogs, drinks, and music galore! Everything starts out just dandy as our favorite hedgehog reflects on his past triumphs in the good old days. You can't help but gush over how much fun is in the air. You were there! You remember how great things were back in the day! As Sonic goes on, you note several inconsistencies in his retellings of what went on in the 2000s. He's a little buzzed. You were there, and you know those things didn't happen as cool as he's making it seem but he tells it so well that you can't help but be entertained! Eventually you notice our hero's speech get slurrier and harder to understand by the time he's talking about the latter half of the decade, and then all hell breaks loose. Sonic's become heavily inebriated and is thrashing about violently, screaming "SPIKE! ROCKEEEET!" at the top of his lungs.You're trying your best to placate him, but he won't let up, and his friends are about as helpless as you are at stopping him. Sonic suddenly stops what he's doing and takes a seat, beckoning you all towards him. He begins to talk about the time he and his past self faced off against Dr. Robotnik and HIS past self while they were piloting some weird time monster. Chills run down your spine as he describes horrors of which you'd never wish upon even the most obnoxious of talking animals. After an eerie silence sets in, Sonic erupts from his seat in a drunken stupor and defecates on the floor. He turns to look at you with his tearful, bloodshot eyes and yells "they said my future was gonna be great!" before jumping out of the window and sprinting off into the wilderness, shrieking. After witnessing this horror, you can't help but to mutter to yourself that he wasn't always like this, and that one day, one day he'll be having great adventures once again just like the good old days. Like the good old days...In the meantime hey this game is wonderful fun until you get to the Colors stages and final boss which are total crap 8/10 would spindash again make sure you get the good mods for it too

content:
Posted: December 5, 2012
												It doesn't take a hater to realize that the past couple of years have been pretty bad to Sonic. Sonic The Headgehog 2006 was the zenith of these terrible games. And I mean terrible. Like, really bad.Sonic Generations however is the complete opposite of those games. It feels like the 'Orcarina of Time' for Sega. The controls are tight, and combines the best of both the old school 2D Sonic games with the Next Gen 3D Sonic games. Theres a wonderful little story that ties it up, and the best part for many will be the fact that Sonic's friends take a backseat completely and only serve as a motivation for Sonic to run at the speed of sound.I do not like Platformers. So take what I say with a grain of salt, but I really enjoyed Sonic Generations, mainly because of all the wonderful BGMs (City Escape and Rooftop Run). Sonic Generations hosts a collection of the best momments in the Sonic franchise sprinkled with alittle bit of Next Gen quality with old school care. No matter if your a fan, a hater, or someone who could careless about Sonic, you'll find enjoyment in this game.GOTTA RUN FAST!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 29, 2014
												Like Skyrim with fast11/10 would fast againRight now to the real review:Sonic Generations came out back in 2011, so I am a little late to the party. But I might as well convince you to buy the game anyway.Sonic Genrations takes Sonic and Co. on an adventure through Sonic's past. Classic stages such as Sonic 1's Green Hill Zone and Sonic Adventure 2's City Escape re-imagined for both modern Sonic, and classic Sonic. Modern Soinc plays the same as he does in the Unleashed Daytime Stages, and in Sonic Colours, sans wisps. (There is actually a mod called the Unleashed Project that brings stages from Unleashed onto PC). Classic Sonic plays like he does in Sonic 2, 3, and Sonic & Knuckles.Both Sonics control very well. Controls can be a little sensitive at times but it's not a major problem.The story is good, not great. But Sonic isnt as story-centrc as other games, so it's no big deal. A monster called the Time eater rips apart space and tme and Sonic saves the day with his past self.The game has a surprisingly large modding community. There's  stage mods (The Unleashed Project, the STH2006 Project), and mods to replace sonic with Metal Sonic, Shadow, Silver, Blaze.... The list goes on and on.There however a few problems I've had with the game, mainly being fps drops down as far as 10-15 at some times, however that may just be my hardware. (Intel HD 4000)Overall I highly recommend this game to new and old Sonic fans alike. A blast of nostalgia for old fans and a Greatest Hits/Quickstart for new fans.Sonic Generations gets a solid 8/10

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 9, 2015
												Sonic Generations is a platform game in which players control Sonic the Hedgehog in two forms: Classic and Modern, in which their main objective is to collect the seven Chaos Emeralds, free their friends and uncover the mystery behind the Time Eater, a mysterious entity who creates time holes. The game features levels derived from 20 years of Sonic history, spreading across three eras, each having three stages and two bosses from previous games: the Classic Era, which features stages from the franchise's early years on Sega Genesis, the Dreamcast Era, focusing on stages from games released during the Sega Dreamcast years and the early years of the franchise's move to non-Sega systems, and the Modern Era, with stages from titles released on high-definition systems, which are played as either Classic Sonic or Modern Sonic.[8] Classic Sonic's levels are strictly two dimensional side scrolling stages, using classic moves like the Spin Attack and Spin Dash, while Modern Sonic's levels follow the 2D/3D style gameplay of Sonic Unleashed and Sonic Colors, featuring techniques such as boosting and homing attacks.] As well as classic power-ups such as Invincibility and Speed Shoes, certain levels have unique power-ups, such as skateboards in City Escape and Wisp powers in Planet Wisp.Classic and Modern Sonic begin the game with six lives, which are lost when they suffer any type of damage with no rings in their possession, or fall into a pit or drown. More lives can be earned by getting 100 rings or finding a monitor (item box) that gives them an extra life. If the player runs out of lives, the "Game Over" screen will appear, in which the player can continue by selecting "Yes"Each zone consists of a main act for each Sonic, the first act is for Classic Sonic and the second act is for Modern Sonic, as well as 10 challenges such as beating an opponent to the goal or finishing a stage with limited rings. A Skill Shop allows players to use points earned from high scores to unlock upgrades such as abilities, shields, and even the original Sonic the Hedgehog Genesis game (Xbox 360 and PS3 only). Completing challenges, as well as finding Red Star Rings hidden in each of the main Acts, unlocks additional skills, as well as bonus concept artwork and music. The music can then be played in any stage, challenge, or boss fight. There are also online leaderboards for two modes: Ranking Attack, which challenges players to obtain the best time and score on each level, and 30 Second Trial, which challenges players to see how far they can get through a level in 30 seconds.The 3DS version follows similar gameplay to the Sonic Rush series for Modern Sonic, and features a different set of levels to the console and PC versions, some of which directly recreate the layouts of classic Mega Drive levels. As opposed to the Skill Shop in the console version, abilities are unlocked as the game progresses, with Classic Sonic learning a Homing Attack and Modern Sonic learning a stomp. Exclusive to the 3DS version are Special Stages, similar to those of Sonic Heroes, in which players must collect spheres in order to gain boost to chase after a Chaos Emerald. The game features 100 mission stages that are unlocked either by progressing through the game, meeting other players on StreetPass, or spending Play Coins, as well as both wireless and online multiplayer modes, in which two players can race against each otherThe game begins with Sonic holding a birthday celebration with his friends, before a mysterious entity known as the Time Eater arrives and uses "time holes" to scatter everyone across different points in history. After being knocked out by the Time Eater, Sonic finds himself in White Space. After Sonic rescues his best friend Tails, they discover versions of themselves from the past, referred to as "Classic Sonic" and "Classic Tails", who are depicted with the appearance and proportions used in concept art from the Sega Genesis era of Sonic games. As the two Tails determine that Time Eater's actions are damaging time and space itself, both Classic and "Modern" Sonic race through their history, restoring time to normal and rescuing their friends. Throughout the course of the game, Classic and "Modern" Sonic encounter Dr. Eggman and his classic self, referred to as "Classic Eggman" (Robotnik), and collect the 7 Chaos Emeralds.When the worlds are restored and the Chaos Emeralds are collected, the Sonics discover that the mastermind behind the now perfected Time Eater are Eggman and Robotnik. "Modern" Eggman reveals his plot to complete the Time Eater Robot by joining forces with his past self, Dr. Robotnik (Classic Eggman), and harnessing the Time Eater's power. Therefore, Eggman will erase his past defeats from history Although the Time Eater manages to overpower the 2 Sonics, the support of their friends and the power of the Chaos Emeralds allow them to transform into their Super forms and confront Robotnik and Eggman. The Sonics eventually destroy the Time Eater, restoring time to its proper state. The heroes return to the present and continue celebrating Sonic's birthday. After the party, Classic Sonic and Classic Tails travel back to their own time as everyone says their farewells. After the credits, Robotnik and Eggman are trapped in white space

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 4, 2013
												The ideal Sonic experience for everyone, enhanced by PC capabilities! Combining the 2D platforming gameplay of the classic Sonic games and the high octane 3D & 2D platformer-racing gameplay of Sonic Unleashed and Colours into one package as Classic Sonic and Modern Sonic respectively, there's gameplay content to appeal to every Sonic fan here... all with the addition of a modding community that continues to keep the game alive where SEGA chose not to.Want to play the entirety of the Daytime stages from Sonic Unleashed? How about playing as a slower-paced and more platforming capable Modern Sonic under the guise of a 2006 style Sonic? Or playing as Classic Sonic in Modern Sonic's stages, or vice versa? What about a Silver mod with a flying air boost, or a Blaze mod with more aerial based physics? And what would you to say to the few yet wonderful custom levels that show the capabilities of level creating?There's so much content to mix-and-match and keep going back to in whatever manner you want, and that's the true strength of Sonic on PC.(old recommendation trashed; replacing with this newer review)

content:

												This is a pretty good sonic game. Coming from the old genesis days, they did a great job at recreating the feel of the old levels and some great new ones complete upgraded with mind blowing speeds and beautiful graphics.  The only issues I have with this game is that some of the boss and challenge fights you go through are a little confusing and it takes some time to figure out what you need to do.  The hold up is figuring some of these challenges out.; and thats not in a good puzzle / solid boss fight sort of way, you will literally run laps around a course chasing someone and thinking "WTF am i supposed to do to end this? "  My other beef is that the game is too easy. There is really no accountability for lives lost and its pretty much a breeze through,  minus the aforementioned challenges. and boss fights that are not clear on objectives.Overall though, very fluid, very colorful and very enjyable ~ reccomended for all sonic fans and for the keeeids.  7.5 /10

												As a huge fan of the series I can say that this is the best modern sonic game.If you like platformers - it's must have.If you're not convinced about the series, it's the first game you should try.+Two great gameplay styles (classic and modern).+Dynamic arcade gameplay.+Sense of speed.+Good idea for a story.+Very good replayability of the levels, many different ways to pass the stages, many additional missions, lots of secrets and unlockables, beating the time record of the stages to get higher ranks and compete in leaderboards.+Epic boss battles.+Great soundtrack.+Nostalgia-filled levels.+Very good graphics, plus PC version is way nicer and smoother than console versions.+Great community-based mod support, lots of mods to download.+AFAIK - very good use of stereoscopic 3D, also on PC.+Unlockable Super Sonic for both regular classic and modern levels after beating the story.-Minuses not noticed at all excepting very, very, occassional camera bugs at the start of the stage (restarting the level helps immediately; i noticed that after a long playtime after beating the story).-Final boss battle could be done better, but overall it's not that bad.

content:
Posted: July 13, 2016
												Very excellent game here. I enjoy playing this, and I just love seeing stages like Seaside Hill and City Escape remade. It makes sense why Sonic's 20th anniversary was a huge success, unlike his 15th. Despite the fact that no new music is introduced, having our favorite stages with their remix makes up for it. This is why Sonic won't die, despite the fact that Sonic's franchise are notorious for having really bad games. Most say Sonic was ruined when it became a 3D game, but the dreamcast games proved that wrong, and then we have a game like this, released only 5 years ago. This is a Sonic game that will forever be remembered for how amaizng it is, unlike *cough* Sonic 06.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 12, 2012
												"Sonic games are bad! They are buggy, the camera can't keep up, and the control is awful!" It's time to forget all that.Sonic Generations features some of the tightest controls I've seen in a Sonic game, a vivid reimaging of Sonic levels from the past, and an excellent soundtrack. Both 2D and 3D sonic are fun to play as, and each level has a remix based on which character you play. That being said, there are some occasions where the camera does bug out. However, this only happens on rare instances. Furthermore, I have not run into any other bugs I can remember during the 5 hours it took to finish the story.Besides the main story, there are many challenges to keep you busy. In conclusion, this is the Sonic game you were waiting for.

content:
Posted: January 15, 2015
												This is a ridiculously good Sonic game.  After playing all of these recent Sonic games that kinda suck, I didn't really think there could be another good Sonic game.  I'm really glad this game proved me wrong, because this is Sonic at his best.  You play through the game as “classic” Sonic and “new” Sonic.  There are many different stages that are all based on classic sonic levels.  The look and music will make you super nostalgic if you played Sonic on the Genesis back in the day.  When you are classic Sonic, you go through the level just like in the original game as a 2D side scroller.  The graphics are great, and the gameplay in these sections is pure classic Sonic.  When you are new Sonic, you play through the game in a racing style.  It almost reminds me of Sonic R on the Sega Saturn but a million times better, because Sonic R SUCKED.  Anyway, these sections are just as fun.  You get to run through the level as quickly as possible and you lock onto enemies more like the new sonic games.  These different game modes go together better then you'd expect it is super fun.The game is pretty short, especially if you don't care about getting a high score.  There are challenges after you have beaten the classic and new Sonic levels, and most of these are fun.   A couple are pretty tedious, but luckily most of these are optional.  There are some pretty fun boss fights in the game too, but don't expect anything too challenging.  The game is very easy to complete, but you can always go back to the levels and try and beat your score which is where the developers obviously hoped you'd spend a lot of time.  If you are the kind of person that likes getting high scores and short times, then you will be obsessed with trying to beat your old scores.The bad part about this game is the port.  The port is pretty awful.  There are no graphics options, and on my machine which has specs that are way higher than the recommended setting it took me a lot of time to figure out how to get this game going at a decent framerate.  It took me a couple hours and a lot of google searches to get this game running at a playable framerate, and if your computer is below the recommended specs and closer to the minimum specs, you may have some issues getting this game into a playable state.  I ended up having to download some 3rd party software to even get the game to run at around 30 FPS.  30 FPS is a bit low, but I don't mind it on this game.  The game was actually designed to be run at 30 FPS from what I can tell, so if you can get it higher that is great but 30 works just fine.  Even though the port of this game sucks, I still would recommend this game especially if you can get it on sale.  Since the game is short, it might be a really good deal to wait for the sale.  I got it for 7.49 and it is definitely worth the price.  If you are an old school Sonic fan, you owe it to yourself to get this game because it truly is the best sonic game to come out this decade.

												Sonic Generations is a blast from the past that I'd recommend any Sonic fan to play. With the game starting at the zone that started it all, Green Hill Zone, and going all the way to Planet Wisp, Sonic Generations was a serious nostalgic trip that any classic sonic fan or modern fan would have a good time playing. The game also sports a pretty awesome soundtrack! Classic Sonic's varation of the stages have a 90's/Genesis feel added to the songs and Modern Sonic's varation resembles the music style of how Sonic's music sounds today! When it comes down to rating the game I'd give it a 8/10.
