number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 29, 2014
												Like Skyrim with fast11/10 would fast againRight now to the real review:Sonic Generations came out back in 2011, so I am a little late to the party. But I might as well convince you to buy the game anyway.Sonic Genrations takes Sonic and Co. on an adventure through Sonic's past. Classic stages such as Sonic 1's Green Hill Zone and Sonic Adventure 2's City Escape re-imagined for both modern Sonic, and classic Sonic. Modern Soinc plays the same as he does in the Unleashed Daytime Stages, and in Sonic Colours, sans wisps. (There is actually a mod called the Unleashed Project that brings stages from Unleashed onto PC). Classic Sonic plays like he does in Sonic 2, 3, and Sonic & Knuckles.Both Sonics control very well. Controls can be a little sensitive at times but it's not a major problem.The story is good, not great. But Sonic isnt as story-centrc as other games, so it's no big deal. A monster called the Time eater rips apart space and tme and Sonic saves the day with his past self.The game has a surprisingly large modding community. There's  stage mods (The Unleashed Project, the STH2006 Project), and mods to replace sonic with Metal Sonic, Shadow, Silver, Blaze.... The list goes on and on.There however a few problems I've had with the game, mainly being fps drops down as far as 10-15 at some times, however that may just be my hardware. (Intel HD 4000)Overall I highly recommend this game to new and old Sonic fans alike. A blast of nostalgia for old fans and a Greatest Hits/Quickstart for new fans.Sonic Generations gets a solid 8/10

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 10, 2015
												TL;DR Sonic Team finally made a Sonic game that isn't terrible.Now all they have to do is get rid of every character that isn't Sonic or Robotnik.This is one of the only modern Sonic games that isn't complete garbage. Sure, it still has the characters, dialogue, and story that makes you want to gouge your eardrums out with a rusty machete, but we're not talking about that. That's easy enough to ignore.The gameplay itself is Sonic. There is no stupid were-hog mechanic, no glitches that make you run through the ground, and no NPC fetch-quests that turn the game into torture.Of course, the developers couldn't be bothered to add keyboard prompts, so be sure to have the 360 controller ready. Actually, this game is pretty much unplayable on a keyboard, but with a gamepad it actually manages to be fun.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 19, 2015
												So, I've been out of the Sonic loop for a looooong time. I played 1-3K as a kid and loved them, and recently played Adventure 1 & 2, and that's pretty much it. Since I'd heard so much praise for this game (and absolutely ADORED its soundtrack), I thought I'd give it a go, and oh. Mah. GAWSH! I had no idea Modern Sonic would be so freaking FAST! Adventure fast was fast enough for me, but this took it up a level and a half. I'm not complaining, I was just in for quiiite the trip! It's still a lovely nostalgia trip of a game, and while not extremely difficult and lacking in plot, the gameplay and soundtrack are perfect enough to keep you playing for hours, even if you're not ready for SUPER-HYPER-OMEGA--LUDICROUS-SPEED-SANIC!Tl;Dr: Good game, worth the price, play it, be ready for fast!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 18, 2015
												Sonic Generations is a game that in large part takes players back to the old days of Sega and some of the darker hours. It's graphics are crsip with a strong and dynamic color pallet that makes the objects wizzing past you seem just as interesting and vibrant as the blue blur. However this strong graphical integrity also gives way to a a large degree of framerate drops as the game trys to catch up with Sonic's speed. The music in the game is on point and includes remixes and reworkings of many older tracks, and if you dare you can collect all of the extra 50 of tracks from Sonic games including some you may not have even heard of (granted not all of the extra tracks are as good as the remixes). My only qualm with this is that the ost was not included in the extras room, so if you like any of the level themes the only way to hear them is in the levels themselves. As far as the story goes the game is sub-par, but it's a sonic game so the story doesn't really matter that much. Sonic and friends are having a birthday party when a giant black monster swoops out of the sky and throws them back in time. From there sonic and tails have to reunite their friends with the help of some strangers, themselves. See, pretty basic. But don't worry the gameplay will keep you going. The gameplay by the way is everything we've wanted from a sonic game to date. it's fast and the controlls are tighter then they have been. Gameplay comes in two forms, the 2.5D side scrolling classic levels, which are just like sonic 2 in their design, with no exception. These levels are fair and each one introduces some new mechanic to the 2d movement, so it stays fresh. These are of solid level design (except Crisis City which has a floating on cars section and the models of the objects your riding are really poorly positioned).  Secondly the 3d modern levels exist and while their controls are refined (no mach speed setions), they still go very very very fast. So expect to only play these for five minutes tops. Honestly I think other then Planet Whisp taking too long and the inclusion of  Sonic 0'6 in the set of levels (as it leaves a bad taste in the mouth of anyone who played Sonic 0'6. ugh, memories) these levels were also very solid. Sonic can be hard to control due to his speed, but that's expected. So to sumarize:- PROS- Great visuals- Great OST- Massive collection of Nostalgia- Improved level design- Classic and modern sections- Cons- Mediocre Story telling- Framerate drops- Crisis City Refection level (sonic 0'6)- little to no replay value  However what about completing the game? This will require you to get all S ranks on main levels, beat hard mode on every boss, and collect every red ring. You will have to do every single mission (but you don't need an S rank), and my personal hell: Beat the final boss without taking damage. And you will get nothing for this, pas completing the collection room full of artwork and music from preivious games. And while this is cool it does nothing to encourage me to play again, or get the other random achievements. And all you need to get that "completiton bonus" is S ranks on leves (for abilities), Missions complete, and all red rungs. You don't have to do hard mode or even beat the final boss. So in short, the completion of this game is hard fought at times ( as the final boss is played as supert sonic so you have no freaking idea what taking damage actually means since YOU HAVE NO HEALTH BAR) and it's just not worth it. So FINISH IT. don't bother completing the game.So finally my rating for this game is 7.5/10 , Finish it.

content:
Posted: August 19, 2015
												Pros Old and new sonic stages remade for this game! Amazing remixed sound track! Graphically impressive for a sonic game IT'S JUST SONIC! No nonsense with shadow, silver, etc Powered up/new abilities with modern sonic makes game interesting Classic sonic stages feel classic yet great, and some of my favorite stages Bosses are fun, albeit a little easy outside of the end boss Colors everywhere! Cons Story is a little simple, but it's a sonic game, so it makes senseA little on the short side This port isn't the best. Constant issues with configurations Not many graphical options  The short missions that are required for you to do to get chaos emeralds are a little dull and kinda over extend the game Overall, Sonic Generations is amazing. One of the best sonic games I've played. Me and my little nephew play this game all the time and we love it. I hope Sega goes back to this style of sonic games. 8.5 out of 10.

content:
Posted: August 26, 2015
												Fab game. Why? Simple. Fixes everything that was wrong with Unleashed. Fast paced, great remakes of old stages from past games. 18 levels (thats 2 acts per zone and thats 9 zones) and a sh*t load of stuff to unlock and bonus challenges. What more can you ask for? I can tell you what you can ask for. Mods. This game is amazingly modable and I myself have played the Sonic Unleashed Day stages, levels from Sonic Adventure, Colours and even a few from Lost world. This game is perfect, replayable and best of all, (if you know how to mod) you can in some way create the perfect sonic game for you. Totally recommend this game. Im a massive Sonic geek and from me one of the best games this past decade of sonic games.

Posted: July 13, 2016
												Very excellent game here. I enjoy playing this, and I just love seeing stages like Seaside Hill and City Escape remade. It makes sense why Sonic's 20th anniversary was a huge success, unlike his 15th. Despite the fact that no new music is introduced, having our favorite stages with their remix makes up for it. This is why Sonic won't die, despite the fact that Sonic's franchise are notorious for having really bad games. Most say Sonic was ruined when it became a 3D game, but the dreamcast games proved that wrong, and then we have a game like this, released only 5 years ago. This is a Sonic game that will forever be remembered for how amaizng it is, unlike *cough* Sonic 06.

content:
Posted: September 27, 2014
												A mix of classic Sonic style and what a modern Sonic game should be. The modern sonic levels can be buggy sometimes, but notthing game breaking. The game gives you that sense of speed that every sonic game should. Its always nice to have a game that is conscious of how rediculous it is, so it doesn't try being serious like some past entries. The perfect example is theres is a part where a giant semi truck is driving on the side of a building with rocket boosters and robotic saw arms chasing you. My main complaint is that most of the boss fights are pretty lame, especially the final boss.Overall though, this is a fantastic game and possibly the only good Sonic game we'll see in a long, long time.

content:
Posted: February 20, 2016
												So everybody says Sonic is a dying franchise, commenting that it hasn't had a good game in forever. I immediately show those people Sonic Generations, a game which combines the classic 2D platforming of the Genesis games and the modern Boost to Win gameplay of the newer titles. Sonic Generations blends these two gamestyles together without it being forced. The levels are great, the music is spectacular, and the game is just amazing all the way through. Get this game ASAP, because going fast will never feel any better.

content:
Posted: November 21, 2012
												Sonic Generations is great. It's fun, it's colorful and it features 100% more of our favorite high-speed blue hedgehog. Both modern and classic gameplay styles are fun and the controls work almost flawlessly. Another strong point of this game is its soundtrack; every part of it is phenomenal.The game may be short but it has tons of replay value. There are red star rings to collect, challenges to complete and the game is fun and the levels are beautiful enough that you'll want to play them more than once.SEGA and Sonic Team have found a gameplay formula that works really, really well and I'm hoping to see it improved upon in the next Sonic game.

But if you've played any of the older Sonic games, whether they be the classics on Genesis, or the Adventure series, or even Unleashed or Colors/Colours, then definately pick this game up. It is well worth the money!

content:
Posted: July 12, 2012
												"Sonic games are bad! They are buggy, the camera can't keep up, and the control is awful!" It's time to forget all that.Sonic Generations features some of the tightest controls I've seen in a Sonic game, a vivid reimaging of Sonic levels from the past, and an excellent soundtrack. Both 2D and 3D sonic are fun to play as, and each level has a remix based on which character you play. That being said, there are some occasions where the camera does bug out. However, this only happens on rare instances. Furthermore, I have not run into any other bugs I can remember during the 5 hours it took to finish the story.Besides the main story, there are many challenges to keep you busy. In conclusion, this is the Sonic game you were waiting for.

Posted: January 5, 2016
												Even though I have some INSANE lag while playing the game, I don't care about it. The story is incredible, great level designs; but there is one problem, and it is the controls. I do not have a controller, and so I use the keys A and D to move, W and S to look up and down, down arrow key to jump (which is annoying and took me some time to get used to it), right arrow key to crouch and left arrow key to do the spinning thing. Let's just say that you need to add control editing so not only me but other people can make the controls however they want. And add the ability to change the video settings, to remove some lag.So I do recommend it for people who have controllers and fast computers, but if you're a PC gamer and you hate having lag, just don't.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 17, 2016
												Extremely clever level design with diverging paths through each level, encouraging level replays to get the fastest time and pursue S-rank scores. 2D sonic levels are fast and feel very smooth in general, and include most of the classic physics, controls, and sounds. These levels are usually shorter than their 3D counterparts, but have a great flow.3D levels are a bit more platforming-heavy, but still have some very fast parts, and Modern Sonic's homing dash and boost abilities are put to good use. These levels do not flow quite as well as the 2D levels, but are visually striking and still manage to feel good. Challenge levels range from fun level variations to frustrating gimmicks, but are largely decent twists on the gameplay, and are mostly optional for the main story. The soundtrack is wonderful, containing remixes of many level themes from throughout the series. The story is pretty much a throw-away but frames the coming-together of classic and modern Sonic decently enough to not be distracting. Although the final level and boss battle fall a bit flat, the game is overall a joy to play.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 26, 2014
												Wow. Just... wow. If you like sonic, or even just platforming in general, get this game. Period.It runs at an amazing 60 fps on my PC at high settings on a 32" hdtv, and looks absolutely gorgeous. Like, really. This is the best a sonic game has ever looked. It has full controller support that's as easy as plugging in a wired xbox 360 controller, going into this game's settings, choosing to use the xbox controller, and starting the game. And unlike other games designed for a keyboard/mouse that are just compatible with a controller, this game is truly designed for a controller and is 70 times better with one. So, if you have a wired xbox 360 or ps3 controller hanging around, use that.This is a perfect combination of classic and modern sonic. It literally has a remade version of levels from nearly every one of the main console sonic games for both classic sonic (who makes an amazing return in HD), and modern sonic (who is even better then before!).If you're a sonic fan, get this. There's so many references to sonic games from all eras that even if you've only played one sonic game you'll probably understand a lot of them. But that makes you think "Oh. Well, I have to be a sonic fan to enjoy this." No. Not at all! Even if you're not a sonic fan and/or have never even played a sonic game, I still say get this. You may not understand all the references, so it won't be AS enjoyable, but it's still the best sonic's ever been in 3D (in my opinion) and it really isn't complicated. It's a platformer, after all. It's still built off of the basic platforming base. Just run and jump. There's just more stuff added on top of that.My only complaint is that this game is too short. They put a lot of effort into it, which is great, but they took so much time on making sure it was enjoyable that in the end they had to make a huge amount of rehashed missions for each stage just so they could actually sell this as a game with enough content to keep you going for more then a day. However, there is an online mode. That's right, this game has a mode in which you can race to the end of a stage as fast as possible and put your best time on the leaderboards. It's great fun replaying a stage 100 times just to try and beat that one record. It also has a "30 second trial", in which you have 30 seconds to try and see how far you can get in one stage. Once your time runs out, the length you traveled in the level is posted to the leaderboards. The best part, though, is that the PC version solves the "too short" problem entirely because of mods. There are so many mods for this game you'll never run out of stages to play. One mod ports all the levels from sonic unleashed on xbox 360/ps3, one ports stages from Sonic 06, one ports stages from sonic adventure, there are even mods that have entirely new stages in them, such as "Meponterations". And with new mods being made every day, you'll never get bored.In brief, this is an amazing piece of art and probably the best sonic's ever been in 3D. Well, maybe not the best, but at least the best in the last decade. Overall I recommend this. 9/10....Yes, I'm bad at reviewing games. xD

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 25, 2014
												Do two Sonics really make one great adventure?Heck Yeah!Seeing as Sonic's 23rd birthday is coming up I thought I might as well leave a review for this game. So what do I think? Well, apart from the return of a horrible level from a horrible game (I'm looking at you, Crisis City), SONIC GENERATIONS is one of the best Sonic games of all time. If you like boost-to-win gameplay with pretty much no challenge, modern sonic is your guy. On the other hand, if you grew up in the days of Blast Processing and being able to do what Nintendon't, then Classic Sonic is the pudgy little mascot for you. Effortlessly switching between Sonic and Sonic on the hub is great, whilst still keeping the loading times down to keep the immersion from breaking.All of the 9 stages have been excellently recreated, my personal favourite being City Escape (both Classic and Modern). Whilst Omochao can be annoying, he can be turned off if you want to do so. Comparing this game to the HD Console versions is easy. This is the one to get, largely because of the modding community! From '06 physics to Adventure Style Sonics, from a Real Hedgehog to Rayman character mods, even from Shrek to Hatsune Miku character mods, this game's modding community has it all!Final Verdict: If you get the chance, spend the money! And check out the various mods available, as they will undoubtedly extend your playtime with this! On a side note, for a better representation of that Blast Processing gameplay, check out the 3DS version of the game! The 3DS version isn't much, but will keep you Sonic Fans happy for a couple of hours, especially with some exclusive levels from past handheld Sonic Games...well, two (Water Palace, Tropical Resort DS Version).The perfect gift for any Sonic fan, whether they want to learn the Boost-To-Win gameplay, or if they want to keep doing what Nintendon't, or even if they just want to celebrate the 20th anniversary of one of the best gaming mascots of all time!A Way Past Cool 10/10

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 15, 2014
												After some flops in the Sonic franchise (Sonic '06, Secret Rings, etc.), this game gets the series back on it's feet, and then it does a backflip and wins the World Cup. In other words, it's really great.Story: Sonic from the past and present, along with their friends, get sucked into a limbo of sorts. After playing through a few areas, the two meet up. Then they decide they need to help save his friends and return the locations back to the real world- erm, the games real world, the sonic world, Mobius. It's a really good plot. it engrosses the player, it does take a bit to start up however. It's still, nontheless, a great storyline. [Score: 8.5/10]Presentation: The graphics for this game are amazing. I originally bought it for the PS3, then recently bought it on Steam as part of a Collection of Sonic games. The PC graphics are undoubtedly better, although you can't hate the PS3's graphics on this game either. The game looks great. [Score 10/10]Gameplay: There are 2 Styles of gameplay, Classic Sonic, and Modern Sonic. Classic Sonic goes back to the roots of the series. Sidescrolling bliss. Modern Sonic goes with the style of playthrough from daytime Unleashed and all of Colors (save for the double jump). Not too much to say about it. Tight controls, high-speed gameplay, it's all really great. [Score 10/10]Level Design: This game was released for Sonic's 20th Anniversary. This is probably why it remixes old stages from other games. The only new stage is the final boss. However, this isn't a bad thing, far from it! This is one of the many reasons this game was so successful. There are 5 stage types, Regular Stage Act 1, Regular Stage Act 2, Mini-Bosses, Bosses, and the final boss. The Regular Stages are for Classic, and Modern, respectively. The Minibosses are unlocked halfway through 3 of the 4 areas of the main hub. They are just reimaginings of older versions of bosses from older games. We have Metal Sonic from Sonic CD, Shadow from Sonic Adventure 2, and Silver from Sonic '06 (but acctually playable). The Boss fights, with the exception of the last one, are throwbacks to other final (or close to final) bosses from other games. These include: Death Egg Robot from Sonic 2, Perfect Chaos from Sonic Adventure, and Egg Dragoon from Sonic Unleashed. Each fight is really solid. The Final boss is Time Eater, in which Modern and Classic sonic both go super and you take them out in a way similar to The True Final Boss in Sonic 3 & Knuckles' The Doomsday Zone. My only real gripe is that Time Eater is a little bit unforgiving, it took me a few tries to beat it. That or I just suck. [Score 9.5/10]Music: Along with the stages, the music is remixed from their respected stages (again, with the exception of the final boss), they are all really good. Some of my favorites include Death Egg Robot, Chemical Plant Zone Act 1, Metal Sonic, and my personal favorite, Time Eater. [Score 10/10 (although I wish it could be higher)]Total Score: 48/50Thank you for taking the time to read this, and Good Night.

content:
Posted: February 5, 2014
												Sonic Generations remixes levels throughout Sonic history, both in the 3D style and classic 2D style. It succeeds at finding the best parts of it's source material without changing any iconic themes. Best of all, it understands the core of what distinguishes Sonic from other platformers: rewarding good play with a feel of speed. This is demonstrated by the speed-run features, such as compartive time when reaching check points and with the classic "higher roads are faster, but more challenging" design philosophy. Truly a celebration of the Sonic franchise

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 12, 2013
												Sonic Generations is what a Sonic game should be. It has taken the best of both worlds of the entire Sonic series and put it into probably what I consider the best game for him yet. Plus, all of the challenges to do aside from the actual runs of the levels add a bit of variety to the game, so you never have to just constantly run through the levels, knowing exactly where you're to go next.I would've hated to be on the team that picked the levels to incorperate. There are way too many good ones to just pick one from each game!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 9, 2014
												Sonic Generations  takes what Sega started with Sonic Unleashed's daytime stages and its work in Sonic Colors and improves upon it immensly, the number of cheap deaths are almost non existant and gone are the days of being able to run off the side of the level trying to take a turn.  The graphics are a beautiful colorful style when they need to and Crisis City finally gets the good treatment it deserves.   The only downsides to the game I can see is that we  got three city themed stages overall when we could have gotten more variety by picking some other levels and a lack of an ice themed level.  However I feel these are more prefence than actual detractors t the game.    The only two bugs I run into is that Online Timeattack play can sometimes crash the game and that if you change your computer set up you might need to do a fresh install of the game due to it constantly wanting you to check your settings.   That bug is made better by the fact that the game uses cloud saving. Overall I highly recommend this game to any person who played Sonic back in the 90s or even still to this day.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 27, 2014
												I know that Sega has gotten a lot of flak over the years for producing sub-standard Sonic games, but "Sonic Generations" more than makes up for that. What I love most about the game is the fact that it unites gamers of all ages to celebrate Sonic and his friends, in all their forms, both old and new. The single player campaign alone is worth playing by itself. The mini-games, however, will keep you more than preoccupied once the campaign is finished. I've played the game countless times on multiple platforms and I'll keep playing it for as long as I can. Highly recommended.

content:
Posted: March 14, 2014
												Sonic Generations is a fun game with both relaxing and very hard levels! The Good about this game is that there are so many levels to play in the game, so whenever you feel like playing a level, you got A LOT too choose from! There are also many characters from Sonic to Silver to Knuckles! Of course there are also many more such as Tails, Amy, Blaze, and Shadow, + More!  Even though u got some characters that are not playable such as Omacho, you still can download mods to play some characters that never made it to the game as well as characters that aren't even in the Sonic Franchise! The Bad about this game is that there is a major amount of difficulties in the levels and they start to put you in RAGE MODE! Also, Sonic's character glitches a lot  when he's speed boosting and it could take a long time too get use to the controls! In all, I think this is a great way to celebrate the 20th year of Sonic and this game would get a rating of 8 out of 10 stars in my opinion!-NickTendo69

While the controls are a little awkward at first (being a port), it eventually feels very natural. All in all, a very good buy.

content:
Posted: March 14, 2014
												Sonic Generations is a fun game with both relaxing and very hard levels! The Good about this game is that there are so many levels to play in the game, so whenever you feel like playing a level, you got A LOT too choose from! There are also many characters from Sonic to Silver to Knuckles! Of course there are also many more such as Tails, Amy, Blaze, and Shadow, + More!  Even though u got some characters that are not playable such as Omacho, you still can download mods to play some characters that never made it to the game as well as characters that aren't even in the Sonic Franchise! The Bad about this game is that there is a major amount of difficulties in the levels and they start to put you in RAGE MODE! Also, Sonic's character glitches a lot  when he's speed boosting and it could take a long time too get use to the controls! In all, I think this is a great way to celebrate the 20th year of Sonic and this game would get a rating of 8 out of 10 stars in my opinion!-NickTendo69

content:
Posted: March 20, 2014
												After the release of the adventure series Sega have struggled to bring fans a game that was as good or better, with some entries, like Sonic unleashed actually being good (not counting any night stages) to the rushed and unfinished black sheep of the series released way back in 2006. That one game along with just passable entries released on down the line saw a lot of fans turn away from the franchise but I can tell you that this game is without a doubt the best Sonic game since Adventure 2.Throughout the game you take on the role of classic sonic, who is played more like the original games in the style of 2D side scrolling but in more of a 2.5D type of style.And of course you take control of modern Sonic who controls in more or less the same way as in Unleashed with some  side scrooling sections thrown in as well.As a long time fan of the series it is really great to see that Sega can still make good Sonic games though the furure of the series is still up for debate with Nintendo now helping out for the next few games which probably means that we are going to see a rapid decline in fast paced gameplay and too much 'family friendly' content as shown by lost world and colours.But overall if you are a fan of the series than you should definately think about buying  the game because it is filled with nostalgia, great gameplay and loads of replayability.Though there are some bad points about the game, these points being that the game is only about 4 to 5 hours and all of the voice actors (with the exception of Eggman as his voice actor was the only one that didn't change after unleashed) are really bad even though some of them have done better in other performances.Closing score: 97/100

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 29, 2013
												It’s been 20 years since Sonic rolled into the realm of games, and with him he’s brought us speed, clever level design and wonderfully imaginative set pieces. He has, however, also brought with him hideous 3d cameras, piles of buggy messes and a hedgehog who drives a jeep and carries a gun. Mixed legacy? You bet it is, and nowhere is the schizophrenic nature of the series better displayed than in the historically minded “Sonic Generations”. Is the blue blur back to his best, or is this simply another false start?Sonic Generations begins optimistically, blasting through Green Hill Zone before being introduced to a charmingly “nod-nod wink-wink” opening cutscene that hints at a more light hearted Sonic adventure than other games have attempted. This reassuringly fun opening is cemented when, after finishing the first level with modern sonic, you think that you’re safe. Modern Sonic played fine, Classic Sonic was great, maybe we’re going to make the long haul here, maybe we can see the game through and not hit any major speed bumps. This goes on throughout the first third of the game, the level design is charming, the cutscenes are small and for the most part amusing, and the music is great. Then something happens, and a cold sweat sits in.Challenges? There are challenges between the levels? The pulse quickens and blood drains from the face. Oh no. They surely didn’t mess this up, they were doing so well! Please don’t make me replay the same level to pad out gameplay please don’t... then the first genuine surprise happens. The challenges are not only really fun; they’re entirely different levels, for the most part! New power-ups are dished out in the form of Sonic’s friends and the level design shifts entirely. OK so these levels are much shorter, but they’re good, they’re fun, and best of all they take about 5 minutes at their most extravagant.Then the first boss fight happens. It’s a mess; spotty controls, frustrating design and uninteresting music leads to the first true lull in the game. You can forgive it though, it isn’t too bad and it ended quickly once you figure out how to hurt the boss. But then you open up the Dreamcast era, and like Sonic does when he needs to go quicker, it goes downhill from there.It’s incredible how Sonic Generations manages to pinpoint the exact moment Sonic jumped the shark but the history lesson is well taught. The level they chose from Sonic Adventure is a city level. The level they chose from Sonic Adventure 2 is a city level. The level they choose for Sonic 2006 is a city level. Suddenly it becomes very apparent that Sonic stopped existing in a sort of fantasy realm and started becoming an urbanite. All of the charm starts to drain, the level design gets, not exactly harder but more finicky, there’s more awkward jumps and bad precision platforming. Even worse are the glitches which suddenly pop up in Modern Sonic; blasting through walls, clipping on the edge of a platform and falling your death. Throw in more unexpected and unfair traps and it all gets a bit frustrating. Classic Sonic seems lost and bewildered in these later levels, outside his 3 games he has to wade through 6 modern titles and in almost every single one of them he is chased by something. I know Sonic being chased is a fun idea, but my god the poor ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ must be magnetic or something.This is Sonic Generations biggest problem, while it’s great to celebrate Sonic’s past, it’s his present that is the true villain of the piece. What’s baffling is how the designers missed a trick in doing as little of the bad Sonic games as possible. They chose to include Sonic Heroes and Sonic 2006, and both of the “new levels” for those games are horrible. Why on earth recognise these infamously bad titles when you could have had a proper Sonic 3 level (the one in the PC version is Sky Sanctuary, a fine level but from Sonic and Knuckles) and brought in Sonic CD for a real nostalgia trip. Instead we get a bad beach level and a third (third!) city level. A terrible decision was made in development, but it could have been worse, we at least didn’t get a Shadow the Hedgehog level.Towards the end the game feels like it might be getting a little stale, so it stops. With only 9 levels, and only 2 Sonics to play them with, Sonic Generations is short, but rightly so. The challenges become a little more cumbersome and tricky towards the end, and the final bosses are a teeth gnashing nightmare, but they are at least beatable. With 90 challenges to play and time trial modes to master some players will get tons out of the end game, but most users will be satisfied to put down the game after the final foe is foiled. I certainly am, and it’s an amicable separation, for £20 I felt I got what I paid for, and the game seems to breathe a sigh of relief that I’m asking no more of it.As Sonic games go, Generations is a fun tribute. It remixes its ancestry but adds little to the series other than a recognition of when to bow out. Classic Sonic was fun to see again, but I doubt he’ll be back and it’s perhaps better that way, he’s had his day and now it’s his older, more jaded self that has to prove his worth. Modern Sonic is not redeemed by this title, and the later levels remind you that he still has his fair share of issues. But maybe he can move on, maybe someday we’ll get that 9/10 Sonic game that blows us away. This, though, is not that game, but it seems it was never meant to be. Short, silly and satisfying, Sonic Generations is a snacky game, not an epic event, and it’s nice to see something that knows its limitations. No melodrama, no over the top score, a fun run through the past of one of gaming’s most contentious icons and then off home with a smile on your face. It’s a better tribute than it ought to be.*Game time has since been oosted by the incredible Sonic Unleashed Mod that adds the levels of Sonic Unleashed to the roster. Highly reccoomended.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 3, 2013
												So my first proper review, and what way to start it off with one of the best Sonic games ever, even if it is simply a load of past stages recreated.The cutscenes are greatly improved from the Xbox 360 version, no longer looking pixilated, well for me anyway. It also runs at a very nice and plesent 60 FPS, making Sonic and his vibrant surroundings look georgous no matter what. The game as a whole looks fantasic as it is, from the cheerful rolling hills of Green Hill Zone, to the gritty and action-packed Crysis City.The stages are so much fun. Each course is littered with secrets and alternate routes that I am still discovering every time I go back to shave precious milliseconds off your high scores. They really are a blast to play and feel unique from one another but not too gimmicky, which Sonic games have felt like in the past. As well as stages we each fight a classic boss at the end of the Era, either being the final boss of a previous game or a rival character (wait, how is Silver here?). The rivals are cool and interesting ideas, and well executed, along with the other bosses. I would have to say my favourite rival is Shadow, it feels just so... right, and it's an amazing update to fight in Sonic Adventure 2. I also love the Death Egg Robo as one of the bosses, all it's phases are just awesome and mix up the battle.But obviously, the highlight of this game is the music, as expected. I love every single one of the remixes (errr... minus Planet Wisp and another Open Your Heart remix, they got butchered) and is my favourite soundtrack next to Sonic 3 & Knuckles and Sonic Adventure 2. From the incredible violins in Rooftop Run to the tears of manliness I cry when I hear City Escape for the 7 billionth time.  Just take some time to listen to it, you'll love it.However, having said that, there are some minor complaints. The game as a whole is a bit short, it'll take you roughly 2-3 hours to complete and even less if your a veteran of the series. The Red Rings add a little more time to 7-9 hours and are a nice reward and incentive for you to discover and explore the stages and it's many routes. Also, the game is very easy. For me anyway, I got most S-Ranks first time. I also find myself going back to Modern Sonic more than Classic Sonic, despite so many people yarning for his return.Overall, this game is amazing, for what there is of it. It may be short, and easy, but if your just looking for some high-speed-nostalgia-trippin'-rocking-beats-blue-burred blast, this is the game for you. A great way to celebrate Sonic's 20th anniversary and a perfect example that the hedgehog is still on top.9/10

content:
Posted: January 31, 2014
												Probably my favorite, if not, my favorite Sonic game in the franchise. Besides the fact that the game gets so fast and fun at points, and the epic sense of tingles going down your back from the bosses and stages, the music makes it even better. Personally, I loved that I could actually change the music for all of the stages and bosses to put in an epic song. While the game may seem great, it still comes with its fair share of bugs. One major issue is the Rouge Seaside Hill mission bug where the game will most likely crash. This can be avoided however using only the boost, and destroying only necessary robots. Sometimes the frame rate of the game may get slow at times, but that comes with most games anyway. Overall, I enjoy the game and I'm pretty sure most other people with a decent computer will too.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 12, 2014
												For those of you who have played Sonic the Hedgehog and enjoyed it, you will love this game. For those of you who probably avoided teh Sonic games, I suggest getting the demo. This game is great, and runs remarkably smooth. The game has a mere 18 levels over 9 different worlds. Not particularly amazing, but those levels provide tons of replay value as you attempt to get all the S ranks. Classic Sonic is fun, but doesn't particularly evolve past what you start with. Probably why it's considered the easy mode of the game. Modern Sonic is where all the best stuff is though. Levels are varied and the speed is ever more intense. You'll find a lot of the games better moments in the Modern Sonic portions. (Though Classic is still tons of fun as well.)

The game as a whole is a bit short, it'll take you roughly 2-3 hours to complete and even less if your a veteran of the series. The Red Rings add a little more time to 7-9 hours and are a nice reward and incentive for you to discover and explore the stages and it's many routes. Also, the game is very easy. For me anyway, I got most S-Ranks first time. I also find myself going back to Modern Sonic more than Classic Sonic, despite so many people yarning for his return.Overall, this game is amazing, for what there is of it. It may be short, and easy, but if your just looking for some high-speed-nostalgia-trippin'-rocking-beats-blue-burred blast, this is the game for you. A great way to celebrate Sonic's 20th anniversary and a perfect example that the hedgehog is still on top.9/10

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 24, 2014
												What can I say? It's one of the best 3D Sonic platformers ever made! And it made it to PC!To be honest, when I bought this, I was expecting an easy game, with little to bo challenge, that I would be able to beat in a couple of hours (I'm looking at you Sonic Colors on the DS). Turns out I was wrong, and gladly wrong, because this game offers a great degree of challenge latter on. The levels are awesome and reminiscent of past Sonic levels, from the recognizable Green Hill Zone to the cloudy Sky Sanctuary Zone. The story is a hit or miss, way too childish and simple, I wish that Sonic games weren't targeted for a younger audience as they are now.Overall a great experience, and one of the best platformers on Steam. You don't need to be a Sonic fan to apreciate the game, but it sure helps!Edit: After playing the game a bit more to achieve 100% completion, I must add that while the controls are fine, I found myself struggling to make certain jumps (god, the frustration) and also found some glitches related to the camera - the camera stays on the side, when it should be centered, makes it hard to platform, when drifting the camera decides to wander off, that sort of thing. Also, the game often crashed when trying to play ranked time attack online, not to mention that the leaderboards are completely hacked, with people having completion times of 00m00s!Other than that, I still recomend this game.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 29, 2014
												Sonic has had a bumpy road in 3D, but you already know that. That being said, I'm happy to admit that Sonic Generations may be the best 3D Sonic game. The gameplay is split between slower, momentum-based 2D Classic Sonic sections and fast-paced frantic 3D Modern Sonic sections. It's the best of both worlds, and both contrast each other beautifully. Seemingly small differences like Modern Sonic's boost mechanic make major alterations throught his levels and the slower more platforming centered Classic Sonic levels allow for more exploration, however both of these playstyles tend to merge and weave in and out of each other in some clever ways. You may find a section of a Modern Sonic level rithe with multiple paths and slower platforming segments or a Classic Sonic section in which you blaze by at ludicrous speeds. The game's presentation is solid, boasting bright, colorful visuals and a rocking soundtrack comprising of remixes from selected Sonic levels of the past. The whole game Sonic Generations for how much it holds on to the past, seems to be carving a new future for the blue blur that I hope SEGA will continue going down. Definatley worth you time and your money. A controller is HIGHLY reccomended and as there are little in the ways of graphical settings, make sure your rig at least meets the reccomended specs as playing this game below 60 frames per second feels very unresponsive and slow, something you don't want in a fast-paced game like this.

												Sonic Generations is easily the best modern Sonic game, a variety of different level designs and the option to play as young or old Sonic gives you the old 2D style Sonic platformer gameplay and the new 3D level designs.The PC port though is very flawed, the online mode is broken and will crash the game randomly.The single player mode is excellent and still makes the game worthwhile even though the online mode is broken.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: December 8, 2013
												A Sonic fan gets Sonic Generations. What happens?MIND BLOW.Sonic Generations is a fantastic addition to the Sonic franchise. From the nostalgic setting of Green Hill Zone, to the bright and fresh Rooftop Run, I was hooked.Classic Sonic feels much like he did in the old days of the Genesis. He runs, he spins, you get the drill.Modern Sonic is the same as in Sonic Unleashed, but with a few tweaks to improve his control. His boost is no longer necessary for certain parts, meaning players who didn't like the boost gameplay can go back to Sonic Adventure style gameplay.The stages are a ton of fun to rush through, but they're also fun to explore. Often, if you speed through the level, you'll miss some secrets and easter eggs. City Escape is one such case. If you don't slow down, you'll miss tons of throwbacks to older titles.The graphics are INCREDIBLE. Often times, the graphics are the best I've seeen on a PC.So the game is a masterpiece, and you should get. The end, right?No.Sadly, Sonic Generations has its fair share of issues.Towards the end of your adventure, three obstacles will arise.Planet Wisp, Egg Dragoon, and (SPOILERS) the Time Eater.Planet Wisp is a mess. Not only is it 95% bland factory, but it's INCREDIBLY LONG. New players will most likely spend 7-10 minutes in this place.Egg Dragoon suffers from the length as well. The boss drags on for while, eventually succumbing to the constant homing attacks you've been spamming for the past 8 minutes. God help you if you play it on hard mode.*SPOILERS*The Time Eater is a boss that ALSO suffers in length. Maybe that was Eggman's plan: to bore you to death. Sadly, not only is this fight long, it's completely one-sided. Often times, you'll be RIGHT infront of him, about to land a hit, when he desides to jump fifty feet back!! Oh, and those, "helpful" friend of yours? Get used to the saying, "It looks like a homing missle!! Be carful, Sonic!!"Thankfully, those are all the problems I had with this game.Sonic Generations is a wonderful platformer for gamers old and new. It offers a bunch of new things to keep the expierience fresh, while also borrowing just enough ideas from Sonic's past to make the ultimate Sonic tribute. If you haven't already, do yourself a favor, and BUY IT!!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 15, 2014
												This is a mild recommendation. I was a big Sonic fan as a kid, so this game has a huge nostalgia value for me. The 2D Sonic levels feel great, the 3D levels are usually pretty good, and hearing a lot of the classic music from the games being remixed is fantastic.But I was a little disappointed in this game, too. I wasn't expecting to finish the game in 6 hours. That feels REALLY short to me, particularly since the game's currently selling for $30 at full price. (I, luckily, got it on sale.) There are a lot of optional challenges which I mostly haven't done, but I didn't feel like the gameplay was compelling enough to make me want to.And in the 3D levels I stumbled across some of the flaws that have plagued the series since the switch to 3D--glitches (one time I fell through the floor and died), a wonky camera (which is REALLY frustrating when you go fast) and occasionally frustrating controls (a lot of times I didn't home in on an enemy with my homing attack when I thought for sure that it should've worked--I'm not sure if it was a glitch or if I was just unclear on how it should work but either way, it was frustrating).I ended up feeling pretty luckwarm on this game, which was really disappointing considering all the praise I've been hearing about it. It DID tickle my nostalgia so I'm giving it a rec for that--the game sets out what it wants to do, pay homage to the Sonic series. If you're a fan and that's what you're wanting, pick it up. Otherwise I find this hard to recommend--there's a lot of better platformers out there on Steam nowadays. At the very least, I'd wait for this game to go on sale rather than paying full-price.

content:
Posted: December 23, 2013
												This game is amazing. whether you play it in 40 frames per second or 60, the game looks and feels great. The game already has a ton of content, and there's tons of free mods for it including: a real hedgehog texture(it only works on modern Sonic but still looks both cool and hillarious), solo ports of levels from Colors, Adventure 1&2, even a level from the almost forgotten Shadow the Hedgehog, and most impressively a port of more than half of the daytime stages from Sonic unleashed. And although this game is almost 3 years old, there are still more mods being made, and with the Sonic GMI program you don't have to merge the mod files with the games, so all you need to do to play the original game is simply uncheck the "enable mods" box and you're good to go.

content:
Posted: November 26, 2013
												This game is unbelievably fun! The story itself probably takes about 7 or 8 hours, which is kind of short, but with over 90 side missions and the amount of challenge they provide, this game will have you playing for days! The game has brilliant level design and combines the 2D and 3D aspects of both the Modern and Classic Sonic stages.Every single level in Sonic Generations is a multi-path racetrack. You'll blaze past ramps, jumps, hidden emblems and entire new depths before you realize that you could have been soaring through them with a second's more dedication. Then you'll return to right your wrongs, as a quicker and more deliberate blur of cold-calculated genius on the rollercoaster setpieces created for your driven demolition. Newcomers will flail as they collide with walls, obstacles and clocks built either to deter them from this franchise forever or beat them into determined masterminds. Dedicated gamers will, on the other hand, give this thing the asskicking it deserves, and they'll earn it by triumphing over gameplay that's both thick and balanced, instead of fighting against the insurmountably broken ideologies that weave their way into most Sonic the Hedgehog games these days. Generations is definitetly one of the best Sonic games in a while, and I highly recommend playing it.

content:
Posted: July 22, 2014
 The best Sonic game SEGA has ever created in years!  This game shows that Sonic finally broke out of the  dark ages  he was facing ever since his 15th anniversary. A lot of people argue with the gameplay elements being a reminiscent to Sonic Unleashed's 'Boost-to-win' mechanic, but it actually perfects it with genius level design. IMO, it actually outshines the 2D sections by providing tons of alternate pathways. Of course, no game is perfect and this game has its fair share of flaws, like Classic Sonic’s physics being a bit wonky and not emulating the good ol’ Genesis controls. Also, the story is an incomplete piece of garbage with bad writing and crappy voice acting (Excluding Tails, Dr. Eggman, Espio and Rouge).  BTW the Final Boss Battle is complete S H I T  ! Long time Sonic fans will appreciate the huge amount of Easter eggs, references and homages that are spread all over the game. *sigh* Unfortunately, this game is pretty short and at times you get that feeling there is something missing. It's like buying a puzzle box with a chunk of the pieces not included. You can beat this in about 3-4 hours without pacing yourself! Thanks to the HUGE modding community, you can have an endless amount of level mods extending the amount of gameplay! Most mods are often ports/recreations of past Sonic levels, so now you can replay your childhood with better controls. I'll give two separate scores for  Sonic Generations :  8.0 OUT OF 10!!!  stand alone 9.5 OUT OF 10!!!  with modsWant to enhance your experience?! CHECK OUT THE SGMC!!!You'll need 7-Zip, WinRAR etc... http://www.moddb.com/mods/sonic-generations-unleashed-project/news/sonic-generations-unleashed-project-10-released Recommended mods to check out  Unleashed Model http://youtu.be/VoVKEUay21o Unleashed Project http://youtu.be/LBE2EFNQoEo Wave Ocean http://youtu.be/MPPYkehJI0U

content:
Posted: October 6, 2012
												SEGA promised the fans and they delivered. Classic sonic is back wearing the correct shade of blue jumping from platform to platform in his whole new 2D world, of course with Modern Sonic tagging along with his 'Sonic Unleashed' style stages. Sonic Generations alternates between the two Sonics as they try and subdue the villain 'cleverly' named the 'Time Eater'. There are 3 eras in the game with 3 stages within each, 2 decades of 'Sonicness' for both Classic fans and Modern fans to enjoy.As you progress through the not so great story, you will play through 1 Classic stage, 1 Dreamcast stage and 1 Modern stage all of which have 2 levels for both Modern and Classic sonic. Watching Classic Sonic 'run' not 'blast' through each stage is wonderful and fills the air around you with sweet nostalgia and success. Not to forget Modern Sonic with his finally mastered 'Unleashed' controls, playing as Modern Sonic is just as enjoyable as it was in Colours and Unleashed but this time with an extra "uummph".I must say SEGA have finally captured the essence of our beloved Hedgehog and have made an excellent game which makes you forget about the many mistakes they have made in the past (Sonic 06). Overall Sonic Generations is an excellent game and a 'must have', even though the game has a fairly bland and predictable plot, and not to forget that Modern Sonic is still... Well... Modern Sonic, but even with all the Complaints from other fans it seems like a meaningless excuse to just hate on our once beloved Sonic.Sonic is finally getting his s*** together not to forget that this is an improvement from his last 2 games or 3. But if you are a true fan you will buy this game, "I mean pleeeaaasse, we all bought Sonic 06". And with added mods from other sonic fans this game is a lot better on PC than any other console: DOpiziite - 8.4

content:
Posted: December 19, 2015
												Overall, Sonic Generations is an amazing game. If you ask me, it's the perfect way to celebrate Sonic the Hedgehog's 20th anniversary. Why? Not only do you get to play as Modern Sonic, but also Classic Sonic (he introduced me to videogames, believe it or not). So, needless to say, it can appeal to you whether you're a fan of the 2D, Genesis classics, or even the modern, 3D games. Every level has been taken from previous games in the series, all of which were voted to be in the game by the fans. One cool feature within the game is the ability to choose what music plays in the background of a level. You can unlock music through collecting red rings (returning from my favorite Sonic game, Sonic Colors) and completing challenges (a lot of which are a major pain in the neck to complete, let alone get an S-rank on). Oh, and if you were to ask me, I think people complain about the final boss fight WAY too much. It's not perfect, but it's not terrible, either (especially once you learn its attack-patterns and can collect rings efficiently). In conclusion, Sonic Generations doesn't quite have everything I expect to see from a Sonic game, but it is a masterpiece and it should be in every Sonic fan's collection.

												Even though I have some INSANE lag while playing the game, I don't care about it. The story is incredible, great level designs; but there is one problem, and it is the controls. I do not have a controller, and so I use the keys A and D to move, W and S to look up and down, down arrow key to jump (which is annoying and took me some time to get used to it), right arrow key to crouch and left arrow key to do the spinning thing. Let's just say that you need to add control editing so not only me but other people can make the controls however they want. And add the ability to change the video settings, to remove some lag.So I do recommend it for people who have controllers and fast computers, but if you're a PC gamer and you hate having lag, just don't.

content:
Posted: February 23, 2016
												This game is great for any sonic fan, especially someone who has grown up with all the different Sonic games starting from Megadrive and going from there.Every level has 2 versions to it. One as retro Sonic where it is more side scrolling adventure and the other where it is the more modern Sonic. Both have the fast pace and exciting scenery Sonic fans will love.First 3 levels are a fantastic revisit of Green Hill Zone and Chemical Plant Zone. They really are true to the Megadrive versions with same monsters, plants and a great re-make of the music. The Chemical Plant Zone really brings back all the horrors of the pink liquid.They also did an amazing job expanding the Sky Sanctuary Zone from Sonic and Knuckles which is good because in the original version the level was quite short.After that it more delves into next gen Sonic. Like Sonic Adventure, Sonic Heroes etc. Levels are great and still stay true to the original feel. I just wish they had a few more Megadrive levels, I would have love to have seen Mushroom Hill Zone, Hydro Plant Zone and Hilltop Zone (Although in the later levels there is something similar)In the later level there is some real hair pulling scenarios that almost ruin the game, especially the last bosses. Way too punishing and time consuming.Overall I would recommend this game for any long time Sonic fan wanting to revisit your favorite levels with a modern twist on them.

												Ok, first things first. Do I reccomend this? Eeeeeeeh, no. Don't buy this game. Instead, wait for a sale or get the Sonic Hits Collection(http://store.steampowered.com/sub/26498/) for about the same price which comes with this and some REALLY good Sonic titles such as Sonic Adventure DX, Sonics 1-3K and Sonic CD. If you're a fan of mediocrity then it also comes with Sonic Adventure 2, Sonic 4 and both AllStar racing games.Now, onto the game. The keyboard controls are absolute♥♥♥♥♥♥ You'll need a gamepad to actually enjoy it, so make sure you have one before you get it(or alternatively get the Hits collection and play some other sonic games while you're waiting). The game is also rather short with just 9 stages with 2 acts and 10 missions each. Some of the bosses, especially the final boss, are disappointingly easy and/or frustrating Now that we have everything negative out of the way...The gameplay is solid 2d/3d Sonic action which lets you switch between modern and classic Sonic. The stages are all rather open which adds a ton to the replay value, and each level is unique and has something special. All the stages are taken from previous games, but add something new to the originals. The graphics are beautiful and the music is excellent as always. The story is just there to link the game together.The game also has great mod support and is a good PC port, with the exception of the previously mentioned♥♥♥♥♥♥controls. Overall, a good experience that I'd say is overpriced. Get the Hits Collection, seriously.

Posted: November 2, 2015
												This is easily the best "new" Sonic game out there. Go figure since it relies heavily on nostaliga and classic mechanics. You can choose between the classic 2D type Sonic and the new 3D type for every act and level. It works surprisingly well and while both 2D and 3D leave some poor level design in its wake, it's still a lot of fun - nostalgia or not.It also looks fantastic on PC. If you want Sonic and more classic Sonic than Adventure Sonic, this game is your best bet. Decent amount of levels and lots of side stuff to do for a Sonic game. Well worth full price, I dare say, if you're a Sonic fan.

content:
Posted: April 4, 2016
												Allright, I purchased this game mostly because I heard that you get to play original Sonic 1 in it. So, yeah... After beating the act 1, I figured out that I should do it again, but now in 3d. And so I did and still nothig, so... I beat the game and finished most of the challanges in 2d and 3d, looking for the mistical Sonic 1 all around and couldn't find it anywhere. So, after spending several hours in my noble quest to be able to play Sonic 1 in PC without some sort of simulator, I gave up on my own logic and I went to consult with the oracle (Google), looking for clues of how to get to this point of the game where you'll be able to play Sonic 1... To find out, that you actually can't. Not on PC version, at least. So, yeah... That was pretty dissapointing. And the game itself is allright, though there are just like... 9 levels and 3 bosses. 18 levels, if you take in count the 3d version of those and 4 bosses, if you count the final one. So, after you beat those, welcome to the challenges and stuff. But it's enjoyable to replay some of the levels, so it's allright. Not a big fan of 3d Sonic, though.7/10.

Posted: July 15, 2016
												OH, MY GOD!!! This has to be the best game ever!! It shouldn't be $ though. This game lasts me hours! I love the concept of the Classic Sonic, who doesn't say anything; meets the loud - mouthed Modern Sonic. There are quite a few requirements for this game, though.I reccomend you have the following...-Windows Vista at the minimum (Sorry Mac users) And I know it says XP for the minimum in the requirements, but everyone knows XP for steam is crap.-Laptop (DO NOT GET THIS ON A DESKTOP IF YOU DON'T KNOW HOW TO FIX THE MONITOR ISSUE!!)If u only have a desktop, go into Program Files (x86)/steam/steamapps/common/sonicgenerations. From there, delete the file called configfiles.cfg, than launch the config, than launch the game.-Any Suppourted Controller (It took me 30 Mins. to configure my keyboard to the game's controls; and the controller is already configed.-Speakers and/or Headphones (This game has AWESOME music in the levels and to be able to unlock in the boss key missions).Overall, I give this game 5/5! There are some ways to get this game on permanent discount, but I didn't use those.HAVE FUN!!!

content:
Posted: February 14, 2015
												// Sonic Generatio is a 2D & 3D Adventure Game: //// Schuitje82 - Extended Review //About:======Finally after years of bad games Sonic Generations is a great game.Sonic Generations is a look at the past of the Sonic games.Many levels come back from Sonic 1, 2, 3 as the adventure series.What I think it's very special that you can play all stages in 2d as 3d perspective.Overall a very unique concept that makes this game special in his own way. Story:=====Story mode is about you are facing Dr. Eggman & Time Lord (what his name is) together with Old & Next Gen Sonic.You run with both character though stages to rescue your buddies who are traped in the stages / time line.When you complete 2d and the 3d part the stage will unlock and you have saved your friend.Gore Gameplay:============The game is not only about the story mode and running.Beside the main story mode the games gives you a♥♥♥♥♥♥load of extra challanges to play.Like Time Trail, Defeating Bosses like Metal Sonic, Collecting Items with knuckles.There is so many things to do in this game this will keep you playing for hours and hours.And gives the game a good variation.There is a ingame pinball table... only this is DLC content :(Graphic & Controls:===============They did a great job with the graphic part of this game.If you PC can handle the game this game looks SuperB on Max settings.The game supports the The Xbox 360 joypad.Did not tested it with other controllers.Game plays very well and gives you the old feeling like the Sega era back in the '90.Overall:=======Game looks great, great music and really has the feel of my childhood sonic game.Score: 9--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------== For more reviews go to www.gamegrin.com ==== Please don't forget to like my reviews ==

content:
Posted: December 26, 2014
												Sonic Generations is a huge tribute to the most popular Sonic game, you can have both the old school sonic and the modern sonic styles of game and the most remembered scenarios and songs from previous Sonic games also has a lot of great artwork, unfortunately has several bugs and i don't recommend you to complete all the achievements.. is too hard with those bugsGameplay 8/10I loved the gameplay, you will have 9 scenarios over 2 acts, these scenarios are map inspired and almost the same from Sonic 1, 2, 3, Sonic & Knuckles, Sonic Adventure 1 & 2, Sonic The Hedgehog, Sonic Unleashed and Sonic Colors. Can seem that are not many maps, but you can play also over 90 challenges.Classic Sonic mode: is the classic platform mode, when you clear the challenges you can use the Electric, Fire, Bubble and Sonic 1 shields.Modern Sonic mode: is a third person mode, in which sonic can lock and hit targets and use Turbo, the third person perspective switches with a platform in several part of each map. The only thing i hate was the final boss fight, i didn't get anthing that was going on.. to much effects weird angles.. and also for me there was several maps in modern sonic that were tricky and confusing but if you play Sonic Adventure previously, this probably won't be an issue.The difficulty of the game is up to you, you can try to get S in all the stages, and make all the challenges, or simply pass the story, but all the boss fights are very easy.. like in every Sonic games the boss has simple patterns.I took me 29 hours to unlock all the Achievements, because of a bug took me some hours to figure it out. Just plaing the story with cinematics can be done in 5, you are forced to play some challenges to unlock the new stages.Graphics 9/10The graphics are pretty descent the only problem is playing using Steam Streaming, i tried but for some reason the image capture of Steam was too slow and couldn't play it that way. And the 2d to 3d charater transformation were great.Sound & Music 9/10The music and sounds are from the previous Sonic games but with a loot of more quality, brings my childhood back each time i hear the Sonic spins, hits fire shield sounds etc. I think the sound work is awesome.Bugs & stability 5/10Several times i found bugs, like the Ranked Attack maps crashes every time... i could find how to "skip" the bug but also has a lot of work and very frustrating...Some scenarios had a few parts with bad collision but almost never caused me getting kill.Total 7/10I totally recommend you this game if you love classics Sega Genesis Sonic i guarantee that you will enjoy it and bring your childhood back a couple of hours. I hope this review were useful to you and tanks for reading.  Regards!

												This is game is amazing. I never expected Sonic to still be good after the Sonic Adventure stuff that I didn't like the direction of. Sonic Generations is like being back in the 90's playing Sonic 2, 3 and Sonic&Knuckles but with improvements. Definitely play if you've ever played and liked Sonic. number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 27, 2014
												Incredibly fun, fast paced, and nostalgic game!Music - The music is such a huge part of the game for me. You can unlock new songs and listen to any song you've ever unlocked while play through any stage or mission. That and a few remixes in this game are just amazing. Favorite remixes are probably the Shadow's battle theme remixed, Super Sonic Racing (Generations mix), and Speed Highway (Modern remix.) But every stage has two remixes it to it (sans boss battles and side missions) that bring back lots of good and bad memories (that damn tornado, ughhhhhh.)Levels - The stages are great and some have achievements are nice little cameo appearances of one time characters appearing here and there in the background somewhere (Fang, Bean, and Polar for example appear on some posters in City Escape.) The levels have entirely nice design although I feel a few of them could have been much better done to either be harder or less of a pain to complete.Story - Same old, same old, Dr. Robotnik(s) up to their old shenanigans as per usual. Nice trip down memory lane regardless.Bonus - The hidden trophy room, good luck figuring out ALL the codes for the trophies (most likely will use a guide like I did since there's no real indication the room exist or how to find and get the codes.) The content room has the FMVs, concept art, character info, and music for enjoyment.Game play - Modern and Classic Sonic vary in play style (although you can eventually unlock Homing Attack for Classic Sonic which takes forever to do.) Classic Sonic is side scrolling and using older game style controls, Modern Sonic uses newer playing styles and can't spin dash sadly but can go into Boost Mode and pick up really nice speed.Overall, I would recommend this game, whether it be part of the bundle, stand alone, or on discount. :)

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 16, 2014
												While it has faults, with some of the later stages slowing things down to a crawl, the majority of this game is just so much damned fun.  It really captures the essence of Sonic.  Not only are the 2d stages great, but the 3d ones work very well for the most part.  The only times that the 3d stages fall apart are when the game no longer has you pinned to a 2d plane.The story is hokey but, you know what, that's actually kind of what I want out of a Sonic game.It's hard to say much else about Generations because when the stages aren't entirely cut and pasted from other games, they're very VERY inspired from stages in previous iterations.  Unfortunately you can also gauge how entertaining they'll be based on where they came from (Hint: the sonic colors stages are awful, as are the Sonic Heroes stages).I may have said some negative things but I had an amazing time with this game and I'm very glad it existed.  Sega could stop making Sonic games right here and I would be happy because we've finally gotten a good one.  If you've ever enjoyed a Sonic game, I really think this should be in your library.

												Personally, I think this is the best Sonic game ever. It doesn't have the most detailed storyline, but that's okay. The music and levels are great on thier own, and I love replaying them. Then, there are hundreds of mods, including level ports from games such as Sonic Colors, Sonic Unleashed, and Sonic the Hedgehog (2006). Then, there are character and even physics mods. If you are just getting in to Sonic, I reccomend you play this game first, then play the games before it, then replay the levels. That's just about what I did, and it worked well for me.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 23, 2014
												Sonic has had a much bumpier career than Mario with his missing appearance on the Saturn, his first adventure into 3D having not aged too well, his first anniversary game being one of the worst games of all time (Sonic '06) and the attempts to fix the franchise afterword resorting to ripping off other non-related games (like God of War). That said, things have been looking good for Sonic ever since Colors came out and Generations does to some extent build on that momentum and even fix many of the problems with the previous 3D Sonic games. Of course much like Sonic's career, Generations has numerous flaws that keep it from reaching the peak of platforming bliss that old Jumpman set.Let's start off with the good: Generations looks and sounds great with crisp graphics, beautiful environments and some of the series best tunes in one package. Both the 2D and 3D levels are mostly fun (with a few disappointing exceptions) and in some cases even fix what weren't really fun levels before (such as '06's Crisis City). The controls are spot on and it seems they have almost perfected 3D Sonic's move set (almost, one of the missions proves that the Homing Attack is still a bit tricky) while 2D Sonic feels just like he did in the old games, which is funny given how odd Sonic 4 felt. The Story is nothing special, but it's not contrived and stupid like in Adventure 2 and '06, plus there are some funny lines here and there. Also the new not-4KIDS cast is great (even though Robotnik is still played by the same actor) and they fit the roles well without any weird ear bleeding voices making you reach for the mute button.As I said though, the game does have flaws that keep it from being a proper classic. For one thing, the game just feels padded. There are 9 levels (3 from each era: the Genesis Era, the Adventure Era and the Modern Era) with 2 acts each, 4 boss fights and 3 rival bosses. Given the general brevity of a standard Sonic level, this makes the game sound a bit short, even compared to other Sonic games. This is where the missions come in. In order to gain access to a boss of a given era, you have to get a key from each of the 3 levels. You get a key by completing missions (there are 5 for each level for both old and new Sonic), which you really only have to beat 1 of in each level. This is thing though; if you are only expected to do 1 per level, then why not just add a 3rd act? Reusing the existing level's assets for random missions just feels like they were tacked on at last minute or added to save money and really they just feel like filler. Franky, adding a 3rd act and just having the missions be completely optional would have been the better option.The other issue is that the missions them selves are mostly not fun. In fact a few are what I'd call "anti-fun" (the Vector music note one is one of the worst things I've ever played in my life). I can think of several that were no fun at all, but can't think of one that was fun off the top of my head. I'm sure there were a few, but they just don't leave an impression on you. The other issue is that while they fixed many levels that weren't fun in old games, they actually ruined one that was fun, that being Planet Wisp. I personally love Sonic Color, so I was excited to see what this level was like, but I was saddened to see that they didn't use any actual level from the game. I can understand for the 2D act (which was even less fun), but not the 3D one. How could they keep the '06 level mostly intact and then just ignore all the levels in Colors? What a waste.Those problems aside, Generations is still a fun game overall and well worth any Sonic fan's time. I'm not sure if I'd recommend it for new fans, maybe check out Colors or even Unleashed first or hell, just buy the Steam bundle that comes with 12 games for free and play the old games in order. There is really no reason not to.I give Sonic Generations an 8.0 out of 10.

content:
Posted: August 16, 2014
												While it has faults, with some of the later stages slowing things down to a crawl, the majority of this game is just so much damned fun.  It really captures the essence of Sonic.  Not only are the 2d stages great, but the 3d ones work very well for the most part.  The only times that the 3d stages fall apart are when the game no longer has you pinned to a 2d plane.The story is hokey but, you know what, that's actually kind of what I want out of a Sonic game.It's hard to say much else about Generations because when the stages aren't entirely cut and pasted from other games, they're very VERY inspired from stages in previous iterations.  Unfortunately you can also gauge how entertaining they'll be based on where they came from (Hint: the sonic colors stages are awful, as are the Sonic Heroes stages).I may have said some negative things but I had an amazing time with this game and I'm very glad it existed.  Sega could stop making Sonic games right here and I would be happy because we've finally gotten a good one.  If you've ever enjoyed a Sonic game, I really think this should be in your library.

content:
Posted: August 21, 2016
												It's a port of the Xbox version of the game. If you have a controller you can use to play the game and got a good enough PC, you're in for a good time.The game itself, as stated by the word "Generations" is a throwback to the previous installments, in this case, in the form of levels both in the "Modern" and "Classic" (More like Sonic 2 but with an OP spin dash) format. The levels aren't exactly ports, but they do channel some of the original elements of the source material, if and when they can... Except for the Sonic '06 level. Thankfully they went full-on original with the design.The reason i reccomend the use of a controller is because the config tool refuses to allow shift as an input, so you can't really bind anything to it. It's a common key to use for Sonic games, so i figured it'd be important to note.It's good, under certain circumstances. It's even got a modding community, which would be fantastic if people weren't trying to port their OCs into the game all the ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ time.BUT THAT'S THE SONIC COMMUNITY FOR YA.

content:
Posted: May 23, 2014
												This is by far the best Sonic game I have played in a long time.  The graphics are amazing.  The nostalgia from the remixes all my favorite songs is great (Chemical plant zone, and City escape).  The game is short if you ignore all the extras though.  All of the bosses except the last one are top notch.  The death Egg Robot fight was good nostalgias, Shadow was fun (they put the space battle in) and the Silver Boss fight is no use.  The last one isn't bad or not fun, I just didn't like it as much as the others.  Maybe it's just because I've never been good at Super Sonic Sections.  The only 2 levels that gave me trouble were the last one and crysis city.  The last level is just too long for my taste.  This is really a problem in some of the bonus missions.  And crysis city must have been infused with the power of Sonic 06.  That level is very faithful to source material.  I got stuck on platforms, got many gameovers, had trouble locking onto enemies, had some slow down, and even got stuck on a loop once.  You can tell they really put a lot of effort into recreating crysis city.  Overall,  I would say buy this game.  Amazing music, good throwbacks to source material, plenty of nostalgia, and overall solid gameplay make this a must own for any sonic fan.  I would say you have to be good at video games to enjoy this as if you are not you will constantly run into stuff.  8.5/10.

content:
