												Sonic Generations is probably the best Sonic Game I've played since Sonic Rush or Adventure 2. (Not counting All Stars Racing Transformed. ) If you enjoyed the original 2D sonic games, then you'll find something here. If you enjoyed the 3D games, you'll find something here.It's a great mix of the old and new. Every level is nostalgic, yet they still have hints of new things and shortcuts, etc. The boss battles are entertaining, aside from the lackluster final boss. There's alot of extra content such as ghost races and other trials to compete in, and you can unlock a fair amount of stuff, including Sonic 1 for the Genesis. My only real complaint is that the Sonic Colors stage sucks no matter what Sonic you play as (Classic or Modern) and Crisis City from Sonic 06 is pretty much as bad as it was in 06. I'd definitely pick this up if  you enjoyed any previous Sonic games.I'd give this a  FAST/10.

number of helpful: 6 of 11 people (55%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 3, 2014
												Few characters can say they've had as many ups and downs as Sonic the Hedgehog. For better or for worse, the Sonic franchise has carved out a long timeline with a lot of changes over the years. Generations is a look at both the old and the new.Sonic Generations is split into Classic and Modern levels, Classic as the 2D Genesis-era sidescroller era and Modern as the 2D/3D platforming speedways. Classic levels play pretty much how one would expect. The physics and momentum aren't quite as tight as the old Genesis games, but they're quite good, and it's a blessing to have the Spindash keyed to one button.Modern levels are a bit more mixed. On one hand, it's clear that this is the evolution of what we saw in Sonic Unleashed and Sonic Colors: a crazy blitz through lush environments, relying on reflexes and intuition to keep the flow from action to action. While it's an absolute joy to punch through a successful speedrun, it's easy to break out of the flow, and find yourself wrestling awkwardly to get yourself back to speed. Seems that you're either super fast or awkwardly trying to speed back up. Old 3D Sonic problems rear their head, sometimes awkward turning and immediate stops and the like. Que sera.Nostalgia runs rampant. Fans of the series will be really pleased with the details. Sonic Heroes era Badniks still do the little detection jump before they attack, the snowboard from City Escape returns, the stages use the classic camera angles for the stage openers. I found myself smiling at the little things. Props to the composers for a fantastic OST.The game is a bit short. 9 levels with a Classic and modern version, some old favorite boss battles and padded challenges round the game out, but I can't help but want much more.Generations is quite flawed, but the sheer spectacle of the speed and adrenaline can't be beat. It's fun.

content:
Posted: November 11, 2014
												Having only played classic games until buying the game, Generations is my first Modern Sonic game, and the twenty plus years in contrast between the Genesis games really showed.While modern Sonic stages were very fun, classic stages were odd. Though they played like old Sonic games, they didn't feel like old Sonic games. In short, the games expects you to use the physics instead of letting you do things your way. For example, I had a habit in older games to quickly halt myself while in a loop so I could backtrack. In this game, if you hit the brakes and try to turn around, Sonic will glitch through the loop and you'll lose a life. It's hard to express, but I hope you see my point.But the game was still fun. The music was really good, and nothing beats listening to awesome songs, old and new, while dashing through stages.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 15, 2016
												It's good for a Sega/Sonic game.  May be mediocre by normal standards.-Visuals are both pretty and nostalgic-Music has a bunch of remixes/rehashes of old songs (many of the songs werent even good to begin with)-Voice acting is terrible as usual-Settings and controller support arent great, kinda porty-Gameplay is OK but has typical Sonic stuff that stops gameplay unless you have the level memorized.  And of course there is a bunch of pointless animation where you aren't actually playing.  There's also a ton of random mechanics in levels that can be both unintuitive and frustrating.  The classic version of Sonic isnt captured perfectly but it's still fun enough (I guess I could say that about the new Sonic as well).-There's challenges that are, for the most part, not fun.-There's skills you can buy/equip which are kinda fun I guess.I only recommend this game if you already like Sonic.PS:In my opinion the pinball dlc is better realized than the whole game.  It's legitimately decent.

												A swan song to the golden age of gaming for one the oldest mascots.  The game combines classic 2D gameplay and the 2.5D platforming and speed of modern offerings.  With excellent graphics, blistering fast speed, and branching paths with lots of collectibles and shortcuts, this game delivers the opitmal Sonic experience.  Top that off with a teeming mod community, and you have a title worth your time and money.  Not to be dismissed!

Posted: December 29, 2014
												UhNot too sure what to write here so heres a recipe for Pancakes insteadIngredients:1 1/2 cups all-purpose flour3 tablespoons sugar1 tablespoon baking powder1/4 teaspoon salt1/8 teaspoon freshly ground nutmeg2 large eggs, at room temperature1 1/4 cups milk, at room temperature1/2 teaspoon pure vanilla extract3 tablespoons unsalted butter, plus more as neededNow to make it1. In a large bowl, whisk together the flour, sugar, baking powder, salt, and nutmeg.2. In another bowl, beat the eggs and then whisk in the milk and vanilla.3. Melt the butter in a large cast iron skillet or griddle over medium heat.4. Whisk the butter into the milk mixture. Add the wet ingredients to the flour mixture, and whisk until a thick batter is just formed5. Keeping the skillet at medium heat, ladle about 1/4 cup of the batter onto the skillet, to make a pancake. Make 1 or 2 more pancakes, taking care to keep them evenly spaced apart. Cook, until bubbles break the surface of the pancakes, and the undersides are golden brown, about 2 minutes. Flip with a spatula and cook about 1 minute more on the second side. Serve immediately or transfer to a platter and cover loosely with foil to keep warm. Repeat with the remaining batter, adding more butter to the skillet as needed.6. Procedure for adding fruit to pancakes: Once the bubbles break the surface of the pancakes, scatter the surface with sliced or diced fruit, or chocolate chips, nuts, etc. Flip with a spatula and cook for 1 minute more, being careful not to burn toppings.

Posted: January 6, 2014
												Incredible sense of speed and velocity, Sonic Generations is everything Unleashed hoped to be.Where Sonic games tend to punish you for being "Too Fast", Generation rewards you more the faster you go, but it's up to you wether you're quick enough to react.The goal stays the same as ever; Stay on the highest possible ground. You usually get 2-3 levels in any given stage. The lower you go, the slower you're forced to run, jumping death gaps and platforming narrow platforms, whereas if you stay high up and react quick enough to not fall down, your progress is significntly faster.Great Sonic game, and would recommend to anyone that likes platformers.

content:
Posted: December 30, 2013
												Game: Sonic GenerationsGenre: AdventureDeveloper: Sonic Team/SEGASystem: Steam/PCTotal Score: 96/100Value Score: 9.6/10• Story: 9/10o Sonic the Hedgehog was having a birthday party with all the friends he has made in over the past couple of years. However something off in the distance a dark ominous being appeared and sucked everyone up and leaving both Sonic and Tails confused at what happened in a unknown mysterious space void. There they find themselves in a familiar location and as they traveled around they managed to find younger form of themselves. Now both Sonics and Tails will be going on a new journey to save their friends and their own respected times and worlds.• Characters: 10/10o Almost every single Sonic series hero and villain appear in this game. There are some ones who do not make an appearance but all of the major characters from the past few generations do appear. You have characters like Sonic and Tails from both the past and present, Dr. Eggman of the past and present, Amy, Shadow the hedgehog, Rouge, Knuckles and the rest from Colors, Unleashed and etc. The enemies are also the same depending on the level of which game it reflects off from. Some of the notable bosses as well from the past games also make an appearance. Sonic Generations is pretty much like a reunion for the Sonic the Hedgehog franchise.• GamePlay: 9/10o Sonic Generations plays differently from the older Sonic games. For one thing levels and stages are divided into different areas from past Sonic games and you can access them through as Classic Sonic or Modern sonic in a world map like sidescroller style. Playing as either sonic will alter the gameplay and changes the whole design of a level/stage. Classic Sonic's gameplay style is more old school 2D view while Modern Sonic's is mostly 3D view like recent Sonic games. There are three levels with each area having a mini boss and a boss at the end of the three levels. Defeating each mini boss and boss earns you a chaos emerald which is used to fight the last boss at the end of the game. Each level consists stages from different eras of Sonic - in the PC version which is the same as the home console versions, the levels and stages are included as : Classic Era - Green Hill from Sonic the Hedgehog, Chemical Plant from Sonic the Hedgehog 2 and Sky Sanctuary from Sonic the Hedgehog 3 & Knuckles. The Dreamcast era includes Speed highway from Sonic Adventure 1, City Escape from Sonic Adventure 2 and Seaside hill from Sonic Heroes. The Modern era which is the last era has Crisis City from Sonic the Hedgehog 2006, Rooftop Run from Sonic Unleashed and Planet Wisp from Sonic Colors. The usual gameplay rules apply to both modern and classic sonic - collecting rings and racing your way towards the exit marker at the end of the stage after avoiding all sorts of enemies and obstacles. For Modern sonic you can super speed dash upon a limitation bar which can be increased by collecting rings while classic sonic mainly plays like the old Sonic games with little to no difference. The level designs for each type is completely different even though it may be in the same stage. You have the usual power ups such as invincibility, shields which range from the regular green shield, the electric shield which absorbs rings, the fire ring which can make Sonic shoot like a fireball and the water shield which Sonic can use to breathe underwater or to have a extra bounce. Upon completing stages you will get access to additional missions which base around the level of where these missions are located (which is above each level entrance). These missions also vary depending on which Sonic you play as and will have a different requirement or goal as well which can range from completing a level, fighting/competing with a rival, collecting certain number of rings or simply surviving amongst other things. Completing these missions will earn you a point towards the achievement of completing all the missions and allows you to unlock a artwork or a music track which can be used optionally on other stages. Red stars also make an appearance in which goes towards your achievement scoring and is counted towards the completion of the game. A new feature introduced to the Generations game is the ability to buy power ups or abilities which can be equipped upon purchase with a limitation on how many you can equip by the number of points it requires compared to how many you have in total. Abilities and power ups range from simple power ups depending on certain situations happening automatically, the inclusion of new speed abilities or the ability to protect yourself with some bonuses such as keeping a few rings even after taking a hit instead of losing all your rings. There's also a special room where you can go and check on character profiles, listen to the game's OST or to even look at some promotional artwork designed for the game. The online feature of the game introduces you to a competitive circuit where you are forced to do a level and are ranked by the time and score upon completion which then gets displayed in a leader boards for bragging rights.• Graphics: 10/10o Sonic Generations use a new style of visual design and fluidity for its cutscenes however the in gameplay seems to be similar to what you would expect see in a HD version of Sonic Colors and of Sonic the Hedgehog 4. The new cutscenes seem reminiscent of a typical western influenced platformer which isnt a bad thing. The visual designs for the characters look great especially on the older versions of characters. The environments re-done from past Sonic games look incredible with the new style and brings a whole new depth to whatever the player had imagined beforehand in the past games. There are some slow down and FPS drops but that is only because you would need a stronger CPU than what is recommended but by not that much and not very noticeable.• Sound: 10/10o Sonic Generations have managed to keep majority of the voice overs for their characters from all eras including the eras without voice overs are nicely done and you can tell the difference in the quality/type of voice. However even though Sonic doesnt talk might be a bad thing - what was worse is the fact that Shadow and Rouge's voice actors were changed but it isnt bad to the extent where they sound completely off. The sound effects which were made famous in the older sonic games and all of the other games make a complete return.• Music: 10/10o Sonic Generations consists of a mixture of old classic tracks, original tracks from modern games and remixes of all of the songs with a bit of new tracks exclusive to the game. The remixes are actually quite well made and some of them are even BETTER than the originals. Another nice thing that they added is the ability to change the music when you play in a stage. Simply upon clicking to start on a stage change the music to whatever you have unlocked via playing missions.• Length: 9/10o Sonic Generations although might seem a bit short but it takes a lot of time and dedication to get all the red stars, perfect score points upon completion and to get every single music/artwork unlocked. At the most you will complete at least 12-15 hours on a straight way playthrough with minimal missions completed. For a platformer that is a pretty decent amount since most platformers are usually done within 7-10 hours.• Replay Value: 10/10o Sonic Generations most powerful aspect is possibly its replay value aspect. With the ability to play in over 50 different stages over the choice of 7+ maps that seems to be a pretty hefty amount considering if you add the mini bosses and the bosses you fight along the way along with some of the things you need to collect such as Red stars which will eventually make you play through the levels multiple times.

content:
Posted: January 11, 2014
												Welcome to the Next Generation!Sonic Generations brings back the core of Sonic along with the new mechanics that Sonic Series needed, since the downfall of "Sonic the Hedgehog (2006)", the series took a major downfall and refused to focus on what the it was all about. Sonic Generations brings back that part and should be considered the franchise's future. However, not sure where and when Sega will continue to use this engine to bring back more classic gameplay perhaps even remake Sonic 1-3 with this engine would suffice in bringing back more Modders to take a challenge.If you have not thought about playing the Classics, and atleast going through time to all the Games that really were a hit aside from the last three levels, you just might enjoy this game. Although, the last 3 sets died to me in the original useage, they really made it fun in this version so the Levels are a bonus.DLC? Not interested, but, hey! Check out the Unleashed Project which is completely free, and replaces all the levels in the game with the levels from Sonic Unleashed! Go get it...The game overall is a 9/10, a few things could be removed, and others added...One last thing, I should Thank a Special Friend who gifted this game. So, Thank You very much (You know who you are).

content:
Posted: January 6, 2014
												Incredible sense of speed and velocity, Sonic Generations is everything Unleashed hoped to be.Where Sonic games tend to punish you for being "Too Fast", Generation rewards you more the faster you go, but it's up to you wether you're quick enough to react.The goal stays the same as ever; Stay on the highest possible ground. You usually get 2-3 levels in any given stage. The lower you go, the slower you're forced to run, jumping death gaps and platforming narrow platforms, whereas if you stay high up and react quick enough to not fall down, your progress is significntly faster.Great Sonic game, and would recommend to anyone that likes platformers.

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 30, 2013
												Game: Sonic GenerationsGenre: AdventureDeveloper: Sonic Team/SEGASystem: Steam/PCTotal Score: 96/100Value Score: 9.6/10• Story: 9/10o Sonic the Hedgehog was having a birthday party with all the friends he has made in over the past couple of years. However something off in the distance a dark ominous being appeared and sucked everyone up and leaving both Sonic and Tails confused at what happened in a unknown mysterious space void. There they find themselves in a familiar location and as they traveled around they managed to find younger form of themselves. Now both Sonics and Tails will be going on a new journey to save their friends and their own respected times and worlds.• Characters: 10/10o Almost every single Sonic series hero and villain appear in this game. There are some ones who do not make an appearance but all of the major characters from the past few generations do appear. You have characters like Sonic and Tails from both the past and present, Dr. Eggman of the past and present, Amy, Shadow the hedgehog, Rouge, Knuckles and the rest from Colors, Unleashed and etc. The enemies are also the same depending on the level of which game it reflects off from. Some of the notable bosses as well from the past games also make an appearance. Sonic Generations is pretty much like a reunion for the Sonic the Hedgehog franchise.• GamePlay: 9/10o Sonic Generations plays differently from the older Sonic games. For one thing levels and stages are divided into different areas from past Sonic games and you can access them through as Classic Sonic or Modern sonic in a world map like sidescroller style. Playing as either sonic will alter the gameplay and changes the whole design of a level/stage. Classic Sonic's gameplay style is more old school 2D view while Modern Sonic's is mostly 3D view like recent Sonic games. There are three levels with each area having a mini boss and a boss at the end of the three levels. Defeating each mini boss and boss earns you a chaos emerald which is used to fight the last boss at the end of the game. Each level consists stages from different eras of Sonic - in the PC version which is the same as the home console versions, the levels and stages are included as : Classic Era - Green Hill from Sonic the Hedgehog, Chemical Plant from Sonic the Hedgehog 2 and Sky Sanctuary from Sonic the Hedgehog 3 & Knuckles. The Dreamcast era includes Speed highway from Sonic Adventure 1, City Escape from Sonic Adventure 2 and Seaside hill from Sonic Heroes. The Modern era which is the last era has Crisis City from Sonic the Hedgehog 2006, Rooftop Run from Sonic Unleashed and Planet Wisp from Sonic Colors. The usual gameplay rules apply to both modern and classic sonic - collecting rings and racing your way towards the exit marker at the end of the stage after avoiding all sorts of enemies and obstacles. For Modern sonic you can super speed dash upon a limitation bar which can be increased by collecting rings while classic sonic mainly plays like the old Sonic games with little to no difference. The level designs for each type is completely different even though it may be in the same stage. You have the usual power ups such as invincibility, shields which range from the regular green shield, the electric shield which absorbs rings, the fire ring which can make Sonic shoot like a fireball and the water shield which Sonic can use to breathe underwater or to have a extra bounce. Upon completing stages you will get access to additional missions which base around the level of where these missions are located (which is above each level entrance). These missions also vary depending on which Sonic you play as and will have a different requirement or goal as well which can range from completing a level, fighting/competing with a rival, collecting certain number of rings or simply surviving amongst other things. Completing these missions will earn you a point towards the achievement of completing all the missions and allows you to unlock a artwork or a music track which can be used optionally on other stages. Red stars also make an appearance in which goes towards your achievement scoring and is counted towards the completion of the game. A new feature introduced to the Generations game is the ability to buy power ups or abilities which can be equipped upon purchase with a limitation on how many you can equip by the number of points it requires compared to how many you have in total. Abilities and power ups range from simple power ups depending on certain situations happening automatically, the inclusion of new speed abilities or the ability to protect yourself with some bonuses such as keeping a few rings even after taking a hit instead of losing all your rings. There's also a special room where you can go and check on character profiles, listen to the game's OST or to even look at some promotional artwork designed for the game. The online feature of the game introduces you to a competitive circuit where you are forced to do a level and are ranked by the time and score upon completion which then gets displayed in a leader boards for bragging rights.• Graphics: 10/10o Sonic Generations use a new style of visual design and fluidity for its cutscenes however the in gameplay seems to be similar to what you would expect see in a HD version of Sonic Colors and of Sonic the Hedgehog 4. The new cutscenes seem reminiscent of a typical western influenced platformer which isnt a bad thing. The visual designs for the characters look great especially on the older versions of characters. The environments re-done from past Sonic games look incredible with the new style and brings a whole new depth to whatever the player had imagined beforehand in the past games. There are some slow down and FPS drops but that is only because you would need a stronger CPU than what is recommended but by not that much and not very noticeable.• Sound: 10/10o Sonic Generations have managed to keep majority of the voice overs for their characters from all eras including the eras without voice overs are nicely done and you can tell the difference in the quality/type of voice. However even though Sonic doesnt talk might be a bad thing - what was worse is the fact that Shadow and Rouge's voice actors were changed but it isnt bad to the extent where they sound completely off. The sound effects which were made famous in the older sonic games and all of the other games make a complete return.• Music: 10/10o Sonic Generations consists of a mixture of old classic tracks, original tracks from modern games and remixes of all of the songs with a bit of new tracks exclusive to the game. The remixes are actually quite well made and some of them are even BETTER than the originals. Another nice thing that they added is the ability to change the music when you play in a stage. Simply upon clicking to start on a stage change the music to whatever you have unlocked via playing missions.• Length: 9/10o Sonic Generations although might seem a bit short but it takes a lot of time and dedication to get all the red stars, perfect score points upon completion and to get every single music/artwork unlocked. At the most you will complete at least 12-15 hours on a straight way playthrough with minimal missions completed. For a platformer that is a pretty decent amount since most platformers are usually done within 7-10 hours.• Replay Value: 10/10o Sonic Generations most powerful aspect is possibly its replay value aspect. With the ability to play in over 50 different stages over the choice of 7+ maps that seems to be a pretty hefty amount considering if you add the mini bosses and the bosses you fight along the way along with some of the things you need to collect such as Red stars which will eventually make you play through the levels multiple times.

												2D Sonic done right.3D Sonic done right.Amazing reiterations of Sonic music in an orchestrial tone.Story is dumb, but you can skip it all.Boss fights are lacking, but still kinda fun.Challenges to keep you busy.Graphics done extremely well.All the levels are rehashed directly from old Sonic games in 2D and 3D. The level design is spot on.Sega finally make a fantastic game that left me wanting more! It's a shame that there is exclusive content on the 3DS version, because I really want to play more retro levels in the style that is Sonic Generations.If you like Sonic, you'll love Generations.

number of helpful: 8 of 16 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 30, 2014
												Sonic Generations. A title that is really good, and has a lot of replay value, but it really... understates its welcome? It has a (slightly) diverse range of remade levels from past games, and both Sonics control beautifully, but it's pretty damn short, and $50 is honestly just overpriced. But when I say replay value, I MEAN IT. It has lots of stuff to collect, including concept art for Sonic games from the past, and even MUSIC from Sonic games from the past! The levels always leave something new for every playthrough, first or not, and keep you playing over and over again. The remixes used for levels are downright AWESOME, and the bosses provide a fair challenge while not being too overly frustrating- very rarely do I ever rage-quit because of a boss. Overall, it makes its place well in the Sonic franchise, and it's an amazing 20th anniversary title. However, the story is so simplistic that it's almost bland, and it just screams missed opportunities. But it does have, yep, a modding community! You can download and play a diverse range of mods that can have new stages, characters, bosses... anything, really! Overall, it's a good game, but a bit overpriced. I recommend it to Sonic fans old and new. Heck, even if you're not a fan of Sonic, just give this game a go. You might end up loving it!

content:
Posted: August 30, 2016
												A wonderful blend of Classic and Modern Sonic, combining and utilizing the mechanics of both while traveling through 9 zones based on Sonic titles, as well as 90 challenge maps based on those levels, plus four boss fights.Pros and Cons+Amazing music+Gorgeous visuals in motion+Great variety in level themes+Fantastic gameplay if you can get into it, but Sonic goes VERY FAST-Stability issues in win 10-Learning curve can be more frustrating to new players than you'd expect-No levels from Sonic 3 or Sonic CD, boo!-And then Sonic is hurled off a cliffThis game is essentially a road-map to effectively pursuing user nostalgia. Playing Modern Sonic in Classic Sonic levels rendered in HD makes you wistful for what could be, and vice versa.

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 30, 2013
												Sonic Generations is definately one of the best Sonic games since Sonic Adventure 2! Its a mix of the old games (Sonic the Hedgehog) with the new ones (Unleashed), and has a great value not only for the Sonic lovers, but specially for nostaligic gamers. Most of the levels played with the "old" sonic will imediatelly be identified by those who used to played Mega Drive's Sonic games! The graphics are beautiful, and the musics, like the rest of the game, its a mix of old (but eternal) tunes but also new ones! The only negative point in this game is its really weak graphic optimization. You better have a really good computer, or your game will run full of crashes and low frame-rates.Anyway, it's a really good game, really worth the price!

content:
Posted: August 4, 2014
												==WARNING==Before I start, I played through this game fully, I have completed around 2/3's of the side missions, and I have not gotten a lot of the red rings. I also used a XBOX 360 controller, so I don't know how the keyboard plays. I've played this in the past and have good knowledge about this community and past games, with that out of the way, lets get to the review!==WARNING==Good homage to all past sonic games, great music (as usual), brilliant level design, and great boss and rival battles, basically and argueably, the best sonic game since Ye ole days.I've been a big fan of sonic's games, weither it would be the OG trilogy, the Storybook saga, the wii and wii u games (colours, unleashed, lost world), and even (some) the spin-offs. and I can safely say this game can hold up to the standards of the prestigous sonic installments.The gameplay is silky smooth with eye candy graphics, Classic Sonic takes a blast to the past with ol' fashioned controls and mechanics, while Modern Sonic offers a Z-axis for all of you fancy people (me included), and new mechanics such as the lovely Boost that everyone can't keep their thumb off of your choice of key binding. Lovely gameplay just lovely.The Music is extremely well done as always so I won't dabble a lot in this part of the review, even the remixes are enjoyable! (proceeds to sing Escape From the City WOOOO).The Levels are well done complete with alternate paths, well placed traps and enemies, and those lovely red rings. yaaaaaaaay. With redesigns of popular places from the sonic universe such as the iconic Green Hill Zone, my only complaint is the devil stage that somehow came from the dreaded '06, (cringes) Crisis City, personally to me the hardest acts in the game, atleast it has good music! (everyone and their ears cheer!). Bosses are great, my favorite being Perfect Chaos. (I LOVE Sonic Adventure, except Big the Cat, why was he even created?!) Anyways, the bosses are great, but I can see why some people complain about them being too easy, The rival battles are one of the most enjoyable parts about this game, especially the battle with Shadow, LIVE AND LEARN. To sum it up Level design is pretty good.The cutscenes are also well done, seeing both Sonics and the Eggmans interacting was both humorous and enjoyable. ( I need a loop of Classic Sonic trying to do the homing attack, don't ask why).Heres a quick check listPros- levels are good and well thought out (Bosses and Rivals included)- gameplay is silky smooth- Music is amazing as always- graphics are eye candy, along with memorable and vibrant enviornments- oh and a great modding community- Get this, Side missions (Especially Modern Sonic's) ARE ACTUALLY FUN THIS TIME AROUND!- the Collectibles are well-worth getting if you love sonic music.Cons- I can see why people don't like the bosses- Crisis City- (for me) the red rings, but they're optional- Classic Sonic is over-SHADOWed by Modern Sonic In my opinionI'm not giving a numeric rating so I'm ending with thisI really enjoyed this game! \m/(>.<)\m/ Rock on, or should I say, Run on!

												A time paradox many people love.  I can simply summarize this game as a vision of nostalgia reflecting on where Sonic came from and how far Sonic has come.What I think is awesome is the ability to play through stages that are reminiscent of the games of yester-year as Modern Sonic, yet being able to play through the games of today as Classic Sonic.  Really nice experience.   However, the final battle is truly lacking....Downsides?  I've experienced slowdown during cutscenes which ruins the voice synchronization of Sonic and Tails.  There are also some moments during the game where the controls will be unresponsive during a few critical moments.  Pits Ahoy!!!!This made me remember how good Sonic used to be.  Very nice experience.

number of helpful: 2 of 5 people (40%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 1, 2014
												TL;DR:  If you already like Sonic games, this is an easy recommendation.  If you're new to the series or not well-informed, this is a great way to see what you've been missing.  I've had this one for a little while.  Since I accidentally deleted my save when I screwed up my graphics settings, I decided to give this game another go-through.  Once again I'll mention the Sonic bundle on Steam.Sonic Generations is both a new game and an anthology of sorts.  It's Sonic's birthday (and this was Sonic's 20th anniversary as of the year it was released), and this mysterious Time Eater thing kidnaps everyone and takes them to this white void where time stands still...and where familiar locales are also present.  And it is in this white space where Sonic meets his past self.  What is the Time Eater, and why has it stolen all of these Zones away?  Gameplay in Sonic Generations is split between two characters, Classic Sonic and Modern Sonic.  Classic Sonic plays much like he does in the Genesis games.  He doesn't have the Homing Attack, but he can Spindash, and most of his gameplay is focused on sidescrolling platforming.  His stages are "2½D" in that even though the course can turn and bend, he still really only follows two planes.  This is most evident in some parts of Sky Sanctuary.  Modern Sonic plays like a cross between the day stages of Sonic Unleashed and Sonic Colors.  He lacks the Spindash but he has a Boost Meter powered by rings and defeated enemies for a nigh-invulnerable surge of speed, his Homing Attack returns, he grinds on rails, he can quickly move to the side or drift for a hard turn, he does tricks off of ramps for more Boost, and he has some 2D sections too, though there are a few 3D platforming sections.  Both characters need to get to the end of their respective Acts to clear the Zones.  The game is split into three sections representing three eras of Sonic:  Classic, Dreamcast, and Modern, and each section has three Zones and are guarded by a boss that comes from that era.  Every Zone has two Acts, one for each Sonic.  Just clearing the Acts isn't enough to progress to the boss however--clearing all six Acts for the era unlocks Challenge Gates for every Zone in that era.  To get the three keys to unlock the boss door, every Zone in that era needs to have just one Challenge Gate cleared (and you need to physically go get the key from the hub world too).  It doesn't matter which Sonic completes which Gate, so long as each Zone has one clear to its name.  And this isn't even enough to open the final area.  The Chaos Emeralds are once again given to you through gameplay, though they're mostly given for boss battles.  And in each era, there are Rival Battles where Sonic faces off with an era-relevant hedgehog.Even though this is a "greatest hits" of sorts for Sonic, the returning Zones aren't copy-and-pasted rehashes of old locales, and they're more like remixes with plenty of callbacks to old features, even if they aren't represented as Zones in this game.  Green Hill Act 1 has the corkscrews from Emerald Hill, the spinning top platforms from Marble Garden get a makeover for Sky Sanctuary Act 1, the street boarding section from City Escape is greatly expanded, and the Mad Convoy section in that Zone returns...with a vengeance.  The returning bosses also get amped up, so old tactics won't work as well this time around.  But this is the perfect opportunity to mention the Skill Shop, a shop set in the hub world where you can use the points for clearing Acts to buy skills to customize each Hedgehog.  While there aren't very many to start, you can unlock more by clearing challenges or beating the game.  The issue is then keeping the cost of all of the skills below 100, which can be pretty tricky since naturally the more powerful ones cost more.  And yes, Super Sonic in stages returns, but you'll have to clear the game first and it'll take up all 100 of your skill points to use.  What I LikedThere's a lot of content here, though if you want to blow through it all, you can probably go from start to finish in a few hours no problem.  If you're a completionist though, look out.  Clearing every Act and boss fight is just to get to the end of the game--can you finish every Challenge Gate?  Get all of the Red Rings scattered through both Acts of every Zone?  S-rank every Act?  S-rank every Challenge Gate?  Getting Red Rings will unlock artwork in the Collection Room to the far left of the hub world, and every cleared Challenge Gate will have a bell to ring, which releases a music note you have a short amount of time to chase down and collect which will reward you with either more artwork or music to listen to in the Collection Room.  Said Collection Room also has a section to review character profiles and rewatch the movies from the game if you want.  I can safely say when I do a review of a Sonic game, I'm going to mention the music.  This game is no exception, and I really liked how both Sonics had a variation of the same theme for each Zone, much like how the music for most Sonic games starting with Sonic 3 did.  Better yet, all of the music you collect through the Challenge Gates and Red Rings can be used for the music for whatever Act or boss fight before you begin.  If you want to fight the final boss to Green Hill Zone, you're free to!  You'll just need to unlock them first.  The hub world also has its own spin on the Zone or boss music when you're near the entrance, so that's a nice touch.  There is a level of polish here I could appreciate.  Consider you free one of Sonic's friends for completing a Zone's two Acts.  The comments they each say differ depending on which Sonic was the second one, though most comment about Classic Sonic looking different than the one they're used to.  One of the movies is also different depending on which Sonic you're using, though unfortunately there's no way to view the "other side" version of it or hear the other friend responses without starting a new game and erasing your old save (or you can back it up first, naturally).  What I Didn't LikeGetting hit in this game is an exercise in frustration.  Both Sonics tend to do the "dazed for a second" thing that started in Sonic Heroes, though there's a skill to negate that.  The big issue I had was that the rings are especially difficult to grab once they've flown out.  Classic Sonic is stuck to the 2D plane but it seems like the rings aren't, and a few times it seems like Modern Sonic's rings were just fake trying to pick them back up.  There aren't any shields in this game (except as skills for Classic Sonic), and while you only drop a portion of your rings when hit if you have enough, just trying to retain those last few can make survival a bit of a challenge.  I honestly didn't like how there was so little mention of the handheld titles apart from a small handful of songs from the Gameboy Advance and Playstation Portable games.  This is more of a personal issue, but I grew up with a Game Gear and never owned a Sega home console, and it's a little disappointing how all of those games just got glossed over.  For as popular as Sunset Park Act 3's unique theme is, even it didn't get a remix here.  Sad.  My rig chugged at a few times, but that's not something I can really hold against the game.  It doesn't scream "bad port" like some games, but if you're looking to buy this, make absolutely sure you have a good enough machine.In Closing...This will be a nostalgia trip for many.  For those like me where it isn't, there's still a lot of fun and enjoyment to be had here.  Can't complain about the controls, and while a game clear won't take very long, 100%ing this game will keep you busy for a while.  Casino Nights DLCYou can probably skip this unless you really have a hankering for hedgehog-themed pinball.

content:
Posted: November 11, 2011
												It's an enjoyable game with some frustrating mechanics and really, really, really cheesy CGI movies (like pretty much all Sonic games). The graphics are sharp, detailed and colorful, the sounds are nice and the voice overs are terrible. The gameplay itself is pretty fun, especially when playing as Young Sonic. The Old Sonic sequences reminded me of Sonic Adventure. They're, most of the times, fast and there are some cool chasing scenes in them as well. The bossfights, well, they're frustrating, especially the ones where you have to beat a rival. The last 2 bossfights can also be really frustrating. But there's fun to had as well of course. You just have to ignore some of the poorer mechanics.All in all, it's a good game, just don't play it for hours and hours and you'll be fine.[Rating: 73/100]

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 17, 2014
												In just a few words, this game is amazing and worth a buy!Why?Well, first of all it is the first "Unleashed Sonic" game for the PC and that alone made me buy this game.Oh and do you remember the Classic Sonic? The one from the Mega Drive/ Genesis games? Yeah, he's here too!This game is basically a "Time Travel" type of game, because the modern and the classic Sonic meet and go through some old Stages (from previous Sonic Games) and each Sonic has it own style of gameplay!Classic Sonic plays like the old Sonic games, and that's awesome because there were a LOT of people complaining because the new Sonic games did not look like the originals.Modern Sonic plays like Sonic in "Sonic Unleashed" and "Sonic Colors", and I think that I don't need to say anything more.Technically, this game is amazing, it runs at Full 60 Fps, so it's smooth as butter, and that's always nice... right? Yeah, it is!Graphically, this game is gorgeus, Sonic Team did an amazing job turning 2D Classic Stages into fully 3D Stages with jaw dropping environments!And I must not forget the Soundtrack, OH GOD! THE SOUNDTRACK! Once again they did an amazing job recreating songs from past games for this game! I can listen to the Classic City Escape song all day long!Now for the bad part. For me the game was too easy and I could beat it in less of a day, but there's an HUGE dificulty spike (at least for me) between Rooftop Run and Planet Wisp. Planet Wisp was a pain in the butt for me (both Classic and Modern)!There's also a ... bug? Yeah, let's call it bug. There's also a bug in the Ranking mode, that I experienced both on console and in my computer. Whenever you play a stage, the game will not save your time in the leaderboards. Although this is not a HUGE thing for me, it's something that I think they should fix.But Overall, I think this game is worth a buy, even if you have the console version of this game!Even though I have the Ps3 version, I bought the Pc version, because it plays at Full 60Fps, it's compatible with many resolutions and we must not forget the giant and great Modding Comunity for this game (and specially the Unleashed Project, that allows you to play all of Sonic's Unleashed Day Stages in Sonic Generations).Final Veridict:Buy it now! (Or the Sonic Hits Collection, because it's really worth the money)9/10

content:
Posted: November 15, 2015
												The Positive:+Great level design+Great gameplay+Awesome game for speedruns+Great soundtrack+Achievements+Leaderboards+Good port, runs well+Dedicated community for creating modsThe okay:*The story is fine but nothing specialThe Negative:-Transitioning from a section of a stage to another section might cause lag in some levels (especially chemical plant) -No trading cards-No PvP which is a big disappointement (the 3DS version has it tough)  -For some reason the PC version is lacking the game Sonic the Hedgehog, present in the consoles-The game is short (would have a reasonable lenght with more 3 stages perhaps)Final thoughts: Sonic Generations is no doubt a great game but leaves a lot to wish for, especially PvP and game lenght.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 15, 2015
												Since Sonic Adventure on the dreamcast I haven't enjoyed a single Sonic game thats been released, until now...This is a true fan service game featuring remastered versions of some of the best levels from the entire series while playing as 2 different versions of Sonic.Each level lets you play as either classic or modern Sonic, classic plays as a side scroller while modern plays like Sonic unleashed (without the silly werehog sections). The game runs at an eye watering pace (especially modern Sonic) and theres multiple routes and secret tokens hidden throughout each stage, getting them all will take some time.Aside from the main story, which should take the average player 6+ hours to complete, theres over 100 challenges to complete too. Beating these challenges unlocks bonus content such as character models, classic music and artwork.If your a fan of the Sonic series then this is a must buy, its simply the best Sonic game in years by far.

content:
Posted: July 30, 2014
												This game. This freaking game. This game is now the quintessential Sonic game. The levels are fun, the music is awesome, and the game is challenging enough and has enough content to keep players coming back for more. I only have a few bad things to say about it. First, the cutscenes often lag for me (it might just be my computer though). Second, Crisis City exists and is harder than I expected (that other sonic game we don't talk about got erased from the timeline! How is there a level from it?). Third, while the design and music for the final boss is awesome, it is...disappointing. For most players it is either too hard or too easy. Overall, despite a few shortcomings, any gamer who considers themselves a Sonic fan needs this game. Seriously. Buy it now.Also, Silver never once says it's no use and SHADOW DOESN'T HAVE GUNS!

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 26, 2012
												Sonic Generations is a Sonic game.Wait! Don't leave. I know that's come to mean a vastly different thing than it used to, but Sonic Generations has shown me that different no longer means bad. An interesting duality-based game, SG proves that the 3D Sonic formula can and does work and it shows you time and time again that when something works, it is beautiful.So it's kind of a shame that after finishing the first six stages, the entire thing kind of says "♥♥♥♥ it" and decides to become mediocre. The 2D sonic stages become horrific timesink chores and the 3D sonic stages lose a bit of their shine.(Sonic Colors stage, please go die somewhere)In addition, the boss fights range from awesome to awful and some of them are downright broken. That doesn't mean you shouldn't get the game, though. Far from it. I find Sonic Generations a great game with some awful flaws, which is a pretty good analogy for Sonic The Hedgehog in general.At $50 or $60 I would have felt cheated, but I think anything under $30 is a decent price for a Sonic game with a good amount of content, a lot of new ideas, and a whole lot of heart (it's even got some decent writing!).I award this game 8.5/10 Bumpers

content:
Posted: July 18, 2013
												A game made for the 20th anniversary of the lightning fast blue hedgehog. It's a game made for the fans, but also a good game to introduce newcomers into the Sonic universe. This game puts both Classic Sonic from the 2D and Genesis games, and Modern Sonic from post-Sonic Adventure in 3D. Each level is a level from a past game, all remastered in HD, with completely new designs for both 2D and 3D gameplay. The game controls splendidly for a Sonic game. The graphics are just amazing to look at, pleasing the eyes. The music is all remixed and given a new feel, complimenting the level perfectly. You're even to change the music with music you've unlocked by collecting special Red Rings and beating Challenge Missions. This game is extremely fun, with an equal amount of platforming and blasting through the level. Recommend this to both fans and people who want to get into the series. 8.5/10

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 21, 2013
												Sonic Generations is a double-shot throwback to the classic Sonic that we knew in the cheap day-cares that attempted to make kids want to stay there, to the light-speed Dreamcast Sonic whose coolness shamed the ice caps. It's been ten years since I've played a Sonic game worth playing, and the 3DS version alone was good enough, but Sonic Generations for the PC (or a console, if you still think they're the pinnacle of gaming) gives hope that the blue blur can still be as great as his glory days. The game has stages from the classics and the times when I cried at how Sonic just wasn't the same, but all of them are fun, and you definitely have a little bit of an edge if you've played a stage on an original game that may be featured in this. On that note, the G.U.N. truck was a bit nasty back in SA2. Here, it's VICIOUS!There's a shortage of downloadable content, so far being only Casino Nights pinball, but the shortage of content is by no means a bore. Casino Nights pinball has some fun slot action from StH2 (Genesis), classic pinball feel of Sonic Spinball (Game Gear), and the... how to say... refined appeal of Casinopolis' pinball stages from Sonic Adventure (Dreamcast). Knowing what I know now of the game, I would've paid $30 to $35 for this (I'd pay more if we were given Mushroom Hill on the PC and consoles), and I'm most certainly proud to have snagged it on a $7.50 deal!

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 18, 2012
												This game has its ups and downs, to be sure.  When I first started playing, I was really enjoying myself.  The Hedgehog engine makes for beautiful scenery and the music is all incredibly well remastered.  The nostalgia-tripping was welcomed.  And then it all went to♥♥♥♥♥♥when the Sonic 2006 level came.  Granted, Sonic Unleashed had a solid level, but the 2006 and Colors levels are abysmal.  All the bosses are boring, the rival fights (save for Metal Sonic) are confusing, and the story is shoehorned.  The gameplay mechanics were fantastic in some areas but the level design throws in cheap hits just to slow you down/make you lose rings.  It's annoying, and considering Sonic is all about moving fast, it's poor level design.I don't know if Generations is Sonic's return to form, but it's definitely fun (at least, on the whole) for a good five or six hours.  And if you're a diehard fan, there's a lot more than that to keep you entertained in the challenge levels and unlockable content.

content:
Posted: December 3, 2014
												I started playing Sonic back when I had my Nintendo Gamecube a long time ago. This created a deep place and a everlasting love for the little blue guy back from a young age. When I fist played Sonic Geneartions on the PC I as confused to say the least. While the game itself looks as great as any other modern game does it the constrolls that really put me off. The game does not come with a pre set control scheme. This make mapping keys difficult especially considering that they way it goes about it is by placing an Xbox controller on your screen and makes you create keyboard alternatives for things like the A, B, X & Y buttons. This bsically just makes you realise that this game was clearly not made with the PC in mind. Despte this, if you use a controller it should work fine as long as it's an Xbox controller.In terms of the game itself asider from the bad PC controlls the game is a huge hommage to fans of Sonic as it contains all of the best, most loved Sonic maps and levels ever made. This includes both the modern and the older sonic maps.In basic terms this game is a wise investment but I'd certainly wait untl you see it on sale so you can get it cheaper. My reason for this is tht it's not that long, unless you wan't to try and get the best times for the levels then you'd spend like 30 hours on it.7/10

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 21, 2013
												Sonic Generations is a double-shot throwback to the classic Sonic that we knew in the cheap day-cares that attempted to make kids want to stay there, to the light-speed Dreamcast Sonic whose coolness shamed the ice caps. It's been ten years since I've played a Sonic game worth playing, and the 3DS version alone was good enough, but Sonic Generations for the PC (or a console, if you still think they're the pinnacle of gaming) gives hope that the blue blur can still be as great as his glory days. The game has stages from the classics and the times when I cried at how Sonic just wasn't the same, but all of them are fun, and you definitely have a little bit of an edge if you've played a stage on an original game that may be featured in this. On that note, the G.U.N. truck was a bit nasty back in SA2. Here, it's VICIOUS!There's a shortage of downloadable content, so far being only Casino Nights pinball, but the shortage of content is by no means a bore. Casino Nights pinball has some fun slot action from StH2 (Genesis), classic pinball feel of Sonic Spinball (Game Gear), and the... how to say... refined appeal of Casinopolis' pinball stages from Sonic Adventure (Dreamcast). Knowing what I know now of the game, I would've paid $30 to $35 for this (I'd pay more if we were given Mushroom Hill on the PC and consoles), and I'm most certainly proud to have snagged it on a $7.50 deal!

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 18, 2013
												A game made for the 20th anniversary of the lightning fast blue hedgehog. It's a game made for the fans, but also a good game to introduce newcomers into the Sonic universe. This game puts both Classic Sonic from the 2D and Genesis games, and Modern Sonic from post-Sonic Adventure in 3D. Each level is a level from a past game, all remastered in HD, with completely new designs for both 2D and 3D gameplay. The game controls splendidly for a Sonic game. The graphics are just amazing to look at, pleasing the eyes. The music is all remixed and given a new feel, complimenting the level perfectly. You're even to change the music with music you've unlocked by collecting special Red Rings and beating Challenge Missions. This game is extremely fun, with an equal amount of platforming and blasting through the level. Recommend this to both fans and people who want to get into the series. 8.5/10

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 26, 2012
												Sonic Generations is a Sonic game.Wait! Don't leave. I know that's come to mean a vastly different thing than it used to, but Sonic Generations has shown me that different no longer means bad. An interesting duality-based game, SG proves that the 3D Sonic formula can and does work and it shows you time and time again that when something works, it is beautiful.So it's kind of a shame that after finishing the first six stages, the entire thing kind of says "♥♥♥♥ it" and decides to become mediocre. The 2D sonic stages become horrific timesink chores and the 3D sonic stages lose a bit of their shine.(Sonic Colors stage, please go die somewhere)In addition, the boss fights range from awesome to awful and some of them are downright broken. That doesn't mean you shouldn't get the game, though. Far from it. I find Sonic Generations a great game with some awful flaws, which is a pretty good analogy for Sonic The Hedgehog in general.At $50 or $60 I would have felt cheated, but I think anything under $30 is a decent price for a Sonic game with a good amount of content, a lot of new ideas, and a whole lot of heart (it's even got some decent writing!).I award this game 8.5/10 Bumpers

Posted: March 16, 2014
												I typically agree with Metacritic regarding game ratings and scores; however, I don't with Sonic Generations. Sonic Generations is one of those games that aims for a nastalgia feel, but also aims to not only revolutionalize the Sonic series, but also try and repair it. That's exactly what this game did with it's story while still offering fun game mechanics. You have a choice to play between classic sonic in his 2D sidescrolling levels or modern sonic with his more 3D levels.This game really was amazing in all it's glory, I recommend all sonic fans give it a chance!

content:
Posted: October 8, 2014
												Sonic Generations is a pleasure to play, coming from a long-time Sonic fan. It serves as a 'love letter' of sorts to old-school Sonic fans. It is technically very unrated, with the Hedgehog Engine now being very versitile and with few bugs (in my experience) and quite a bit more polish since it's first appearance in Sonic Unleashed. The levels are rich with detail and personality, and none of the game feels rushed or cheapened. The story is forgettable and you WON'T find yourself invested in it in the slightest. SEGA definately put a lot of effort and affection into this title. In my oppinion, this game raises the bar again... But for how long...  :p

number of helpful: 2 of 6 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 15, 2014
												This game is amazing. It celebrates the highs of the Sonic franchise and acknowledges the lows. ('06). It features both Classic and Modern Sonic. Aside from the Final Boss, (and a few of Modern Sonic's missions: Vector's Rooftop Run and Charmy's Planet Wisp), every game stage, normal and mission is excellent. One of my favorite parts of this game is that they provide a whole bunch of iconic Sonic tunes for you to unlock and use as the music to the stage. The only drawback this game has is: the plot (I know) feels unfinished. They needed more cutscenes featuring character commentary on stages. (Presumably, they were cut for time.) There are nine stages: Green Hill, Chemical Plant, Sky Sanctuary, Speed Highway, City Escape, Seaside Hill, Crisis City, Rooftop Run, and Planet Wisp. Each level has a Classic and Modern level, each accompanied by five missions. (You only have to do a grand total of 9, one per unique level.) There are three bosses, and three rival fights, and your typical Super Sonic final boss at the end.The format is good. But honestly, without ANY Eggman base levels, it feels like it's the first half of a game that immediately skips to the final boss. Small Nitpick to avoid a repeat of '06.My personal picks would have been:Scrap Brain Zone (1), Metropolis Zone (2), Launch Base Zone (3), and then Aquatic Base ('06) that segways into Final Egg (Adventure). After that you get the flying ship levels, Winged Fortress, Flying Battery, and Skydeck. And then you get the Final Base. I also would have liked that they included levels with scrapped ideas from classic games like Sonic 2's Winter Zone and Rock Zone and Dust Hill Zone or Sonic CD's 8th level. (more commonly known as R2 due to CD's missing level slot.)But time constraints, I suppose cut prospective ideas like that out, I guess making it a 21st anniversary game with the slogan 'He's legally an adult now.' probably wouldn't have worked.

content:
Posted: January 6, 2015
												Incidentally enough, I bought this on an amazon sale and it so happened to be my first steam game, although I had created an empty account a few months prior. This being a Sonic game with 3D levels made relatively recently, even with the good reviews I had seen there was always that lingering concern that it would pull a Secret Rings on me- not '06 terrible (I actually haven't played that but I've heard enough)- but just not compelling, and certainly only a shadow of the original games. At times, you might find yourself wishing for a bit of that super-smooth 3 and Knuckles, as always. But Generations still delivered beyond my doubts. It's definitely the best in a long while. And the graphics are a visual feast, although sometimes even a bit overwhelming as you speed by, as the game blends 2D and 3D elements in a beautifully seamless manner. The only bad thing is the Perfect Chaos boss fight. I hate that. A lot.But yeah, it's pretty good. Easily worth 5 on a sale.

number of helpful: 2 of 6 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 16, 2014
												Sonic Generations Review by nikfanPLOT 6/10I liked the plot of this game... But it was really short and was not going anywhere! I really liked Classic and Modern Sonic as characters in this game and Time Eater was interesting before we saw the obvious reveal that the "The Time Eater" was controlled by Eggman and the Dr."PINGAS" Robotnik.GAMEPLAY 9.5/10I must say... This is maybe the most fun I've had with a Sonic Game. I think the control is near perfect, the level design is interesting and not "tunnel like". It's a saferide that will give you a lot of pleasure if you are a Classic Veteran or a Modern Veteran(I can't say this for myself... I started out with the Adventure formula... But I still get enjoyment out of Modern and Classic Sonic) But I still think(For me atleast) Modern Sonic was more enjoyable, with all the speedrunning tricks and that speed. Sega got fast with this game... GRAPHICS 9/10Graphics look really good. It looks better than Colors and is somewhere on the same level with Sonic Lost World. But it's still not as beatiful as Unleashed. But you can add Unleashed Graphics thanks to the Modding Community.MUSIC 10/10This is a soundtrack I really enjoyed. All of the tracks were enjoyable and nostalgic giving it that Anniversary feel. My favourite tracks are Sky Sanctuary(all of them), Crisis City(Act 1) and City Escape. I also really enjoy Speed Highway Act 1. That track just sounds like it should be played in a Night Club and I love it :3REPLAYABILITY 10/10When the game is pretty fun to replay and speedrun... I must say, one of the best thing about this game is the Modding Community. They work on outstanding mods and they do come out freaquently. So it's a perfect way to come back to the game and try out some awesome modifications people came up with... OVERALL SCORE: 8.5/10I really liked this game. But I wanted more from the plot...P.S: Perfect Chaos is... Awesome

content:
Posted: January 31, 2015
												Seeing as how the last Sonic game I played before this was Shadow the Hedgehog on Gamecube, this Sonic game was obviously an adjustment for me as far as game mechanics, but the changes they made to the game mechanics since StH is what made it an awesome gameplay experience for me. I love how it caters to both classic and modern Sonic fans with its two styles of gameplay. Although I prefer modern Sonic's levels, classic Sonic's levels give me a nostalgic feeling because of how similar they are to the Sega Genesis style of controlling Sonic. The modern remakes of certain levels and songs also get me nostalgic as well. And I can't forget to mention the graphics are fantastic in comparision to the Gamecube era of Sonic games. After I had beaten the storyline, the game left me with wanting more modern remakes of levels from Sonic's past. Sonic Generations is one of the best Sonic games Sega has made so far.

content:
Posted: January 13, 2015
												I never fully understood why I've always been fascinated with Sonic the Hedgehog. The classics are fun but very frustrating at times. And since modern Sonic came out, Sega has been screwing up with making quality games. They added a few annoying characters rather than memorable ones and it seems that the voice actors/actresses and lines chosen for these characters get worse and worse with each new title. Don't get me wrong, I understand it's hard to come up with new ideas and I'm sure they'll get out of the rut sometime. But at least get decent voice acting. Please.Whether you were introduced recently or around when Sonic first came out, you will love this game. It's the perfect blend of nostalgia and modern gaming combined into one. Sidescroll run as classic Sonic and listen to the jumping and rolling sounds you know and love; then play as modern Sonic and blaze through the courses with maximum speed. Each has their own unique abilities to use. Classic Sonic rolls and spin jumps and modern Sonic dashes at high speeds and has a homing attack. The music is as classic as ever; but with a modern twist thrown in that blends in perfectly for that nostalgic but modern feeling. If you aren't getting it yet, this game is very nostalgic for most people. The stages themselves are all from past Sonic games old and new. If you were hoping for brand new stage ideas however... I'm sorry to say you will not get them in this title. The story too isn't anything new for Sonic and his friends. The only cons I have are:-Short story even with side missions-First half was nothing but a blast and the second half was all the bad game stages....still fun but irritating-Not all Sonic games were referenced (Sonic Riders and Lost Rings to my knowledge)It's too bad they didn't add more memorable levels from the games like the jungle and my personal favorite with the proper introduction to Shadow the Hedgehog (Sonic Adventure 2 where it shows Maria and you start by grinding down a bridge with awesome guitar music). As much as I wish it had more, it was worth the money. I paid $7 and I would say wait for a sale of at least $15 for this game. I'd say it's worth about that. Great game!

												3 different eras, 2 Sonics, 1 epic adventure. The Best looking Sonic game for now, Sonic Generations is pure epic game where you can play as Classic Sonic and Modern Sonic. Game features a great story, gorgeous graphics, amazing soundtrack, nice gameplay. It also features 9 different levels from first to last Sonic games re-designed especially for this game. Also lot of challenges for 2 Sonics to test their different skills. By clearing stages you get points which you can spend on different upgrades. Crazy speed, jumping over obstacles, defeating different bosses, everything awaits you here. Fans will be amazed and newcomers will be blown away by unbelievable speed and different landscapes. So go grab it it's a Sonic game you musn't miss. Happy birthday Sonic, may you be with us for many later years and amaze us with your speed as always.

number of helpful: 0 of 3 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 13, 2011
												Do you feel that the Sonic franchise is obsolete or dead? Sonic Generations may change your mind. By combining both worlds: side-scrolling platforming with speed elements and full out 3D speed segments with minor amounts of platforming, Sonic Generations has managed to create something fresh amongst the billions of indie platformers and first-person shooters.If you used to be a fan of the series, the general setting of the game may be of interest to you. Essentially, Sonic's sent back through time to revisit iconic levels in the flagship titles with some new twists. This time however, the perspective is skewed to two different angles. Each bring up a "What if" scenario with the game's release date and design. Classic Sonic turns the level into an early 90s platformer, questionably the music as well. Modern Sonic on the other hand, shows the level if it was made and designed around the last couple of Sonic games (the good parts, not the bad). It's a short game, but cheap. Try it.

content:
Posted: July 4, 2013
												in this co-op 2-player platform-em-up, you can play as either Sonic or the Son of Sonic as you jump, dodge and roll your way to several stages inspired by earlier Sonic games. all the way from Green Hills Zone (you might remember this from Sonic Adventure 2, where it was a secret level!!!) to The Floating Sanctuary (one of Knuckle's stages in Sonic Adventure Director's Xut) or even the mysterious Crying Cities (from the smash hit Sonic The 2005, the game which represented the blue bombers breakthrough in the West), this game is sure to tingle your nostalgia senses. the gameplay is stellar, for the most part - all the parts where you play as Sonic are great, but playing as the Son of Sonic is sometimes a little slow, which is strange since sonic is about going fast. more imporntantly, the plot is marvellous - it borrows heavily from games such as Nier, as the narrative mostly focuses on Sonic's relationship with his son, the Son of Sonic.Sadly, you can not play as Shamwow the ♥♥♥♥♥♥. this is a definite flaw.SCOREA graphic: 4/10 (some of the level designs look outdated)Speed: 50% (the Son of Sonic is not as fast due to being tiny bby hadgehog)Rings: this game has'emMusicals: 7/10 (i would have liked to hear some more classic sonic tunes such as "Knuckles Pumpkin Song" or "Knuckle's Water Level Song"TOTAL SCOREY-

content:
Posted: November 9, 2016
												Generations is generally considered to be one of the better new Sonic games, but I have no idea why.  The controls are sluggish, the level design is a linear tightrope with perpetual deathdrops if you deviate from preset path, the game puts more emphesis on 'tricks' than anything else.  Sonic games used to be great.  This one, it goes through the motions but I didn't have any fun at all.  If you want a good Sonic game, pick up one of the original Genesis ones, which are also on Steam.

content:
Posted: January 11, 2016
												+ Looks nice+ Main stages are mostly enjoyable- I can't go 10 minutes without the camera getting stuck behind the geometry, Sonic getting stuck in momentum going back and forth on a loop-de-loop, some other graphical glitch, or the game crashing.- Control inputs just don't work some of the time. Multiple times a stage the jump button doesn't register and that's a problem.- Challenge stages are mandatory to unlock the boss fight after you finish the main areas for that chapter. This wouldn't be THAT big of a problem if the challenge stages weren't shoddy modes that played poorly.- The level select is needlessly complicated. It's shocking how difficult it is to just find they keys you maybe unlocked from the challenge rooms and the challenges that correspond to any of the 3 keys in each chapter. I shouldn't be getting frustrated trying IN THE LEVEL SELECT! Unbelievable the only part I would need a guide is the MENU. That's just terrible design.The negatives absolutely crush what's good about this game. As is I can't recommend it.

content:
Posted: July 14, 2012
												Not only a solid return to form for the high-octane hog, there's also plenty of meat on it's bones with many stages, bosses and various challenges to complete, along with unlocking new skills and content along the way.   Less a mere franchise addition, more a full-blown trumpeting tribute to Sega's previously mistreated mascot - and it pulls it off with aplomb.A stonking soundtrack, sporting a great many classic tunes, both remixed and originals from previous games, tops off a gorgeous, colour drenched platformer that caters for both explorative, find all the secrets play to simply tearing through the stages at as ball-blistering a speed as possible.    Great stuff.

content:
Posted: February 17, 2012
												Sonic's first comeback since the games on the Sonic Heroes Engine (games like Shadow The Hedgehog Sonic Riders 2: Zero Gravity and of course Sonic Heroes) you play as Modern Sonic and Sonic from the years of Sonics 1 to just before Sonic Adventure (not sure what game it is) it's fairly short at 9 stages and two acts for eatch stage for you to play as Sonic and his younger self and 6 bosses (5 if you don't include the final boss) In Sonic Generations you play most of Sonic's best stages (i mean best because there are some stages that arn't there that are good like Cool Edge stage in Sonic Unleashed and metel harbour for Sonic Adventure 2 and even emarald Coast from Sonic Adventure but rooftop run is good enough). This version of Generations doesn't have everything unfortunitly. The only thing it doesn't have is the meggadrive emulator for Sonic 1 but since the PC already has a few genesis emulators who cares? Also theres a little suprise in intro for the final boss.Also the community has forced modding into this game (i think) and there are already a set of awesome mods from rendering patches like FX Pipeline to the Unleashed project and even Unleashed Sonic Himself (mostly the Unleashed Sonic model has a few animation glitches here and there, although they are mostly in-game cinimatic issues.)Also this game is good to play when your feeling stressed, sad or possibly angry since the music makes you feel better and the gameplay brings you back into the real world, even though the game is (like basically all the 3D Sonic games) one of the easiest games i have ever played, although that isn't a bad thing but the chalanges also mix things up a little, you have a few perk-based chalanges (the one i liked the most was the Endless Bost chalange) aswell as your generic "beat your doppleganger" chalangers (and no before you ask it isn't a modern version of Metal Sonic unfortunitly.)Also as i mentioned earlier this game has a few perks which can be small things like giving a free boost at the begining of a stage if you hit your boost key at the right time, extending boost bar and/or giving a regenerate boost bar, to perks which speed you up and reduce the speed penalties from going up slopes or running in water, and even some OP or semi-OP perks like Time Break (which *SPOILER* the final boss uses) and Super Sonic which have perks and cons like with Super Sonic you can fly while you boost and your invincible but you lose rings overtime (which would be obvious if you played as Super Sonic or any super form in any Sonic game) and boosting drains your rings faster, and Time Break slows down the game time (including Sonic which gives you more time to react and can be useful at times) but the stop watch still runs at normal time or faster making Time Break only useful when going back through the stages for the emblem Red Rings.

number of helpful: 1 of 7 people (14%) found this review helpful3 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: September 5, 2016
												Mediocre game at best in my opinion, I played for as long as I could, I quit when I found out that you are guaranteed to lose the Silver fight if you don't have enough boost.Here are my main issues with Modern Sonic and his levels-For some reason there are two sets of controlls for moving side to side, there's the analog controls which steers you in that direction, and then there's the left and right bumpers that move you over to that direction.But you are still required to use the analog controlls in order to move forward, while still having the wonky steering controls attached to it, making it easy to go off course and die.-If you are going faster than walking speed, you have no time to react to anything in front of you unless you know what's going to happen beforehand, this wouldn't be so bad if it didn't lead to losing lives very frequently.-Bashing into a flying enemy can often lead to you just fall to your death if it was so much as an inch away from it's top height.-There are a lot of sections where you're expected to either to slow down extremely or stop entirely in order to do some platforming, neither of course becomes apprent until you smack into it and lose your rings/die.-You're never fully explained what anything does or what button you're suppose to press.-Sometimes mechanics are introduced with no explanation at all.As the game goes on it becomes clear less and less thought was put into levels as development increased, parts where a jump stops right in front of an enemy for you to slide into become more and more frequent, long stretches of road that lead straight directly into spikes are more common, level desgin as a whole gets worse as you progress.I havn't tried to play this with a keyboard because the game comes with no key binds for keyboards, it asks you to select keys binds for each button on a controller, which sounds awful.I'm sure if you're willing to put up with floaty controls, imprecise movement, and horrible level desgin, you'll enjoy this game better than I did.
