content:
Posted: August 5, 2015
												This game was meant as a kind of museum to sonic's history, but seeing as it's sonic mausoleum is much better description. A broken relic of sega's need to be edgy and beat nintendo. Seriously the controls are floaty and the platforming is terrible, speed as a central mechanic is also completely ridiculous, platformers require prescision and forethought but how are you supposed to do that when slightly tapping in any direction sends you careening off the edge of a platform. It succeeds in being a look back at Sonic's history and if that's what you want go for it but if you've gained some common sense and lost the rose tinted glasses then avoid this monstrosity that can only be described as an old, drunk out of shape Sonic wanking in a mirror

number of helpful: 7 of 20 people (35%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 20, 2015
												Biggest issue for me is that Classic levels, which were the main reason for me to buy the game, are incredibly boring. They have absolutely no flow, very far from that perfect mix of speed and platforming of the Genesis classics, and they also lack uniqueness aside from a couple of gimmicks. I also experienced a weird issue with the controls of Classic Sonic: attempting the ground roll sometimes just randomly stops your momentum (instead of enhancing it) and some other times just... doesn't work.I surprisingly found myself enjoying way more the Modern levels: overall they are fine, but I think SA2 is probably the better choice if you want that kind of gameplay (disclaimer: I'm saying this but I don't know if the PC port's any good, I played it on Dreamcast several years ago).The extra "Challenge" levels are ridiculously repetitive, every single one I tried basically was "repeat a portion of the level you just played with no challenge whatsoever, but oh wait here's a totally irrelevant gimmick that'll make you think you're doing something different". Spoiler alert: you won't be doing anything different.It's just really mediocre overall and not worth its full price, although I'd recommend it on a sale if you're a diehard Sonic fan.

number of helpful: 3 of 12 people (25%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 16, 2015
												Basically, except the "remastered" core 2D gameplay and a few good music tracks, everything here is between "mildly irritating" and "batshit awful". 3D-Sonic levels suffer from little to none playtesting, and so are flooded with both technical and design missteps. This situation tops at bosses -- they annoy and bore at the same time, and are completely screwed up with bugs. By the way, "annoying and boring" is also true about cutscenes -- I can't call them a story, it's just that -- and every single character, both Sonics included (yep, the "old" Sonic does alright with being unbearable and mute at once).That said, gameplay is not brilliant at all. Levels for 2D-Sonic are mostly okay, although they suffer from several strange design decisions. Favorite case -- signs for death pits placed in such manner they rather mock your fatal error than give valuable info. Ironically, 2D-sections for 3D-Sonic (oh yeah, his levels aren't 100% 3D, with constant frustrating shifts of perspective) might play somewhat better because of "modern" Sonic's moves serving as last chance of escaping stupid death. If you won't step into another glitch, of course.But all could be forgiven (or tolerated) if the assets are great. Well, first of all, there are not much of them: only nine locations, each from a different series' entry, and each divided between two Sonics -- 18 levels, plus horrible bosses (and a miriad of challenge missions that reuse main levels). Decent amount, but certainly not a great nostalgic trip to all the places of glory. I don't give a damn about modern Sonic games, so I don't particularly hate them -- but only one location per each of the first three games? Come on already. That just doubles the bad taste from poor QA.All in all, too much of a ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t for a few good moments. If this is the "best Sonic game since Sonic & Knuckles" as some internet folks say, all the others must've been flat out horrible.

content:
Posted: May 21, 2016
												The game is great, the levels are a lot of fun and there are always new events taking place that pull me in further, however, I've got to say that this game was incredibly lazily ported to PC. All of the prompts tell the player to push the XBOX equivalent controls, and the controls are awful! The game tells you to push the Y button when you need to be pressing "W" on a keyboard. You can't reassign the controls either, which annoyed me to no end. You WILL die many times because of the fact that the game will tell you to quickly push certain buttons at certain times and you won't know what the game is referring to. Other than the fact that the game is a very lazy port, it's a good game, but I haven't been so annoyed with a games controls in quite a while. I would recommend buying it for the console it was released on, certainly not on PC.

Posted: July 24, 2016
												This is probably the best Sonic game of all time, however, that isn´t saying much.I can´t stress this enough. This is a Sonic game. If you buy a Sonic game, it´s because you want to go fast. I shouldn´t have to wait for a platform to come back or for the level event to end to continue moving. If I wanted to do that, I could´ve easily bought a Mario game. Some levels are extremely long, and horribly paced, and at times when you want to go fast, the game will simply not allow it by placing an enemy that, unless you´ve played the same level over and over again (seriously, this game borderlines on trial and error, a lot), you won´t see coming, stoping you dead on your tracks.I´d recommend it if you´re a hardcore Sonic fan, and if you can deal with bad level design. And yes, the music is great, as usual.Also, why is this 2011 game so hard to run? Barely any graphic setting and no real way to adjust them. It´s not really well optimized.

Posted: July 14, 2016
												This is not a Sonic game.I grew up with the original Sonic games and the GBA Sonic advance series.What made them good includes:+Fluid controls+Easy to get speed back after a failure+Not jumping up tiny pointless ledgesThis game is none of that. The 2.5D to 3D feels nausiating and 'little Sonic' is like a fat kid chasing after an ice-cream truck. It feels sluggish.The port is horrible. Cutscenes are in 480p24 (or 30, not sure) and the voice acting is... Not terrible surprisingly. The control scheme IS NOT AUTOMATIC (!!!!) and requires you to map buttons to certain keypad stuff on your keyboard. There is a "default" button but it isn't the default. No idea why. Everything starts unmapped.There are no options for above 1080p60, so no 120Hz or 1440p for you unfortunately.Worst part of my experience was that ♥♥♥♥ing tutorial bot. I could have survived if it weren't for "PRESS X TO GO FAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAST"It all feels forced. I did not enjoy the experience.(For reference I've also played +2 hours at a friends house on his TV. This did not fix anything. We were both maxing it with no artifacts though, so if you like the console version then this will do you fine. The port isn't bad, just not up to enthusast standards, which I suppose isn't what Sonic is for, but it would be nice. Escpecially since Pirates/Emulators CAN run these things at 4k144 which sucks for steam users.)

number of helpful: 17 of 42 people (40%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 4, 2014
„I beat You all the time by myself Eggman, and now there’s two of me!” ~Sonic The above quotation sums up the whole idea of this new Sonic installment pretty well. What You get in Sonic Generations is more of the same, proven experience known from some of the  older SEGA productions.  Across the course of the game we revisit some iconic locations from the Sonic universe both in 2D and 3D incarnations, and once again roll through them with a blazing speed.Unfortunately the game does not introduce anything new, except more of the old ideas. Even challenges (called acts) assisting each main level feel somehow repetitive and in most cases waste their own potential. There are a few promising moments, but in most cases they’re ruined by numerous bugs, glitches and sloppy controls.As I said earlier, the whole idea about the game, and it’s main plot twist is an emergence of a mysterious time-eating fellow who “erases time”. This allows our heroes, namely Sonic and Tails, to team up with their previous incarnations on a quest to save all well-known Sonics friends. During our task we’ll be forced to beat each area twice, both with our “new” fully 3-dimensional Sonic, and his old-2D-only-self, once again collect all chaos emeralds, and finally beat time-eating creature.The plot is almost nonexistent, dialogues between Sonic and Tails feel stiff and does not encourage to explore the world. The case is similar with our friends, who once rescued reappear only to help us during certain, usually 2-3 minutes long acts, by performing certain special actions. Sadly those certain acts are usually affected by the highest number of glitches.There are only two good things I could say about this game, while recommending it to any non-hardcore Sonic fan would be the music and the modds. Music in this game is simply a collection of best pieces from the previous Sonic Games, which more than once proved itself to be one of the strongest points of the series, perfectly accompanying our high-speed runs through the world.As for the modding system it’s unofficial, but in my opinion the game improves dramatically after a few modds are installed. Luckily most of them come equipped with a guides allowing us to change the game drastically. Not only we are able to change our playable character, add new levels or even add new game modes, but also change already existing levels, or even affect controls of both Sonics.Summing up, the game is not bad, and I’d risk saying that it’s still, despite all its flaws, a solid Sonic experience. Unfortunately numerous bugs, glitches, poor plot, and terribly broken on-line mode make it feel like an unfinished product. So if You’re not some kind of hardcore-hedgehog fan, better avoid this game and get Yourself one of the older, proven editions.Pros:•	Refreshed classic levels•	Old music brought back to life•	2D and 3D gameplay mode in one gameCons:•	Extremely sloppy controls both with keyboard and X-box controller•	Booring plot, and repetitive side challenges (acts)•	High number of bugs and glitches•	Broken on-line mode•	Visibly unfinished product with a lot of wasted potential

content:
Posted: July 18, 2016
												I really want to recommend this game for it's fantastic level design and soundtrack, but there is just one problem that placed my review in the negative.The controls for this game are atrocious. Usually I play fast-paced platformers with a controller to give myself precise movement when going from point A to point B, but the fact that this game can barely keep the button input to controller really bugs me.  I can only play 10 minutes of the game before the game purposely messes up my controller scheme and I end up dying.  The majority of my deaths in this game come from this problem.SEGA, it's been 5 years since this game came out. Why havn't you fixed this problem yet?You people might be saying, "Well, why can't you just get used to the keyboard controls?" Because the keyboard controls feel wonky controling Sonic around; it works well with the classic stages since they are all 2-D, but in the modern stages is where the problem of controling Sonic comes in, since his stages switch to 3-D.  Modern Sonic feels stiff controlling with 4 directional buttons compared to the joystick of a controller.Overall, I would say just buy a console version of this game.  You will enjoy it better than this version. Unless someone can find a solution to the controller problem, I will not recommend this version of the game.

Posted: January 20, 2015
												Sonic Generations could have been a good game, but the controls, the messed up automated camera movement and all kinds of perplexing bugs make this high-speed platformer a complete mess. [EDIT: It is possible that my hardware is the cause of some of the problems described in this review (see comments).]pro:+ nice graphics and level design+ high speedcontra:- just a few levels- controls slow and messed up- automated camera movement- optimization issues, low framerate (sic!)- music can get on your nerves- a lot of bugs - for example: 1) sonic getting stuck in some part of the scenery with the need to restart the level; 2) automated camera movement makes a wrong turn for some reason, you cannot see the character or the course anymore and have to restart; 3) elements of the scenery appearing or disappearing; 4) sonic "transporting" from one spot on the screen to another; 5) sonic not reacting to input (however, this may in part be due to the slow controls)Seriously, I got it on a 75% sale and even though I got some fun out of it, it was not worth the money AND the frustration resulting from all the issues named above....BTW, if you wonder about the short time i spent in the game according to steam: I played quite a few hours and finished all the main levels in the game, but steam never recognizes the time I spent in a game while being offline...

												There's nothing I can tell you about this game you don't already know. Sonic in 3-D remains as terrible an idea as letting John Romero make Daikatana. Sonic in 2-D handles about the same as Mario in New Mario Wii; that is to say, about as enjoyably as getting your nuts pounded on a dresser with a spiked bat. If you're like me and are willing to slog through all the dull parts because you're intrigued by the remade levels from earlier games, just save yourself the disappointment and money and go buy Sonic's Ultimate Genesis Collection. The idea that this game was made by professionals is both comical and an insult to other professionals. You could devote an entire college course to studying the myriad ways this game fails. (2/10)

content:
Posted: August 5, 2014
												Sonic Generations is the game that really took a good, long look at Sonic and answered the very important question: why did Sonic never make the jump to 3D successfully?The answer, unfortunately, is that Sonic was never actually all that good in the first place, and this game merely throws this into sharp relief.Sonic Generations' fundamental premise is a split between the past and the present - half the stages in the game are old-school, 2D platformer stages similar to what you would have experienced on the Sega Genesis, but with much nicer graphics, while the other half of the stages in the game are new, 3D platformer stages rather like those in the new Sonic games.You would think that the 2D levels, being "good sonic", would be better, and on the whole that's correct, but really, the 3D stages aren't terrible by comparison in many cases - sure, they do have some obnoxious things to them here and there, but many of them flow fairly decently.The real problem is that the game is never really excellent, even though the earlier stages draw very heavily on the first few sonic games for their stages and mechanics. The sad truth is that the game really points out what is wrong with Sonic - that going incredibly fast and precision platforming are utterly at odds with each other, and while the loop-de-loops and other things that Sonic goes through were cool back in the day when the graphics looked really slick, nowadays, even with top-of-the-line graphics, you realize that it just is spectacle - there's no real substance to those parts, while the actually substantive parts, while okay, are not amazing.The game isn't terrible, but it isn't great either; it is okay on the whole. If you want to play a 2D/3D platforming game, you could do worse - and would be, if you played any other modern Sonic game. But if you're looking for a great new game to play, I'd go elsewhere - the game is okay, not awesome, but, alas, Steam does not allow a "meh".

number of helpful: 7 of 23 people (30%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: June 14, 2014
												Well i have to say this game has impressed me. Not because it's good but because i'm amazed at how frustratingly angry it managed to make me. And simply put if a game can't be enjoyed because it makes you as angry as it made me then it's just not   worth it. The worst part is that this game has so much promise and has a lot of the elements of a great game but it's let down by some of worst controls i've experienced in a long time coupled with terrible camera angles, which combined detroyed my ability to enjoy this game. In this game you play as both classic Sonic in levels reminiscent of the Mega Drive era Sonic as well as modern Sonic (or ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ Sonic as i prefer. I hate the way Sonic is now) in 3D levels.The Good:- the game does look beautiful and the visuals were the most impressive thing in this game for me. The levels have been lovingly designed and each one looks great. -the soundtrack is decent is well with remixed tracks from the older games which still sound good.- the 2D levels are good and play out almost exactly like the old MegaDrive ones.The Bad:- the controls. God they are terrible. I played with a 360 controller and found the controls laggy and unresponsive which in a game that is very fast is a recipe for disaster. - the awful camera angles. The amount of times the camera changes mid jump or during some other tricky maneuvere is ridiculous and leads to a lot of deaths. This is the last thing you need when the controls are as awful as they are.- The story is completely forgettable tripe but to be fair a good story has never been a necessity in a Sonic game.It really does kill me to have to slate this game because i feel it would have been a classic if not for those controls and camera angles. I wanted so badly to like this game but it just got to a point where i was to frustrated to even want to play anymore and it became an ordeal. I could only recommend this to hardcore Sonic fans. To anyone else just give it a miss. 4/10

Posted: May 7, 2014
												I bought this game £5. Whilst it's certainly worth what you pay for, I definitely would not recommend this game. The story is ok at best, but the dialogue is so cliche and dragging. The side scrolling levels are the best bits, but when it gets to 3D sonic, it is terrible. Controls are not responsive, the homing attacks are a nuisance and most of the time you have no control of sonic whatsoever. There also plenty of side missions which is why I say this game is worth £5. But some side missions are repetitive, or just plainly uninspired. I got the feeling that TEAM SEGA really rushed making this game.5.5/10

content:
Posted: January 10, 2015
AUDIORemastered ClassicsVISUALHybrid Mash-upDIFFICULTYEasyVIBEBalancedCRAVINGDelightfulON SALEOccasionallyPROS:  It's fascinating to see how a level from the newer 3D sonic games could have looked in 2D, and vice-versa. The game plays rather fun in both modes, and when you're done with each 3D/2D level there are a slew of challenges unlocked for each stage. The game knows that a big driving force in the franchise is its awesome soundtrack and uses it to its advantage. It's a pretty definitive collection for what music the series has to offer! For once, Sonic's controls are spot-on. We haven't seen this in a long, long time.CONS: This installment is not without its glitches, despite its uncharacteristic polish. The bonus level for Rouge is badly glitched, the scoreboard is completely down, and some levels deal with game-crashing glitches. Not only is it the scene to be pointed to for how the story is horribly told through monologuing, but this boss single-handedly showcases the curse of Sonic The Hedgehog: The crash and burn that occurs when new, relatively untested elements are brought to the table. The final level is an absolute mess of poor conveyance, disorienting depth issues and various characters constantly distracting you with irrelevant tips.WORTH: This one goes on sale about five times a year for up to 75% off. However, Sonic steam keys get bundled often outside of Steam. You may want to try sites like Bundlestars and Indiegala, as they have sales with more frequency.OVERALL: It's not the beacon to the promised land people are making it out to be, but Sonic Generations is cool and has a fair amount of content to keep you entertained. It's the kind of game you want to get really good at, because success within it is satisfying as hell! The Sonic formula is composed of some very fickle elements, so the impression this one leaves of true balance is rather amazing.SCORE: 8/10                                                                     Full Review Coming SoonEdit: I have made it recently a personal policy to not recommend games with broken achievements. People may not discover this fact until after several hours of completionist play, and after experiencing that myself twice, I've found it to be unfair! whether or not you find the goals of completionists agreeable or foolish, I'd hope you can agree that achievements unattainable through any legitimate means are damaging to the community, as they promote hacking and developer carelessness for these established systems.

content:
Posted: March 6, 2015
												The graphics, music and levels in this game are pretty good, but the gameplay and controls on the other hand...You are not rewarded for trying to speed things up, one boost with modern sonic and you will end up in the water/lava/whatever is around the tiny platforms. The general controls are very 'slippery'. With retro sonic even you can't platform like you are supposed to and it's very annoying. With the wonky controls even pressing A twice will make you fling off way too far into the direction you weren't facing (with modern sonic). There's a lot of precise platforming required in this game and not being able to stop where you want to is very frustrating. The levels and bosses are easy and the only thing you will die from is falling in the water due to trying to go fast, pressing A when something to interact with just gets randomly deselected and you will end up in the water, and just not being able to change direction at all.To make it even shorter I liked the retro sonic levels a bit because they resembled the old sonic games slightly, and that's where it stops being a game and starts being a terrible experience (mostly gameplay wise).

content:
Posted: December 26, 2012
												Call me crazy (don't really, because I'll get sad), but I don't like any of the 2D Sonic games. In fact, with the exception of Sonic Adventure 2 I don't like any of the 3D ones either.Sonic Generations is what has been described to me as the best of both worlds. To be completely honest, I don't know anything about the 2D levels (a friend played those, I did the 3D ones) because I completely tuned out when it wasn't my turn.The 3D levels, on the other hand, have two parts. The first being when the camera is behind Sonic, the player simply needing to make him sidestep occasionally while he runs. The second being when the camera is to Sonic's side, in which case you can run into enemies and walls repeatedly because there's no bloody way to see what's coming.To a non-fan, the "story" consists of Sonic dicking around through time and saving a buttload of characters you probably won't know and definitely won't like.Rating:♥♥♥♥♥♥10

content:
Posted: June 21, 2014
												This game is like your best friend's younger sister.  You're best friend is also probably classic Sonic.  This game is cute, and has fun on its own, and begs for you to play with it, but damn what a ♥♥♥♥♥.  This game is so finicky to get going, and never feels quite right.  If you like Sonic, you already own this game.  If you don't care about the series and want to play something that lives up to its hype, buy a console version that handles the way it should.Scale: 1=despised 2=negative 3=could go either way 4=positive 5=lovedGame design: 3/5  It's not so much the game itself that sucks, it's the lack of options and compatibility.  Controller functionality is pretty much broken and who wants to play $30 for a Sonic game just to be forced to use WASD.  Plus, like most Sonic games, this one glitches out the♥♥♥♥♥ but I guess that's just part of the tribute to modern era Sonic.  Classic Sonic levels are suprisingly tight tho.Tone: 5/5 The story blows, but what do you expect for Sonic?  What do you expect for a crossover?  That is what this is right, generational crossover?  Regardless, this game is conceptually beautiful and comes together pretty nice.  Level designs capture both eras in a pretty real way.Personal skew: 2/5  I'd be all over this game if the developers seemed to give a crap about their product.  Thanks for porting to PC... Please fix it.

content:
Posted: January 5, 2014
												I love Sonic the Hedgehog games and this one is no exception, sadly this version of the game is a mix of love and hate. This game makes me feel really nostalgic playing my old favourite levels in a newly designed world and amazing and the story for this game seems well thought out for what I've played of it, and the game just feels fast pace which was alway's one of Sonic's charms. The bad is the PC version of the game can be painful to play because it's has a few annoying glitches, some of the levels will cause the game to crash, and some of the cut scenes audio don't line up with voices and some of the cutscenes will just end abruptly to the point you feel like you misses something or don't notice it until the next cutscene. Some of these though annoying can be ignored but one glitch can not be ignored because it makes the game virtually unplayable the glitch happens when someone uses a non XBOX 360 controller, it seems random but when playing as modern Sonic will start to flip to the left of the screen, sometimes it may happen once or twice or never stop leaving sonic to constantly flip out causing me to die A LOT. I've also tried programs to fix this but nothing worked for me. my final thoughts would be to buy this game for your XBox 360 it's probably the safest bet, because this game is great but due to the issues listed above can be a pain to play.  The only way I'd recommend getting this game is if you buy the Sonic hits Collection pack, I was lucky enough to get it on same so I only paid $1 for this game but even if the pack is at full price of $30 paying $2 for each sonic game is a steal and if it works for you then bonus.Thanks for reading and I hoped this helped.

number of helpful: 2 of 13 people (15%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 5, 2014
												GameplayYou know, I would have loved this game if the developers weren't so god damn convinced that anyone gives more than two ♥♥♥♥♥ about the bloody 3d sonic games.The 2d sections are a wonderful throwback to the original games and even the 2d sections of the new 3d games are quite enjoyable. But the 3d portions are littered with small platforms, unresponsive  controls.  Badly integrated gimmicks and quite frankly gameplay that would make sonic '06 look good. I haven't touched on the Bossbattles yet, In my oppinion the boss battles are the only time the 3d parts actually serve a purpose. Like with the rest of the game the developers pushed the gimmick of having half 2d and half 3d in the boss battles as  well  but since some if not most of the bossbattles are slower pased you can actually see where you are going and controll the character.  Sadly half of a decent game does not a good game make.  I couldn't force myself to finish the game.  Unless you really enjoy the 3d sonic games.  And if you do bless you for you have a much higher tolerance for ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t than I have. I'd say pick up the game because its really clear that the developers tried to push that the most.  For anyone else I'd suggest that you veer away from this game.  A small note on the DLC  From what the dlc offers its quite clear that we don't have to look here for any improvement of the original game either. The Dlc merely offers some new gimmicks and not the throwbacks to some nostalgia that the package teases us with.ConclusionsAll in all I'd say that the franchise is running kind of stale. Where Super Mario 64 managed to embrace 3d and pull out something worth looking at.  Sonic never made the transition all that smoothly,  You just can't have a 3d platformer and keep the sense of speed that you want in a sonic game.

content:
Posted: November 9, 2011
												In typical Modern Sonic style, the levels are all balls hard with too much visual clutter and zero reaction time. As a result, you can't tell what's coming up and you can't tell what's going on. If you manage to get something right, then it's generally either by chance or because you've replayed the same level 50 times just to try and nail that one impossible jump at high speed with lousy steering accuracy.It also seems very counter intuitive when using the boost ability causes you to miss almost every shortcut because you're moving too fast, so you end up taking the longer path with more obstacles and you end up wasting more time than you saved by boosting.For the record, it's a pretty bad design choice when selecting 'restart level' from the pause menu will reduce your life counter by 1, but quitting to the level select area then reselecting the level will not carry this penalty.Don't bother buying this. Go buy the Mega-Drive classics and play all the Sonic games there instead.

number of helpful: 5 of 20 people (25%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: December 6, 2014
												Sonic Generations takes gamers on a romp through the history of Sonic the Hedgehog and, as a result, shows a bite-sized look at the downfall of their mascot.The story plays out like this, at a picnic for Sonic's birthday, all of his buddies including Tails, Knuckles, Amy and... everyone else... get sucked into a big portal thingy made by a big monster. Sonic follows and has to save them as they have been frozen in a big, white wasteland. Meanwhile, Sonic and Tails from the past have been scooped up as well and are also running through levels too because reasons.Sure the storyline is a bit ridiculous but that's fine. It's a great excuse to have Sonic play through reimaginings of his most iconic levels in both the original 2D style and the new 3D style of his more recent outings and it first, it's a blast. Only at first, though. The game works like this, there are three sections of the game consisting of three stages and a boss battle. Each stage has two acts giving a total of 18 levels plus four boss battles (because of the final boss). Act 1 of every stage has you playing as old-school Sonic in a 2D style while Act 2 lets you play as the newer Sonic.At the beginning of the game, this works out really well. I grew up with Sonic the Hedgehog and getting to play through the reimagined Green Hill Zones and Chemical Plant Zones were wonderful. Not only that, but they actually gave me a greater appreciation for the newer style of Sonic the Hedgehog. 2D Sonic was great but I often found myself missing the homing blast and greater ability set of older Sonic of which younger Sonic is missing all but his iconic spin dash. Once you get through a set of three levels, a huge glut of 30 challenges unlock that have you playing through the levels with different variations such as ghost races or playing with one of Sonic's friends. It can be overwhelming but the game only makes you try one from each stage in order to unlock three boss keys bringing you to the boss fight. It's a great way to add additional content without forcing players into repetition.Unfortunately, as the game progresses, the level design starts to reflect the newer games which is far from a good thing. the Sonic '06 level takes you into a firy apocalpyse where you have to avoid a giant flame tornado and from here on, the whole game starts going up in smoke. Levels start throwing ridiculous obstacles in your way and seem to actively prevent you from enjoying the speed previous levels have enjoyed. Whereas before you got to skateboard down a hill chased by a giant, demon-possessed truck, now the ground is broken up with near-constant stops and barriers. Playing as 2D Sonic, it was a blast getting to spin dash and enjoy the rush of speed but now, spin dashing will only bring you less than a second before you run into a wall that simply doesn't need to be there. The 3D Sonic fares better in these stages but he's not immune from their effects either. Levels start frequently using newbie traps that aren't challenging as long as you know they are there, bringing your fun to an unnecessary stop seemingly just to prevent a perfect run on the first try. Also, the camera starts doing very funny things, trying to work around all the jumble of visual assets that frankly don't need to exist. Depth is also a very tough thing to judge in the 3D levels, frequently resulting in missing rings and rails that require a specific type of jump.Despite the dire nature of the game, Sonic '06 is far from the worst. In fact, one of the better rated Sonic games in recent memory, Sonic Colors, results in easily the worst of the bunch. Requiring ridiculous power-ups to move forward that constantly result in slowing down and finding the ability means these levels take easily over 8 minutes each, a near-eternity for a Sonic game. Considering the powers weren't fun to begin with, 8 minutes of near constant power-up hunting is a slog that no one should have to suffer through.*Possible minor spoilers below. Seriously, quite minor though. Skip paragraph if you so choose.*So you've beaten all the stages, gotten all 7 Chaos Emeralds and are ready for the final battle. It's Super Sonic time, right? Well, I don't think I'm spoiling anything by saying yes (this is Sonic after all), but you're in for the worst time as Super Sonic ever. The movement is so incredibly unresponsive and your objective is so unclear that I actually wanted this segment of the game to end, the first time I've ever thought that playing as Super Sonic in any of the games prior. It wasn't a power rush but actually made me feel like I was completely out of control of the character as he did whatever he wanted. You can switch between 2D and 3D on the fly during this battle but I'm still not sure what the point of 2D was as it never did any damage to the boss. Maybe I missed something but, in that case, why was it not clear what I was supposed to be doing?*End spoilers*Ultimately,  Sonic Generations starts off great and crashes and burns as it progresses, basically just like Sonic the Hedgehog. Still, this is probably the best Sonic game since Sonic Adventure 2 and there is plenty of fan service ranging from unlockable concept art to music from the games. Saying this is the best Sonic game since 2001, though, really isn't saying much. If you are a Sonic fan like me craving a good, modern Sonic game, this is the closest you will get. If you are a Sonic skeptic, however, this won't change your mind.

content:
Posted: October 7, 2014
This review is based on my own experience with the game. I understand that other people may have more positive experiences than I did, but this review isn't based on that. This is about the troubles I faced trying to get this game to work, and the terrible response the game gave me in return. Thank you for understanding.Sonic Generations is a great game. The intense platforming style of Sonic is one of the greatest gaming experiences that you will ever play. But the game was definitely made with consoles in mind.The story in Sonic Generations is definitely generic, but it's not dislikeable. All of Sonic's friends have prepared a birthday picnic for him. Before they know it, everyone is sucked up by 'time holes' and scattered in different places in history. Sonic is then knocked out by the Time Eater, who created the time holes, and ends up a sort of purgatory, known only as White Space. He then rescues Tails, only to find that they both have previous versions of themselves, a 3D version of their original forms in the earlier Sonic the Hedgehog games. Both of the Sonics then have to travel through time to rescue his friends and stop the Time Eater.I have no problems with the game itself, and from what I have seen, it runs perfectly on the PS3, Xbox 360 and 3DS. But the PC port of Sonic Generations was awful. If you have never used an Xbox controller before, you're in trouble, because the game has all the controls written out with A, B, X and Y. This makes keyboard controls confusing, and I often sat there trying to remember what the Enter button incase I stuffed something up.The game also performs poorly, and even with the graphics on medium, I was only getting around 15-20 frames per second on a PC that could handle other games of the same graphical quality well. I was extremely disappointed, and also did not enjoy the settings for the game, which opened in a completely different window, and were confusing to change.Fortunately, I kept this game installed knowing that Microsoft was soon releasing the drivers for the Xbox One controller, so I plugged it in, hoping that Sonic Generations would respond to that. It did, and I was able to play the game well. But, being that I was recieving a minimal frame rate, I lost interest and played other games that I enjoyed and knew ran well.To sum up, Sonic Generations looks like an amazing game for console, but poor PC porting means that desktop players are left with no choice but to use a controller, and tolerate a low frame rate. If you are looking at getting Sonic Generations, don't buy it for PC.3.2/10

content:
Posted: July 13, 2014
												The game itself is nothing but a waste of money because it has levels that don't fit gameplay (or vice versa). In my opnion Sonic Colours was way better than this in terms of everything. By the way, Sonic Generations is very short and only has 18 levels and 43 bosses (not to also mention the stupid challenges). Okay, let's start off with classic Sonic's stages.Green Hill Zone: Bad, a stage that makes you feel that you need a homing attack. But some sections were really fun to speedrun through (no classic feel at all)Chemical Plant Zone: Good, homing attack doesn't feel like a requirement and it for some reason gives me the serious, but at the same time cute feel of the original stage. Most played classic Sonic's stage by me. Sky Sanctuary Zone: Awful, full of♥♥♥♥♥♥in the way (*cough-cough*EggRobo's*cough-cough*) and again the homing attack feels like a requirement.Speed Highway: Average, but an interesting stage. At some places homing attack does feel like a requirement, but if you can spindash right then you might start to actually like it.City Escape: Trolly, a stage that has a ot of♥♥♥♥♥♥in your way so I never enjoyed it. And the unexpected truck all over the place...Seaside Hill: Not recommended. I would definitely say that it's a lot more anjoyable to play the stage with the homing attack. Crisis City: Trolly again...Orange Roofs: I ♥♥♥♥ING HATE THIS♥♥♥♥♥♥br>Planet Wisp: I ♥♥♥♥ING HATE THIS♥♥♥♥♥♥br>Now for Modern stages:Green Hill Zone: Fits the gameplay, amazing music and cameras (and a beautiful Light Field). I've gotta love that Giant Chopper scene. I never imagined Green Hill Zone would be that great before I played it...Chemical Plant Zone: Awesome at the start. Both 3D and 2D sections are enjoyable. But it's hard to get on the rail at the last part. And again awesome music.Sky Sanctuary Zone:♥♥♥♥♥♥IN THE♥♥♥♥♥Speed Highway: Good at the start. If you can stay on the top pathways then it's one of the most enjoyable modern stages.City Escape: Y U DO THIS, SEGA & Sonic Team?Seaside Hill: The stage itself is slow-paced but it seems to quite fit the gameplay. Overall average.Crisis City: *♥♥♥♥♥♥s*Orange Roofs:♥♥♥♥♥♥IN THE♥♥♥♥♥Planet Wisp:♥♥♥♥♥♥IN THE♥♥♥♥♥Now let's talk about Super SonicClassic Super Sonic:♥♥♥♥♥♥IN THE♥♥♥♥♥Modern Super Sonic: MEAN♥♥♥♥♥♥IN A MEAN♥♥♥♥♥Bosses and rivalsMetal Sonic: boringGiant Mech: The only boss/rival I like.Shadow: Aren't we supposed to be friends now?Perfect Chaos: averageSilver: How the f#ck is he supposed to even f#cking know me?Egg Dragoon:♥♥♥♥♥♥in the♥♥♥♥♥..Time Eater:♥♥♥♥♥♥♥:P5,5/10

content:
Posted: February 22
												This is honestly not a very good game. I expected a lot after all the praise I read but I don't see it.As someone that enjoyed the oldschool Sonic games this game did not hit the spot. The classic 2D sections had clunky physics stemming from the 3D engine(I fell out of the very first level in my first try even fffs) and the 3D Sonic sections are as horrible to play as I always thought they looked like. There seems to be a lack of quantity in levels and I was disapointed that the Flame-Blitz-Bubble shields were not used to design levels and instead used for challenges and unlockable skill.I will say that the developers made the most of the game by offering challenges, ratings, hidden red rings for every level. So if you enjoy it then you have a lot of extra playtime in this package to unlock stuff.The music is also very nice with many of the hits.I give this a thumbs down because Valve can't be arsed to implement a proper rating system and I think you should just go emulate or buy the roms if you are looking for 2D Sonic fun because this is -just- an ok game.

												If you owned a Genesis, first of all, good on you, secondly, you should buy this game.  It will make you feel like you're 13 again.  It's hard to trust a Sonic game when SEGA has thrust the franchise into the ground, but I have to say, this does a great job of bringing back the brand.  There are many reasons to play games: new ways of thinking, artistic appreciation, exploring new genres, but this one has the most important quality: it's ♥♥♥♥ing fun as hell.

content:
Posted: April 7, 2012
												Meine persönliche Jump´n Run Referenz der letzten Jahre und eine Messlatte für alle Jump´n Runs, die mit den Genregrößen aufschließen wollen.Das Jubiläumsspiel des blauen Schalligels macht seinem Namen alle Ehre und fährt sämtliche Geschütze auf. Die Musikuntermalung kommt wie gewohnt von Crush 40, vielmehr ist es eine Kompilation guter alter Stücke, die neu aufbereitet in das Hauptspiel implementiert wurden.Die Level lassen uns in Erinnerungen schwelgen, da es sich um Neuflagen alter Serienteile handelt, z.b Green Forest (Sonic the Hedgehog) oder City Escape (Sonic Adventure 2),in diesem Falle handelt es sich jedoch nicht nur um eine grafische Generalüberholung, sondern vielmehr um eine komplette Umstrukturierung der gesamten Levelarchitektur,überdies sind die Level jeweils in 2D und 3D gehalten und mit der jeweiligen Sonic Figur anwählbar. Das Geschwindigkeitsgefühl ist schwindelerregend gut und dank der hervorragend justierten Kamera geht die Übersicht nie flöten.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: May 31, 2014
												This is, without a doubt the most fun I've ever had playing a platformer. It's the best platformer I've played with Rayman Origins and Ducktales Remastered right behind. Everything about it is so...perfect. The music, the animation, the visuals, even the gameplay for once, just fantastic. It's really the perfect Sonic the Hedgehog game. Basically what happens is that a mysterious monster has erased Sonic and his friends, as well as the young Sonic (Sega Genesis era) and Tails. Now, Sonic(s) must race through their past to restore it and their friends. Young Sonic's gameplay is more 2D, and is like the Genesis games with a modern touch (although light), and its great, as good as the old sonic games. In the modern Sonic sections, that's where the game gets great. They really finally did it. They made 3D sonic great. It combines the fast paced nature of Sonic Adventure 1, with the platforming of Sonic Adventure 2, and it works fantastic. Overall, I can't say enough good things about this game. Believe it or not, I was actually like, close to tears when I played this. The good kind of tears, it was just completely overwhelming to a long time sonic fan, its just so great. There are a couple bad things. One is very minor, and is that the main stages are a bit too easy. You have to try very very hard not to get below a B rank, and I only remeber running out of lives once, on a boss fight. Not to say that there aren't challenges though, there's lots of sub-missions that are plenty challenging, and there are a lot of them. And there are time records, all sorts of stuff to add lots of replayability. The collectibles are great, and its fun to team up with other sonic characters to accomplish them. Another thing that is a minor complaint is although the diversity in the levels is astounding, there are some times when I said "wait, wasn't there a segment just like this in the previous level?" This is also minor, and is present in most games, so its no big.Pretty much the last thing I can possibly say about this thing is that its kinda cheesy, it's adorably cheesy though, I'll be rolling my eyes, but honestly, this is pretty great for a Sonic game, which has had lots of uh...groan worthy writing in the past. Lastly, there's pretty much no story, its there, but it is pretty generic, but its fine, and obviously is there to provide context for this remix of games. Oh, and the boss fights are mixed, they're not great, but there's been worse, and the only real problem with them is the gameplay of it, in that they're simple, but I don't mind, really, they're not really awful like some.All in all, all of these complaints, I'm just trying to force myself to say something bad. You have to understand, it is a sensational game. If you haven't got it already, get it. Do it. Honestly the only reason that you wouldn't at least enjoy it a little bit is if you really, really, really hate platformers, or uh, action games, or fun. Buy itdo it

content:
Posted: December 1, 2015
												This is the game that shows that the Sonic franchise is not a lost cause, fans need to stop complaining that Sonic games should be like this and be like that, and instead just ask that they should be good.Like I said in my Sonic 4 review, the reason why Sonic failed so bad in recent years, is not trivial things like Sonic's green eyes, homing attacks and Dr. Robotnik now being Dr. Eggman, the problems are SEGA and Sonic Team's incompetence, while Sonic 4 was made to be exactly what everyone wanted and still divided opinions, Sonic Generations has a lot of things that purist fans didn't want but still was liked by most people.The Classic Sonic stages did a much better job on capturing the essence of the Sega Genesis / Mega Drive games than Sonic 4, and unlike what those whiny fans say, the levels with Modern Sonic are also very likeable.The game has flaws and some parts are bad, like the Final Boss that I managed to beat and I'm not sure what I did, but overall this is a great Sonic experience, again, showing that there is still hope for this franchise.
